{
  "translated_title": "Cho Kuk Indicted on Bribery and Other Charges... Forged Internship Certificate Under Choi Kang-wook's Name (3rd Comprehensive Report)",
  "translated_text": "[Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Gye-yeon = Prosecutors on the 31st brought former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54) to trial on charges including bribery. Prosecutors determined that the scholarship Cho's daughter received from Pusan National University School of Medicine was a bribe. Circumstances were also uncovered showing that former Minister Cho forged a lawyer internship activity certificate under the name of Choi Kang-wook (51), Blue House Public Service Discipline Secretary.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Anti-Corruption Investigation Division 2 (Chief Prosecutor Go Hyeong-gon) indicted former Minister Cho without detention this morning. This comes 126 days after the investigation began with extensive searches and seizures on August 27. With this, the investigation into corruption charges against former Minister Cho and his family has essentially concluded.

Former Minister Cho faces 11 charges including bribery, violations of the Improper Solicitation and Graft Act and Public Service Ethics Act, obstruction of justice by deception, obstruction of business, exercise of forged official documents, exercise of falsely prepared official documents, forgery of private documents, exercise of forged private documents, instigation to forge evidence, and instigation to conceal evidence. The indictment spans 58 pages.

Prosecutors applied bribery and Improper Solicitation and Graft Act violation charges regarding the 6 million won [approximately $4,500 USD] scholarship that daughter Cho (28) received from Pusan National University School of Medicine from November 2017 to October the following year.

Roh Hwan-jung (60), director of Busan Medical Center who gave the scholarship to the daughter, was also brought to trial on charges of offering bribes and violating the Improper Solicitation and Graft Act. Prosecutors determined that former Minister Cho, as Blue House Civil Affairs Senior Secretary at the time, was in a position to exercise influence over the operation of Yangsan Pusan National University Hospital where Director Roh worked, as well as high-level appointments such as Pusan National University Hospital director.

Former Minister Cho is also charged with involvement in his children's university admissions fraud along with his wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57, indicted under detention) of Dongyang University.

The charges include falsely obtaining an internship activity prospective certificate from Seoul National University's Public Interest & Human Rights Law Center for son Cho (23) in July 2013 and submitting it to Hanyoung Foreign Language High School, and submitting falsely prepared materials including internship activity certificates for the son's graduate school admissions to Korea University and Yonsei University in October-November 2017 and to Chungbuk National University Law School in October the following year.

Prosecutors determined that the Cho couple, when their son would miss classes to prepare for overseas university admission, asked Professor Han In-seop of Seoul National University Law School to issue a false internship prospective certificate to get attendance recognized. They found that former Minister Cho forged his daughter's Seoul National University Public Interest & Human Rights Law Center internship certificate.

Circumstances also newly emerged showing Secretary Choi's involvement in former Minister Cho's son's admissions fraud.

Prosecutors confirmed that the son falsely obtained lawyer internship certificates under Secretary Choi's name twice in 2017-2018, when Choi was with law firm Cheongmaek, and submitted them for graduate school admissions. Based on physical evidence secured from around former Minister Cho, they concluded that Secretary Choi issued the first internship certificate, and former Minister Cho directly forged the second one.

Secretary Choi, a former military prosecutor, is a junior of former Minister Cho from Seoul National University Law School. He served as chair of the Judicial Committee of Lawyers for a Democratic Society (Minbyun) and entered the Blue House in September last year, working with former Minister Cho for nearly a year. Secretary Choi is reportedly refusing to comply with prosecutors' requests for appearance.

[Yonhap News file photo]

It was also discovered that former Minister Cho took his son's exams at George Washington University in the United States. Prosecutors determined that Minister Cho received online exam questions from his son twice in November-December 2016 and solved them separately, resulting in the son receiving an A grade, and applied obstruction of business charges against George Washington University. The false documents submitted for domestic graduate school admissions also included a George Washington University scholarship certificate.

Former Minister Cho is also charged with violating Public Service Ethics Act obligations for blind trust and falsely reporting assets in connection with Professor Chung's nominee stock investments.

Prosecutors determined that former Minister Cho knew about Professor Chung's nominee stock investments and jointly managed the assets. They allege that after taking office as Civil Affairs Senior Secretary in May 2017, he falsely reported having debts to hide nominee stocks worth approximately 800 million won [approximately $600,000 USD].

Prosecutors determined that former Minister Cho obstructed the Public Service Ethics Committee's asset review work by submitting falsely prepared loan agreements and other materials as explanatory documents.

Prosecutors also confirmed circumstances showing that funds for purchasing shares of secondary battery company WFM came from former Minister Cho's account. However, they did not apply bribery charges as they determined the stock purchase was unrelated to former Minister Cho's official duties.

There are also charges that he had Professor Chung forge private fund operation status reports during parliamentary confirmation hearings in August this year and instructed asset manager Kim (37) to replace and conceal the hard disk of the PC at his Bangbae-dong home in Seoul.

Prosecutors additionally indicted Professor Chung on charges including forging Dongyang University youth humanities program certificates and awards and submitting them to Hanyoung Foreign Language High School. Considering that the charges substantially overlap with Professor Chung's previous indictment, they requested that former Minister Cho's case be consolidated with Professor Chung's trial.

While they determined that the daughter and son conspired in some admissions fraud charges, they have not yet brought them to trial. Prosecutors stated, "We plan to sequentially conclude investigations of other related parties as well."

dada@yna.co.kr

Tips via KakaoTalk okjebo<Copyright holder (c) Yonhap News, unauthorized reproduction-redistribution, AI learning and use prohibited>December 31, 2019 4:37 PM transmission December 31, 2019 4:37 PM transmission"
}

{
  "translated_title": "Prosecutors Indict Former Minister Cho Kuk Without Detention on Bribery and Other Charges (Comprehensive Report 2)",
  "translated_text": "[Photo synthesis and illustration by Jang Hyeon-gyeong]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Gye-yeon = Prosecutors on the 31st sent former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54) to trial on charges including bribery. Prosecutors determined that the scholarship received by Cho's daughter at Pusan National University School of Medicine was a bribe.

This comes 126 days after launching the investigation with large-scale raids and searches on August 27. With this, the investigation into corruption charges against former Minister Cho and his family has been virtually concluded.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Anti-Corruption Investigation Unit 2 (headed by Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) indicted former Minister Cho without detention this morning.

The charges applied to former Minister Cho include 11 counts: bribery, violations of the Improper Solicitation and Graft Act and Public Service Ethics Act, obstruction of justice through deception, obstruction of business, exercising forged official documents, exercising falsely prepared official documents, forging private documents, exercising forged private documents, inciting evidence fabrication, and inciting evidence concealment. The indictment spans 58 pages.

Prosecutors applied bribery and Improper Solicitation and Graft Act violation charges regarding the 6 million won [approximately $4,500 USD] scholarship that his daughter Cho (28) received from November 2017 to October of the following year at Pusan National University School of Medicine.

Roh Hwan-jung (60), director of Busan Medical Center who gave the scholarship to the daughter, was also sent to trial on charges of bribery and violations of the Improper Solicitation and Graft Act. Prosecutors viewed that former Minister Cho, as Blue House [Korea's presidential office] Senior Secretary for Civil Affairs at the time, was in a position to exercise influence over the operation of Yangsan Pusan National University Hospital where Director Roh worked and regarding advancement to high-level positions such as director of Pusan National University Hospital.

Former Minister Cho is also suspected of being involved in his children's college admission fraud along with Professor Jeong [Kyung-sim, his wife].

The charges include: in July 2013, falsely obtaining an internship activity certificate from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his son Cho (23) and submitting it to Hanyoung Foreign Language High School; in October-November 2017, submitting falsely prepared materials including internship activity certificates for his son's graduate school admissions to Korea University and Yonsei University, and in October of the following year for admission to Chungbuk National University Law School.

Prosecutors determined that when the son would miss classes to prepare for overseas university admission, the Cho couple asked Professor Han In-seob of Seoul National University Law School to issue a false internship certificate to have his attendance recognized.

Prosecutors found that former Minister Cho forged the internship activity confirmation letter under the name of a lawyer at Law Firm A submitted for his son's graduate school admission, and his daughter's internship certificate from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center.

[Yonhap News file photo]

It was also discovered that former Minister Cho took his son's exams at George Washington University in the United States. Prosecutors determined that Minister Cho received online exam questions from his son on two occasions in November-December 2016 and solved them separately, resulting in his son receiving an A grade, and applied obstruction of business charges against George Washington University. The false documents submitted for domestic graduate school admissions also included a George Washington University scholarship certificate.

Former Minister Cho is also charged with violating mandatory blind trust obligations under the Public Service Ethics Act and falsely reporting assets in connection with his wife Professor Jeong Kyung-sim's (57, indicted under detention) borrowed-name stock investments at Dongyang University.

Prosecutors determined that former Minister Cho knew about Professor Jeong's borrowed-name stock investments and jointly managed the assets. After taking office as Senior Secretary for Civil Affairs in May 2017, he allegedly falsely reported debts to hide borrowed-name stocks worth 800 million won [approximately $600,000 USD].

Prosecutors judged that former Minister Cho obstructed the asset review work of the Public Service Ethics Committee by submitting falsely prepared loan agreements and other materials as explanatory documents.

Prosecutors also confirmed circumstances showing that funds for purchasing stocks in secondary battery company WFM flowed out of former Minister Cho's account. However, they did not apply bribery charges, determining that the stock purchase was unrelated to former Minister Cho's official duties.

There are also charges that he conspired with Professor Jeong to forge private fund operation status reports during confirmation hearings in August this year and instructed asset manager Kim (37) to replace and conceal the PC hard disk at their Bangbae-dong [Seoul neighborhood] residence.

Prosecutors additionally indicted Professor Jeong on charges including forging certificates of completion and awards from Dongyang University's youth humanities program and submitting them to Hanyoung Foreign Language High School. Considering that the charges substantially overlap with those for which Professor Jeong was previously indicted, they requested that former Minister Cho's case be consolidated with Professor Jeong's trial.

While prosecutors determined that the daughter and son conspired in some college admission fraud charges, they have not yet sent them to trial. Prosecutors stated, "We plan to sequentially conclude investigations into the remaining related parties."

dada@yna.co.kr

Tips via KakaoTalk okjebo<Copyright holder (c) Yonhap News, unauthorized reproduction and redistribution, AI learning and use prohibited>Sent 2019/12/31 13:21 Sent December 31, 2019 1:21 PM"
}

{
  "translated_title": "[Timeline] From Cho Kuk's nomination as Justice Minister to prosecution indictment",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Do-hoon = On the morning of the 31st, when prosecutors indicted former Justice Minister Cho Kuk on charges including bribery, a banner bearing the image of former Minister Cho was hung in front of the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office. 2019.12.31 superdoo82@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Jae-hyun = Prosecutors indicted Cho Kuk (54), former Justice Minister, without detention on the 31st on charges including bribery, use of forged official documents, and violations of the Public Service Ethics Act.
This comes 126 days after launching the investigation with large-scale raids and searches on August 27.
The following is a major timeline related to former Minister Cho.
[Yonhap News file photo]

◇ August 2019
▲ August 9 = President Moon Jae-in nominates Cho Kuk, former presidential chief of staff for civil affairs, as Justice Minister.
▲ August 14 = President Moon submits personnel hearing request for candidate Cho to the National Assembly. Revelation of spouse and children's 7.4 billion won [approximately $5.5 million USD] private equity fund investment agreement.
▲ August 16 = Allegations raised regarding candidate Cho's family involving fake divorce, fake real estate transactions, fake address registration, and Woongdong Academy 'fake lawsuit' suspicions.
▲ August 19 = Allegation raised that candidate Cho's daughter received scholarships six times despite failing at Pusan National University School of Medicine.
▲ August 20 = Allegation raised that candidate Cho's daughter was listed as first author on a medical paper while in high school and used this for university admissions.
▲ August 23 = Candidate Cho announces social return of private equity fund investment and Woongdong Academy.
▲ August 27 = Prosecutors launch full-scale investigation by deploying Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office special investigation unit. Raids and searches at about 30 locations including Seoul National University and Pusan National University.
[Yonhap News file photo]

◇ September
▲ September 2 = Candidate Cho holds press conference at the National Assembly after personnel hearing falls through.
▲ September 3 = Prosecutors conduct second raids and searches at Dongyang University, Seoul National University Medical School, and others.
▲ September 4 = Allegation raised of forgery regarding commendation letter from Dongyang University president received by candidate Cho's daughter. Dongyang University President Choi Sung-hae tells media in interview, "Never issued a commendation letter."
▲ September 6 = Personnel hearing held 28 days after nomination. Prosecutors indict candidate Cho's wife Chung Kyung-sim on charges of forging Dongyang University commendation letter.
▲ September 9 = President Moon appoints candidate Cho as Justice Minister. Prosecutors request arrest warrants for private equity fund management company Colink Private Equity (Colink PE) CEO Lee Sang-hoon and Wells C&T CEO Choi.
▲ September 10 = Prosecutors conduct third raids and searches including home of Minister Cho's brother's ex-wife and fund investment target Wells C&T CEO Choi's residence.
▲ September 11 = Court rejects arrest warrants for Colink PE CEO Lee Sang-hoon and Wells C&T CEO Choi.
▲ September 14 = Prosecutors arrest Minister Cho's fifth cousin Cho upon his return to Korea in connection with 'private equity fund allegations.'
▲ September 16 = Prosecutors request arrest warrant for Minister Cho's fifth cousin on charges including illegal trading and false disclosure under Capital Markets Act, embezzlement and breach of trust under Specific Economic Crimes Aggravated Punishment Act, and instigating evidence destruction. Court issues arrest warrant. Prosecutors summon Minister Cho's daughter for questioning.
▲ September 20 = Prosecutors conduct fourth raids and searches at Colink PE investment companies Iksung and IFM.
▲ September 21 = Prosecutors conduct fifth raids and searches at Woongdong Middle School and others regarding 'fake construction contract' allegations.
▲ September 22 = Prosecutors re-summon Minister Cho's daughter.
▲ September 23 = Prosecutors conduct sixth raids and searches at Minister Cho's Bangbae-dong residence, Ajou University, Chungbuk National University Law School, Yonsei University Graduate School, Ewha Womans University admissions office, and other universities where Minister Cho's children applied.
▲ September 24 = Prosecutors summon Minister Cho's son for questioning.
▲ September 26 = Prosecutors summon Minister Cho's brother and former sister-in-law for questioning.
▲ September 30 = Prosecutors request arrest warrant for broker Cho in connection with 'Woongdong Academy hiring corruption.'
[Yonhap News file photo]

◇ October
▲ October 1 = Broker Cho arrested in connection with 'Woongdong Academy hiring corruption.'
▲ October 3 = Prosecutors conduct first summoning of Minister Cho's wife Chung Kyung-sim for questioning. Request arrest warrant for 'Woongdong Academy hiring corruption' broker Park. Indict Cho Kuk's fifth cousin with detention on stock manipulation and embezzlement charges.
▲ October 4 = Prosecutors request arrest warrant for Minister Cho's brother on charges including breach of trust and acceptance of bribes under Specific Economic Crimes Aggravated Punishment Act, and instigating evidence destruction. Court issues arrest warrant for 'Woongdong Academy hiring corruption' broker Park.
▲ October 5 = Prosecutors conduct second summoning of Chung Kyung-sim for questioning.
▲ October 8 = Prosecutors conduct third summoning of Chung Kyung-sim for questioning. Prosecutors execute arrest warrant for Minister Cho's brother. Brother waives pre-arrest suspect interrogation.
▲ October 9 = Court rejects arrest warrant for Minister Cho's brother.
▲ October 12 = Prosecutors conduct fourth summoning of Chung Kyung-sim for questioning.
▲ October 14 = Prosecutors conduct fifth summoning of Chung Kyung-sim for questioning. Minister Cho resigns after 35 days in office.
▲ October 16 = Prosecutors conduct sixth summoning of Chung Kyung-sim for questioning.
▲ October 17 = Prosecutors conduct seventh summoning of Chung Kyung-sim for questioning.
▲ October 18 = First trial preparation session for Chung Kyung-sim's Dongyang University commendation letter forgery charges.
▲ October 21 = Prosecutors request arrest warrant for Chung Kyung-sim on 11 charges including false reporting and use of undisclosed information under Capital Markets Act, violations of Proceeds of Crime Control Act, obstruction of official duties by deception, use of falsely prepared official documents, and instigating evidence fabrication.
▲ October 23 = Court issues arrest warrant for Chung Kyung-sim. Detained at Seoul Detention Center.
▲ October 29 = Prosecutors re-request arrest warrant for former Minister Cho's brother.
▲ October 30 = Prosecutors raid and search four companies including Daebo Construction in connection with former Busan Deputy Mayor for Economic Affairs Yoo Jae-soo's 'inspection cover-up allegations.'
▲ October 31 = Court issues arrest warrant for former Minister Cho's brother. Detained at Seoul Eastern Detention Center.
[Yonhap News file photo]

◇ November
▲ November 4 = Prosecutors raid and search Financial Services Commission and others in connection with former Deputy Mayor Yoo Jae-soo's 'inspection cover-up allegations.'
▲ November 5 = Prosecutors raid and search former Minister Cho's research office at Seoul National University Law School.
▲ November 11 = Prosecutors additionally indict Chung Kyung-sim with detention, applying 14 charges including false reporting and use of undisclosed information under Capital Markets Act, violations of Financial Real Name Act and Proceeds of Crime Control Act.
▲ November 12 = Prosecutors raid and search Sangsangin Savings Bank regarding 'private equity fund involvement allegations.'
▲ November 14 = Prosecutors summon former Minister Cho for questioning regarding 'admissions corruption and private equity fund allegations.' Former Minister Cho exercises 'right to remain silent' during questioning.
▲ November 18 = Prosecutors indict former Minister Cho's brother with detention on charges including acceptance of bribes, obstruction of business, and instigating evidence destruction.
▲ November 19 = Prosecutors raid and search former Deputy Mayor Yoo Jae-soo's residence and office.
▲ November 21 = Prosecutors conduct second summoning of former Minister Cho for questioning regarding 'admissions corruption and private equity fund allegations.'
▲ November 25 = Prosecutors request arrest warrant for former Deputy Mayor Yoo Jae-soo on charges including bribery and improper handling after accepting bribes.
▲ November 27 = Court issues arrest warrant for former Deputy Mayor Yoo Jae-soo.
[Yonhap News file photo]

◇ December
▲ December 4 = Prosecutors raid and search Blue House Presidential Secretariat regarding 'Yoo Jae-soo inspection cover-up allegations.'
▲ December 11 = Prosecutors conduct third summoning of former Minister Cho for questioning regarding 'admissions corruption and private equity fund allegations.'
▲ December 13 = Prosecutors indict former Deputy Mayor Yoo Jae-soo with detention on bribery and other charges.
▲ December 16 = Prosecutors conduct first summoning of former Minister Cho for questioning regarding 'Yoo Jae-soo inspection cover-up allegations.'
▲ December 18 = Prosecutors conduct second summoning of former Minister Cho for questioning regarding 'Yoo Jae-soo inspection cover-up allegations.'
▲ December 23 = Prosecutors request arrest warrant for former Minister Cho.
▲ December 26 = Court conducts pre-arrest suspect interrogation of former Minister Cho.
▲ December 27 = Court rejects arrest warrant for former Minister Cho.
▲ December 31 = Prosecutors indict former Minister Cho without detention on bribery and other charges.
trauma@yna.co.kr
Tips via KakaoTalk okjebo<Copyright holder (c) Yonhap News, unauthorized reproduction-redistribution, AI learning and use prohibited>2019/12/31 11:43 transmission 2019 December 31 11:43 AM transmission"
}

{
  "translated_title": "Gwangju Education Office Restricts Hagwon Instructors from Concurrent Work as Arts High School Specialist Teachers",
  "translated_text": "[Yonhap News file photo]

(Gwangju=Yonhap News) Reporter Son Sang-won = Starting next year, Gwangju hagwon instructors will no longer be able to work concurrently as specialist subject teachers at arts high schools.

The Citizens' Movement for a Society Without Academic Cliques issued a press release on the 29th stating, "The Gwangju Metropolitan Office of Education's recently revised guidelines for contract teachers stipulate that concurrent employment is not permitted for occupations that directly impact students, such as hagwon instructors," and "The concurrent employment of hagwon instructors as arts high school teachers, which has been problematic, has become virtually impossible."

The citizens' group said, "We welcome the guideline revision," and urged that "the education office should secure a pool of specialist subject teachers based on public interest, and arts high schools should provide balanced career and academic guidance so they don't degenerate into mere tools for admission to prestigious universities."

The citizens' group had been demanding improvements, arguing that involving famous hagwon instructors in regular school curriculum—not just after-school programs—poses greater risks of indirectly promoting hagwons or encouraging sales of portfolio products like choreography and composition, rather than providing the positive function of managing practical instruction.

According to instructor profiles submitted by Gwangju arts high schools, 28 out of 255 specialist subject teachers (10.9%) were hagwon instructors, the citizens' group reported.

The citizens' group argued, "If arts high schools operate as curricula focused on college entrance exams, they block diverse career choices and planning centered on creativity," and "Going forward, when recruiting specialist subject teachers, hagwon owners and instructors should be excluded from hiring in accordance with guidelines and principles."

sangwon700@yna.co.kr
Tips via KakaoTalk okjebo<Copyright holder (c) Yonhap News, unauthorized reproduction-redistribution, AI learning and use prohibited>2019/12/29 15:45 transmission December 29, 2019, 3:45 PM transmission"
}

{
  "translated_title": "Prosecutors Wrap Up 4-Month Investigation into 'Family Corruption Allegations'... Cho Kuk to be Indicted This Week",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Han Jong-chan = Former Justice Minister Cho Kuk gets into a car after completing his second summons investigation at the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office on the afternoon of the 21st of last month. saba@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Seong Do-hyeon = Prosecutors who have investigated former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's 'family corruption' allegations for about 4 months will send the former minister to trial without detention this week and conclude their investigation. Whether to include Cho's daughter (28) as a defendant is still under consideration until the last minute.

◇ Cho Kuk indictment finalized... weighing timing of prosecution

According to the legal community on the 29th, the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Anti-Corruption Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) has virtually completed reviewing the legal theories to apply to Cho and other case-related individuals and drafting the indictment, and is deliberating the timing of prosecution.

Prosecutors were reportedly originally planning to send Cho to trial on the 27th.

However, it is known that the schedule was postponed after the court rejected an arrest warrant requested by the Seoul Eastern District Prosecutors' Office in connection with allegations of 'covering up inspections' against former Busan Deputy Mayor for Economic Affairs Yoo Jae-su (55, indicted under detention).

Prosecutors are not expected to indict Cho on the 30th, when Justice Minister nominee Choo Mi-ae's National Assembly confirmation hearing is held. This is because announcing investigation results regarding the immediate former Justice Minister on the day the successor minister nominee's confirmation hearing is conducted could raise unnecessary misunderstandings.

In particular, the 30th is also the day when the National Assembly is expected to hold its first plenary session of the new extraordinary session and vote on the Corruption Investigation Office for High-ranking Officials (CIO) bill placed on the fast track.

Since announcing investigation results when sensitive legislative issues are at stake could lead the political community to interpret this as a political act, there is a high possibility that prosecutors will exclude the 30th as the prosecution timing.

Prosecutors have recently announced their policy to indict Cho's family corruption allegations case 'within this year' if possible. Therefore, prosecutors are considering the 31st, the end of the year, as the prosecution timing.

However, since there is no situation requiring prosecution within the year at all costs, January 2nd of next year is also reportedly being considered as a strong option.

The case involving allegations of college admissions corruption and private equity fund irregularities involving former minister Cho's family, which began with extensive searches and seizures on August 27th, will see all related parties sent to trial within this week after 4 months.

[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

◇ Cho Kuk's daughter likely to be indicted without detention... brother-in-law and mother likely not to be prosecuted

Prosecutors have so far indicted 5 people under detention, including Professor Jeong. These include 3 family members - Professor Jeong, Cho's younger brother Jo (52), and his cousin Jo Beom-dong (36) - as well as 2 accomplices who served as money delivery agents in conspiracy with brother Jo regarding Ungdong Academy corruption.

Prosecutors continue to review whether to also indict the daughter when indicting Cho. The daughter is already specified as an accomplice in admissions corruption charges in Professor Jeong's indictment, which prosecutors additionally filed on the 11th of last month.

Within the prosecution, opinions reportedly include that since the mother has already been indicted under detention and the father will also be sent to trial, the daughter should receive prosecution deferment, as well as opinions to proceed with summary indictment for a fine since the charges are proven.

However, it is known that they are deliberating until the last minute, as there are also opinions that indictment without detention is inevitable considering that both parents were not detained and the daughter denied all charges and did not cooperate with the investigation.

Prosecutors are also referencing the case of a former Sungkyunkwan University professor who was indicted under detention on charges including obstruction of business for having students ghostwrite papers for his college student daughter's Seoul National University Graduate School of Dentistry admissions. At that time, the daughter was indicted without detention along with her mother.

Prosecutors reportedly concluded not to send Cho's son (23) to trial. Cho's mother Park (81, chairperson of Ungdong Academy), who was implicated in Ungdong Academy corruption allegations, is also reportedly not expected to be prosecuted.

Regarding private equity fund allegations, prosecutors are expected to indict without detention Professor Jeong's younger brother Jeong, executive managing director of Bonamie System who was an 'accomplice' with Professor Jeong and Jo, as well as Lee Sang-hoon (40), nominal representative of private equity fund management company Colink Private Equity (PE), and Choi (54), CEO of streetlight flasher manufacturer Wells C&T.

In addition, Kim Kyeong-rok, a Korea Investment & Securities private banker (PB) who serves as asset manager for Cho's family and helped with personal PC hard drive replacement, may also be sent to trial.

[Yonhap News file photo]

◇ Expected to be indicted for violations of Public Service Ethics Act, etc... interest in whether bribery charges will be applied

Cho faces allegations related to ▲ involvement in nominee stock investment in his wife's WFM shares ▲ daughter's receipt of Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine scholarship ▲ false issuance of Seoul National University Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center internship certificate ▲ Ungdong Academy sham litigation and hiring corruption ▲ false preparation of private equity fund operation status reports ▲ evidence destruction of PC at his Bangbae-dong, Seoul residence. He exercised his right to remain silent during three suspect interrogations.

Prosecutors are expected to include charges such as violations of the Public Service Ethics Act, which were not included in Professor Jeong's indictment, in Cho's indictment.

Prosecutors are expected to apply charges including violations of the Public Service Ethics Act for concealing Professor Jeong's nominee stock investment details during public official asset reporting, as well as violations of the Financial Real Name Act and criminal instruction for evidence concealment.

The point of interest is whether bribery charges will be applied to Cho. Prosecutors examined whether WFM sold stocks cheaply to Professor Jeong, Cho's wife, in expectation of influence from the Blue House senior secretary for civil affairs, and whether there was a bribery nature to the daughter's medical school scholarship.

Even after prosecutors conclude their investigation into 'family corruption' allegations, investigations targeting Cho will continue. The Seoul Eastern District Prosecutors' Office Criminal Division 6 (Chief Prosecutor Lee Jeong-seop) is investigating allegations of covering up former Deputy Mayor Yoo's inspection, while the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Public Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Kim Tae-eun) is investigating allegations of 'ordered investigations and election interference.'

After Cho's indictment, Anti-Corruption Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) will switch to a prosecution maintenance system. This is because the importance of trials has grown, with conflicts arising between prosecutors and the court over indictment amendments in Professor Jeong's trial for 'family corruption' allegations.

Some are interested in whether Cho's cases will be consolidated. If Cho is indicted related to 'family corruption' allegations, he will be tried at Seoul Central District Court. If he is additionally indicted for 'inspection cover-up' allegations, he will also be tried at Seoul Eastern District Court where former Deputy Mayor Yoo is being tried. Therefore, there are observations that he could be tried in one of the two courts through case consolidation.

A lawyer who is a former presiding judge said, "From the defendant's perspective, being tried in one place rather than multiple places is advantageous in terms of guaranteeing defense rights," but predicted, "Considering the different nature of family corruption and inspection cover-up allegations cases and that former Deputy Mayor Yoo is already being tried, there is a high possibility that the first trial will proceed in two branches and be combined in the second trial."

raphael@yna.co.kr
Report via KakaoTalk okjebo<Copyright holder (c) Yonhap News, unauthorized reproduction-redistribution, AI learning and utilization prohibited>2019/12/29 08:00 transmission December 29, 2019 08:00 transmission"
}

{
  "translated_title": "[Timeline] From Cho Kuk's nomination as Justice Minister to the rejection of his arrest warrant by prosecutors",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Ryu Young-seok = Former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, who has been under prosecution investigation on suspicions of covering up a Blue House inspection regarding former Busan City Economic Deputy Mayor Yoo Jae-su, is attending a pre-arrest suspect interrogation (warrant substantive review) held at Seoul Eastern District Court in Songpa-gu, Seoul on the 26th. 2019.12.26 ondol@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Seong Do-hyun = On the 27th, the court rejected the arrest warrant for former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, who was charged with abuse of authority and obstruction of rights exercise in relation to the 'inspection cover-up suspicions' involving former Busan City Economic Deputy Mayor Yoo Jae-su.
The following is a major timeline related to former Minister Cho.
◇ August 2019
▲ August 9 = President Moon Jae-in nominates former Blue House Civil Affairs Senior Secretary Cho Kuk as Justice Minister.
▲ August 14 = President Moon submits Cho's personnel hearing request to the National Assembly. Facts revealed about spouse and children's 7.4 billion won [approximately $5.6 million USD] private equity fund investment agreement.
▲ August 16 = Suspicions raised regarding Cho's family involving fake divorce, real estate disguised transactions, disguised address registration, and Woongdong Academy 'fake lawsuit' allegations.
▲ August 19 = Suspicions raised that Cho's daughter received scholarships six times despite failing at Pusan National University Medical School.
▲ August 20 = Suspicions raised that Cho's daughter was listed as first author on a medical paper during high school and used this for university admissions.
▲ August 23 = Cho announces social contribution of private equity fund investment and Woongdong Academy.
▲ August 27 = Prosecutors launch full investigation with Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Department. Search and seizure at about 30 locations including Seoul National University and Pusan National University.
◇ September
▲ September 2 = Cho holds press conference at National Assembly after personnel hearing falls through.
▲ September 3 = Prosecutors conduct second search and seizure at Dongyang University, Seoul National University Medical School, etc.
▲ September 4 = Suspicions raised about forgery of Dongyang University president's commendation certificate received by Cho's daughter. Dongyang University President Choi Seong-hae tells media, "Never issued such a certificate."
▲ September 6 = Personnel hearing held 28 days after nomination. Prosecutors indict Cho's wife Chung Kyung-sim on charges of forging Dongyang University commendation certificate.
▲ September 9 = President Moon appoints Cho as Justice Minister. Prosecutors request arrest warrants for Corlink Private Equity (Corlink PE) CEO Lee Sang-hoon and Wells C&T CEO Choi.

{
  "translated_title": "[New Year Interview] Seoul Education Superintendent Cho Hee-yeon: "Decision on Sunday Rest System for Hagwons to be Made After First Half of Year"",
  "translated_text": "Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education Superintendent Cho Hee-yeon. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education Superintendent Cho Hee-yeon stated in a New Year interview with Yonhap News on the 26th that he would make a conclusion on whether to introduce the 'Sunday rest system for hagwons,' which recently completed public deliberation, after the first half of next year.

Regarding 'mock election project classes' that conservative groups worry may have political bias, Superintendent Cho said, "I will ensure that (teachers) do not use it as a means to advocate political opinions or private interests."

The following is a Q&A with Superintendent Cho.

-- What are your thoughts as we welcome the New Year?

▲ I have set this year's theme as 'haehyeongyeongjang' [解弦更張], which means restringing a geomungo [traditional Korean zither]. I will tighten loose strings and replace broken ones.

In particular, next year will mark 10 years since the innovative school policy began in Seoul. I will examine the path we intended to take, the path we have actually walked, and the path we will move forward on.

-- Please select just three priority projects for the New Year.

▲ I want to focus more on the essence of education. First, I will achieve innovation in classes. At the same time, I will thoroughly take care of basic academic skills. Finally, I plan to strengthen ecological transformation education in response to the climate crisis.

-- Public deliberation on the Sunday rest system for hagwons, which would force hagwons in the Seoul area to rest on Sundays, recommended introducing the system. When will the decision on whether to introduce the system be made?

▲ The Sunday rest system for hagwons is a very sensitive policy where students, parents, hagwon operators, and hagwon instructors are all direct stakeholders. I also know that there are many opinions that it should not be introduced because it has limited effectiveness due to the balloon effect (Seoul hagwons resting would lead to a rush to hagwons in surrounding areas that don't observe the holiday) and because it violates (students') 'autonomous learning rights.'

Accordingly, I plan to decide carefully with sufficient time. After comprehensively reviewing the public deliberation results and policy research results coming out around February next year in the first half of next year, I will determine whether to introduce the system through close consultation with the Ministry of Education and the Seoul Metropolitan Council.

-- There are criticisms that it is 'hasty' for the education office to conduct mock election classes at 40 elementary, middle, and high schools during next year's general election as part of social issue education.

▲ The Public Official Election Act amendment lowering the voting age to 18 has been designated as a 'fast-track' item in the National Assembly. I believe this period before the general election is an appropriate time to provide democratic citizenship education through mock election classes.

The education office will continue to consider teaching methods until February next year when teacher workshops for mock election classes are conducted. I will also carefully examine educational materials provided to schools to ensure they are not biased. Through teacher training, I will ensure that mock elections are not used as a means to advocate specific political opinions or private interests, and I will monitor the class process.

-- Progressive education groups are opposing the policy to conduct basic academic skills diagnosis for 3rd grade elementary and 1st grade middle school students starting next year using standardized tools in the form of multiple-choice tests.

▲ The basic academic skills diagnostic tools that the education office will use are so easy that 70% of test-takers score 90 points or higher out of 100, so (students who take the test) cannot determine what level other students' academic abilities are at. While there were differences of opinion with education groups regarding the use of standardized tools, mutual consultation has now been achieved.

-- You were about to announce a 'joint growth plan for original residents (Korean students) and immigrants (Korean-Chinese students)' in partnership with Guro, Geumcheon, and Yeongdeungpo districts, but the plan has stalled due to strong public opposition to the bilingual education reinforcement policy included in the plan. What are your future implementation plans?

▲ I will announce the plan in January next year. I only delayed the announcement because more persuasion process was needed, not because I won't pursue it.

-- The site selection for the special school in Jungnang District (Dongjin School) is making little progress. There are concerns that the opening could be postponed to 2023. Please explain the future schedule.

▲ Final consultation with Jungnang District Office regarding the site is underway. We were scheduled to begin urban planning decision change services and design this year, but the schedule was somewhat delayed when Jungnang District requested a different location from the one originally selected by the education office. I will proceed with urban planning decision change services and design next year to ensure there are no obstacles to opening in 2023.

{
  "translated_title": "Prosecutors Seek Prison Terms for Two Money Intermediaries in 'Woongdong Academy Hiring Corruption' Case",
  "translated_text": "[Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Hyeong-bin = Prosecutors have sought prison sentences for two accomplices accused of delivering bribes to Mr. Cho (52), the younger brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, in exchange for teacher hiring at Woongdong Academy, a school foundation operated by former Minister Cho's family, in connection with hiring corruption allegations.

At the sentencing hearing for Mr. Park (52) and Mr. Cho (45) on charges including breach of trust and bribery held on the 6th before Judge Hong Jun-seo of the 4th Criminal Division of Seoul Central District Court, prosecutors stated, "We request a sentence of 2 years imprisonment and forfeiture of 38 million won [approximately $29,000 USD] for Park, and 1 year and 6 months imprisonment and forfeiture of 25 million won [approximately $19,000 USD] for Cho."

Prosecutors argued, "This case involves foundation operators and job brokers conspiring during the private school teacher hiring process to receive large sums of money using regular teacher positions as bait," adding, "The teaching profession, which should be an object of trust and respect, has been reduced to a commodity for sale, seriously undermining the constitutional value of establishing fair competitive order."

Mr. Cho and Mr. Park were brought to trial for involvement in the Woongdong Academy hiring corruption.

They were indicted under detention in October on charges of receiving bribes from parents of teacher hiring applicants, taking portions as commissions, and then delivering the remainder to former Minister Cho's younger brother, who served as administrative director of Woongdong Academy.

They are also accused of providing teacher hiring exam questions and answers received from former Minister Cho's brother to applicant parents in exchange for money.

At the trial held on the 27th of last month, the defense attorneys for Mr. Cho and Mr. Park acknowledged all of the prosecution's charges while arguing that "they acted on instructions from former Minister Cho's younger brother." Former Minister Cho's brother also acknowledged in court that he had received some money during the Woongdong Academy teacher hiring process.

In his final statement, Mr. Park pleaded for leniency, saying, "Faced with economic difficulties, I failed to judge rationally and acted in a way that lost morality, and I am sincerely repenting through my incarcerated life."

Mr. Cho's defense attorney also asked the court for leniency, stating, "Please consider that while he initially denied the charges during early prosecution investigation, he later confessed to all aspects and cooperated with the investigation."

The court decided to sentence them on the morning of January 10th next year.

This trial is the first to conclude among the cases where related individuals were indicted over corruption allegations involving former Minister Cho's family.

{
  "translated_title": "260,000 Jobs Added Last Year... Mid-sized Company Jobs Increased More Than Double That of Large Companies",
  "translated_text": "(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Yul = Last year, jobs increased by 260,000 compared to the previous year, according to statistics.

Small and medium-sized enterprise jobs grew at twice the scale of large company jobs. Jobs at companies with fewer than 5 employees plummeted by 240,000.

While jobs in wholesale and retail trade, real estate, healthcare and social welfare services, and accommodation and food services increased, jobs in manufacturing and construction decreased.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lim Hwa-young = On the afternoon of the 18th, a job seeker examines employment notices at the '2019 Job Success Il-gu Day Job Fair' held at the Seoul Seocho District Office auditorium. 'Il-gu Day,' meaning 'Job Finding Day,' is a job fair jointly hosted by four autonomous districts—Seocho-gu, Gangnam-gu [an affluent district in Seoul], Songpa-gu, and Gangdong-gu—with HR representatives from 15 excellent companies participating to conduct one-on-one on-site interviews and plan to hire 158 people. 2019.11.18 hwayoung7@yna.co.kr

According to the '2018 Job Administrative Statistics Results' announced by Statistics Korea on the 5th, last year there were 23.42 million jobs, an increase of 260,000 from the previous year.

Looking at job changes by company size, large company jobs increased by only 70,000, while small and medium-sized enterprise jobs increased by 160,000. The scale of increased jobs at small and medium-sized enterprises was more than double that of large companies.

For large companies, newly created jobs reached 240,000, but eliminated jobs also reached 170,000. Small and medium-sized enterprises provided 2.46 million new jobs, accounting for 82.8% of all new jobs (2.97 million). Non-profit organization jobs increased by only 30,000.

Of all jobs (23.42 million), large companies accounted for only 15.7%. Small and medium-sized enterprises accounted for 63.9%, and non-profit organizations 20.3%.

Compared to 2017, the proportion of large companies increased by 0.4 percentage points, while small and medium-sized enterprises decreased by 0.4 percentage points. Non-profit organizations fell by 0.1 percentage points.

By employee scale, jobs increased by 140,000 at companies with 300 or more employees, by 100,000 at companies with 50-299 employees, and by 20,000 at companies with fewer than 50 employees.

Jobs at companies with 1-4 employees plummeted by 240,000 as eliminated jobs (1.46 million) exceeded new jobs (1.22 million).

Park Jin-woo, Director of Administrative Statistics at Statistics Korea, said, "We cannot say there was no impact from minimum wage increases on the job decrease at companies with fewer than 5 employees," adding, "To see accurately, we need to look at more detailed data, but it's difficult to make definitive statements based on administrative data alone."

Companies with fewer than 50 employees provided 52.6% of all jobs, companies with 300 or more employees provided 31.7%, and companies with 50-299 employees provided 15.7% each.

Last year, individual business establishments created 1.38 million new jobs and eliminated 1.32 million jobs, resulting in an overall increase of 60,000 jobs.

Among these, individual business establishments with 1-4 employees saw jobs decrease by 50,000. This was due to more business contractions (550,000) than business expansions (500,000). Individual business establishments with 5-9 employees and those with 10 or more employees increased by 60,000 and 50,000 respectively.

Individual business establishments with 1-4 employees provided 71.2% of all 7.35 million individual business establishment jobs, while those with 5-9 employees provided 13.9%, and those with 10 or more employees provided 14.9% of jobs respectively.

Individual business establishments refer to businesses without corporate status operated by one person or jointly by multiple people, and generally encompass what is commonly called self-employment.

By industry, jobs increased in wholesale and retail trade (70,000), real estate (70,000), healthcare and social welfare services (40,000), and accommodation and food services (40,000), while manufacturing and construction decreased by 60,000 and 30,000 respectively.

By industry job scale, manufacturing was the largest at 20%, followed by wholesale and retail trade (12.8%), construction (8.9%), and healthcare and social welfare services (8.3%).

Jobs counted in job administrative statistics refer to employment positions occupied by workers, which are distinct from employed persons.

For example, if Mr. Kim works at a company during the day and as a hagwon instructor at night, there is one employed person but multiple jobs may be counted.

The standard for determining the number of jobs is one year, and a job that employs someone for only 3 months out of the year is considered as 0.25 jobs.

{
  "translated_title": "'From Last in Class to Perfect CSAT Score' Song Yeong-jun of Gimhae Foreign Language High School",
  "translated_text": "[Photo by Park Jeong-heon]

(Gimhae=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Jeong-heon = "After entering high school, it was hard to shake the feeling that I was falling behind academically to kids who had received hagwon education. I wanted to prove to myself that good grades were possible without hagwon education. I hope many people will recognize that effort can triumph."

Song Yeong-jun (18), a student at Gimhae Foreign Language High School who received a perfect score on the 2020 CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam), expressed his thoughts on achieving a perfect score on the 4th, stating that he firmly believed it would be a 'right world' where focusing solely on school studies without hagwon education could still yield good results.

Song had been a 'model student' who maintained top 10 rankings in his class through middle school.

Living with his single mother who worked hard at a restaurant, his family's modest circumstances meant he achieved these results through personal effort alone, without even once attending the common hagwons or receiving private tutoring.

Song, who entered Gimhae Foreign Language High School through a special admission program for socially disadvantaged students, felt great frustration during the class placement exam.

Ranked 126th out of 127 total students. Thinking 'studying is not my path,' he even applied for counseling with his homeroom teacher just one week after admission, saying "I want to transfer to a technical high school."

Given his family's difficult financial situation, he wanted to find employment quickly to lessen his mother's burden even a little.

His homeroom teacher steadied Song's wavering resolve, saying "If your family situation is difficult, I'll look into scholarships for you. Don't give up and let's try once more."

"When my teacher believed in me to the extent of looking into scholarships, I wanted to repay that trust, which made me focus even more on my studies. The summer vacation of my first year was the turning point. After solving seven math workbooks—my personally most difficult subject—I gained confidence, and as I invested more time in other subjects, my grades improved."

[Photo by Park Jeong-heon]

Song had never received hagwon education except for learning English and math at a neighborhood study room during his 4th-6th grade elementary years.

Starting from the winter break of his second year, taking online lectures to fill in his gaps was all he did.

Instead, he built his skills by studying until midnight every night, and after becoming a senior, until 1 AM.

As he began receiving perfect scores in turn across different subjects in both school records and practice exams, his confidence grew.

"On the day of CSAT, while taking math, English, and other subjects, I thought I had gotten perfect scores. However, Korean language has ambiguous aspects due to the nature of the subject, so I couldn't be certain of a perfect score, but when the preliminary scoring results showed perfect scores in all subjects, I bragged about it to everyone in the neighborhood. Before CSAT, I went around asking people questions like 'What gift will you give me if I get a perfect score?' as a kind of self-hypnosis. By talking about it everywhere, it became solid motivation even if just due to the pressure."

Song plans to do 'motivational' part-time work for middle school students while waiting for the results of early admission to Seoul National University's Liberal Studies program.

He judged it would be meaningful to both save up tuition money before college and encourage students through his own experiences.

Kang Mu-seok, principal of Gimhae Foreign Language High School, emphasized, "High-achieving students are often self-centered, but Song has such good character that there's no one who dislikes him. Rather than the result of achieving a perfect CSAT score, I value more highly the process of him overcoming his trials, and I hope he grows into an inclusive global leader in the future."

Having overcome a major hurdle in life, Song's dream is to become a righteous prosecutor who corrects injustices in our society, or to live as a doctor and lessen his mother's economic burden.

Song said, "I thought about hiding my difficult family circumstances, but I came to speak about it because I think it should be a good world where you can speak proudly about such things," adding "In college, I want to have fun with friends and enjoy the leisurely time I haven't been able to have until now."

{
  "translated_title": "Cho Kuk's Brother Admits "Received 100 Million Won" - Partially Acknowledges Hiring Corruption, Denies Other Charges",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Hyeong-bin = The brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, Mr. Cho (52), who was indicted on charges including 'Ungdong Academy hiring corruption,' mostly denied the charges at his first trial. However, he partially admitted to receiving money from applicants during the Ungdong Academy teacher hiring process.
[Yonhap News file photo]

The Seoul Central District Court Criminal Agreement Division 21 (Presiding Judge Kim Mi-ri) held the first pretrial hearing on the morning of the 3rd for Mr. Cho, who was indicted on charges including breach of trust under the Act on the Aggravated Punishment of Specific Economic Crimes. Since defendants are not required to attend pretrial hearings, Mr. Cho did not appear in court.
Mr. Cho, who served as administrative director at Ungdong Academy operated by former Minister Cho's family, is accused of securing construction payment claims based on fraudulent construction work and filing fake lawsuits against Ungdong Academy in 2006 and 2017, causing damages of 11.55 billion won [approximately $8.7 million USD] to the school foundation.
Prosecutors believe that Mr. Cho filed these multiple 'self-lawsuits' to transfer 11.5 billion won [approximately $8.7 million USD] in debt to Ungdong Academy, then evaded forced execution by the Korea Asset Management Corporation, which had acquired the claims, and also applied charges of evading forced execution.
Mr. Cho is also accused of receiving a total of 180 million won [approximately $135,000 USD] from two applicants while hiring social studies teachers for Ungdong Middle School under the school foundation in 2016-2017, then providing them with exam questions and answer sheets, and attempting to destroy evidence when the prosecution investigation began.
Mr. Cho's side denied most of the charges on this day.
Mr. Cho's attorney argued, "The starting point of this case is that the defendant forged and altered documents with false claims," and "Since the defendant had no knowledge whatsoever that the claims were false, the two lawsuits and the charge of evading forced execution connected to this do not constitute crimes."
He added, "It cannot even be determined for certain whether these claims are actually false."
Mr. Cho's side acknowledged receiving money during the Ungdong Academy teacher hiring process, but showed differences with the prosecution regarding the amount.
Mr. Cho's attorney claimed, "He received 50 million won [approximately $38,000 USD] from each of the two applicants, totaling 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD]," asserting that the prosecution's claim that Mr. Cho received 147 million won [approximately $110,000 USD] is not factual.
He explained that while Mr. Cho leaked the first written exam by bringing it from his mother Park Jeong-suk's house, who is the chairwoman of Ungdong Academy's board, he was not involved in the selection process thereafter.
Mr. Cho's side also completely denied the charges of providing escape funds to co-defendants Mr. Park (52) and Mr. Cho (45) who were indicted as accomplices in the hiring corruption process and encouraging them to hide, as well as the charge of attempting to destroy evidence before the prosecution investigation.
The court decided to hold the second pretrial hearing at 11 AM on the 7th of next month.

{
  "translated_title": "Ulsan Education Office: "Expansion of Regular Admissions Goes Against Public Education Normalization"",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Ulsan Metropolitan Office of Education. Resale and DB prohibited]

(Ulsan=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Yong-tae = The Ulsan Metropolitan Office of Education announced on the 29th that it has concerns about the expansion of regular admissions recruitment outlined in the Ministry of Education's announced 'University Admissions Fairness Enhancement Plan.'

The Ministry of Education announced that it would raise CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam)-focused regular admissions to over 40% by the 2023 academic year for 16 Seoul-based universities where student record comprehensive screening and essay-writing exam-focused screening account for over 45% of total recruitment.

The city education office issued a press release that day stating, "The expansion of CSAT-focused regular admissions has a high possibility of making the public education normalization and classroom instruction improvement efforts we have pursued thus far come to nothing."

It continued, "If the Ministry of Education's plan is introduced, school education will return to problem-solving-focused instruction like entrance exam hagwons [private academies], and schools will once again become entrance exam battlegrounds," expressing concern that "this is a regressive measure that goes against the '2015 Revised Curriculum,' which aims to cultivate creative and convergent talent required by future society and realize happy learning."

It also pointed out, "Dependence on hagwon education will increase, leading to greater economic burden on parents" and "this could bring about educational uniformity that evaluates everything based solely on grades."

On the other hand, it expressed welcome regarding the introduction of social integration screening to expand higher education opportunities for socially disadvantaged groups and promote balanced regional development.

The city education office analyzed that "this will provide substantial help for Ulsan students advancing to universities in the capital region."

The city education office stated, "We will minimize student and parent anxiety through the Ulsan College Admission Information Center by providing college admission information materials and one-on-one face-to-face counseling."

{
  "translated_title": "Teachers Call Regular Admission Expansion 'Regressive Policy,' Parents Say 'Should Expand More' (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Jung Ha-jong = Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye announces measures to strengthen fairness in the college admission system at the briefing room of the Government Complex Seoul on the 28th. 2019.11.28 chc@yna.co.kr

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = When the government announced on the 28th a college admission system reform plan including the expansion of regular admissions [admissions based solely on CSAT scores] at major Seoul universities and reduction of extracurricular areas in school records, teacher organizations poured out criticism and concerns.

Parent groups that had advocated for a massive expansion of regular admissions also showed critical reactions, calling it a 'show-off reform,' and concerns emerged from the college entrance exam market that it would only increase the burden on test-takers.

The Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations (KFTA) issued a statement that day criticizing it as "a college admission reform that will diminish the significance of the student record comprehensive evaluation system [holistic admissions based on school records, essays, and interviews] and discourage students' diverse educational activities" and "shook the college admission system according to the regime's taste while ignoring the issues with former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's children."

While KFTA said "we sympathize with the expansion of regular admissions in terms of balance between admission types," they pointed out that "there is a problem with hastily crafting policy under pressure from political circles after not accepting the 45% regular admission ratio that was prominently presented during last year's public debate process."

The Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union (KTU, a left-leaning teachers' organization) also expressed "deep regret at the decision to expand regular admissions while ignoring the voices of the education sector" through a commentary, denouncing that "although limited to 16 universities, most major universities are included, so the actual ripple effect will be absolute. It should be withdrawn."

KTU called it "a regressive decision that renders worthless the precious efforts to create a school culture of discussion and cooperation" and criticized that "the mandatory 10% social integration admission type is also insufficient for the purpose of restoring the educational class ladder."

Both KFTA and KTU criticized the non-reflection of extracurricular areas of school records in college admissions with one voice, saying it would "discourage students' self-directed learning" and was "conduct that forgot the educational value and essence of extracurricular activities."

The National Association for College Entrance Guidance and National Association of Career and College Counseling Teachers also issued a joint statement that day, criticizing that "many current students and parents expected fairness in early admissions [comprehensive admission system], but the government misread public sentiment" and "this announcement is a clear misjudgment that returns all elementary, middle, and high schools nationwide to a dismal CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] ranking system."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Young-eun = Starting from the 2022 academic year when current high school freshmen take college entrance exams, major top-tier universities in Seoul will select more than 40% of new students through regular admissions. Also, universities will be required to disclose evaluation criteria for the student record comprehensive evaluation system that has caused unfairness controversies, thereby improving admission transparency. Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye announced the 'Measures to Strengthen College Admission System Fairness' containing these contents at the Government Complex Seoul on the 28th. 0eun@yna.co.kr

Parent and civic groups that have consistently advocated for 'regular admission expansion' showed dissatisfaction with the Education Ministry's plan to "recommend more than 40% regular admissions only to 16 universities in Seoul."

The Parent Group for Promoting Regular Admission Expansion held a press conference in front of the Government Complex Seoul that afternoon, claiming "it's only regular admission expansion in appearance and words, a torture of hope that fails to empathize with the pain of parents and students" and "if you acknowledge the evils of the student record comprehensive system, abolish it and pass the 'more than 50% regular admission' bill proposed by the Liberty Korea Party."

The National Assembly for a Fair Society also held a press conference, urging that "regular admissions should have been expanded to 50% this time and increased to more than 80% in the medium to long term" and "CSAT minimum standards should also be strengthened, and measures should be prepared so that no departments fail to select through regular admissions."

The National Parents Association for Realizing Equal Education urged that "responding only to student record comprehensive system issues that arose from the Cho Kuk incident without comprehensive diagnosis, they didn't even touch the mitigation of murderous entrance exam competition and abandoned school education" and "stop populist policies and hurry fundamental reform."

The civic education group No Worries About Private Education welcomed some aspects, saying "abolishing extracurriculars, introducing a public admission officer system, and abolishing essay-writing exams and special talent admissions will guarantee college admission fairness."

However, No Worries About Private Education expressed concern that "early admission CSAT minimum standards were not abolished, raising concerns about problem-solving classroom disruption, and there are no measures regarding oral exams that test subject knowledge, so test-taker burden remains."

Admission consulting companies analyzed that under the Education Ministry's plan, the regular admission ratio would effectively increase to more than 45%, extracurricular school records would be abolished, and the importance of both CSAT and school GPA [high school transcript grades] would grow together.

Jongno Academy Sky Education predicted that "considering that the average number of early admission transfer students at the 16 universities is 3-4%, the scale of regular admission selection will effectively be at the 45% level starting from the 2022 academic year entrance exams that current high school freshmen will take" and "in early admissions, the importance of GPA and in-depth oral interviews will increase, so test-taker burden will grow even more."

Daesung Academy's Daesung Academic Development Research Institute predicted that "specialized high schools, autonomous private high schools, and general high schools in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] will be somewhat disadvantaged in early admissions but will show stronger performance in regular admissions."

  "translated_title": ""Part-time jobs don't give weekly holiday pay"...30% of youth labor consultations are wage issues",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Jang Woo-ri = The biggest problem young people face in the workplace was found to be wage-related matters such as weekly holiday pay and severance pay.

Union Center, a consultation and education center affiliated with Youth Union, released 343 cases of youth labor consultations from January to October this year, revealing that 31.8% of consultations were about 'unpaid wages,' making it the most frequent issue.

'Employment contracts and employment types' accounted for 17.5%, followed by remedy procedures (13.6%), working hours and rest (9%), and resignation (8.1%).

According to the data, among unpaid wage problems (multiple counts), young people frequently requested consultations from the center to recover unpaid weekly holiday pay (61 cases) and severance pay (59 cases).

The center added that there were cases where people consulted about whether there was a way to receive weekly holiday pay after quitting, having agreed to the boss's statement that weekly holiday pay wouldn't be provided when starting part-time work, and cases inquiring about severance pay settlement standards and allowance calculation methods.

In employment contract and employment type consultations, discussions were held about failure to create employment contracts and the possibility of recognizing worker status for study room managers, hagwon instructors, and others.

Han Ji-hye, center director, said, "When Youth Union was first established, many young people came to us just to vent their frustrations, but recently, more people are coming who understand what the issues are and are asking for specific countermeasures."

She emphasized, "There are many cases where people quit because they couldn't endure various unfair treatment from companies, but the possibility of remedy is higher if accurate information is identified in advance and evidence is preserved," adding "Labor rights education that can provide practical help to young people should also be expanded."

Youth Union is an organization that works for youth employment stability and labor rights protection, established in 2010."

However, NWPE expressed concern that "early admission CSAT minimum standards were not abolished, raising concerns about disrupted problem-solving classes, and there are no measures regarding oral exams that test subject knowledge, so test-taker burdens remain."
College entrance exam companies analyzed that under the Education Ministry's plan, the regular admissions ratio would effectively increase to more than 45%, non-curricular school records would be abolished, and the importance of both CSAT and school GPA would grow together.
Jongro Academy Sky Education said, "Considering that the 16 universities' early admission carryover numbers average 3-4%, the regular admission selection scale will effectively be around 45% starting from the 2022 academic year entrance exams taken by current high school freshmen" and predicted, "Since the importance of GPA and in-depth oral interviews will increase in early admissions, test-taker burdens will grow even more."
Daesung Academy's Daesung Academic Development Research Institute predicted, "Special purpose high schools, autonomous private high schools, and general high schools in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] will be somewhat disadvantaged in early admissions but will show stronger performance in regular admissions."

  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = While the Ministry of Education announced on the 28th measures to expand regular admissions quotas at major Seoul universities along with strengthening fairness in student record comprehensive screening (holistic admissions), critics argue that there are no substantial measures to dispel field concerns about so-called 'lottery-like school records.'

The core of this announcement involves gradually reducing the reflection of non-curricular areas of school life records in university admissions, completely abolishing them by the 2024 academic year, and strengthening universities' disclosure of holistic admissions evaluation criteria and selection results.

However, among parents and students who have advocated for 'regular admissions expansion,' criticism emerges that "the fundamental reason we can't trust holistic admissions is that the level of school record writing differs by teacher, yet no effective measures for this are visible." This is why the modifier 'lottery-like' is often attached to school records.

The Ministry of Education announced it would develop teacher training modules to strengthen teachers' evaluation and recording capabilities to resolve disparities in school record entries, expand such training, and operate continuous liaison and exchange programs between high school teachers and university admissions officers.

For 'detailed abilities and special remarks' (detailed remarks) written by subject teachers, they explained they would make entries mandatory in stages and create and distribute standard guidelines next year.

However, Ms. Cho (47), who has a high school sophomore son, scoffed, saying "Excellent teachers who write school records meticulously differ from the start in their interest and passion toward students," and "Could my child's homeroom teacher, who is perfunctory and rigid, learn such passion through formal group education like training?"

Another parent, Ms. Park (45), also raised her voice, saying "Not only homeroom teachers but also the detailed remarks written by each subject teacher are important, yet even within one school, teachers' levels differ," and "The Ministry of Education tells us to 'trust schools and teachers,' but what can we do about the anxiety that we're ruined if we get the wrong teacher, when there's no mechanism to wash away such fears?"

[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

Regarding the complete abolition of non-curricular activities outside the regular curriculum from university admissions and the elimination of holistic admissions personal statements starting from the 2024 academic year when current 8th graders take university entrance exams, universities express dissatisfaction.

They argue that if universities want to see what career paths and aptitudes students have designed and worked toward, they need to look at personal statements as well as non-curricular activities, but removing all of these due to unfairness suspicions makes the purpose of operating holistic admissions meaningless.

One admissions expert worried, "Wasn't it proven through holistic admissions fact-finding that universities don't hesitate to use illegal and irregular methods to secure excellent students first?" adding "If universities create variant screening methods or greatly strengthen interviews, it's students who will suffer."

A high school teacher in Seoul said, "If holistic admissions decrease and subject-based admissions increase, students will be driven into infinite school record [GPA] competition and dependence on 'pinpoint hagwons [hagwons known for accurately predicting exam questions] near high schools' will increase, making high school classes desolate."

There are also criticisms that while university admissions policies keep changing course with questionable effectiveness, leaving students, parents, and teachers in continued confusion, the only side smiling is the hagwon education market.

Following the Ministry of Education's mention that essay and written response questions could be introduced from the 2028 CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], there are already talks that essay hagwon education for elementary students will increase, or that if universities disclose detailed evaluation criteria to enhance holistic admissions transparency, customized admissions consulting for top-tier universities will become more sophisticated.

On the 27th, Seoul Central District Court Criminal Division 4 Judge Hong Jun-seo conducted the second trial preparation session for Mr. Cho (45) and Mr. Park (52), who are involved in the Ungdong School Foundation hiring corruption case.

Mr. Cho and Mr. Park were indicted under detention last month on charges of receiving bribes from parents of Ungdong School teacher hiring applicants, taking a portion as commission fees, and then delivering the remainder to former Minister Cho's younger brother, who serves as Ungdong School's administrative director.

They are also charged with providing teacher hiring exam questions and answers received from former Minister Cho's younger brother to applicant parents in exchange for money.

At today's trial, the defense attorneys for both Mr. Cho and Mr. Park admitted to all of the prosecution's charges.

Mr. Park's defense attorney stated, "We admit to all charges, but [our client] acted according to the instructions of former Minister Cho's younger brother."

Since the prosecution and defendants have no additional evidence to present and have admitted to all crimes, the court decided to hold the first oral argument session on the morning of December 6th, proceed to deliberation, and then set a sentencing date.
