{
  "translated_title": "Seoul 'Hagwon Sunday Closure' Support at 63%... Cho Hee-yeon "Will Review Policy Implementation" (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "A view of the hagwon district in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], Gangnam-gu [an affluent district in Seoul], Seoul. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = Results from the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education's citizen deliberation on introducing a mandatory Sunday closure system for hagwons showed 62.6% in favor of Sunday closures and 32.7% opposed.

Accordingly, the introduction of a system mandating that hagwons in the Seoul region must close on Sundays is expected to be pursued in earnest.

The Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education's Hagwon Sunday Closure Public Deliberation Committee announced on the 26th the results of deliberations by 171 citizen participants on the introduction of the hagwon Sunday closure system.

The citizen panel consisted of 66 elementary, middle, and high school students including elementary students, 54 parents, 24 school teachers, and 27 general citizens. Deliberations were conducted for two weeks from the 26th of last month to the 9th of this month.

Looking at the deliberation results, ultimately 62.6% (107 people) of participants supported introducing the hagwon Sunday closure system. Opposition was 32.7% (56 people) and those who withheld their opinion were 4.7% (8 people). Support was about double that of opposition.

The public deliberation committee evaluated this result as "support being overwhelmingly greater than opposition." The committee explained that the basis for using the term "overwhelming" was "because the gap between support and opposition was outside the margin of error."

In a public opinion survey by the public deliberation committee before deliberations began, the support-opposition-withholding ratios among participants were 59.6%-25.1%-15.2% respectively. In the survey after the first deliberation, support-opposition-withholding were 53.8%-35.1%-11.1% respectively, with support and withholding decreasing while opposition increased. However, after the second deliberation, opposition and withholding decreased while support increased to the 60% range.

Based on final results, support rates were highest in the order of school teachers (75.0%)-parents (63.0%)-general citizens (59.3%)-students (59.1%). Opposition rates were in the order of parents (35.2%)-students (34.8%)-general citizens (33.3%)-school teachers (20.8%).

Among those supporting the introduction of hagwon Sunday closures, 60.7% cited "to institutionally guarantee students' health and rest rights" as the most common reason.

This was followed by "creating an environment where families can spend weekends together" (19.6%), "to reduce high dependence on hagwon education" (15.9%), "to reduce the harmful effects of commuting to distant hagwons outside one's residential area" (0.9%), and other reasons (2.8%) in that order.

On the opposition side, "violation of students' autonomous learning rights" (55.4%) was cited most frequently as a reason. This was followed by "because illegal and variant forms of private tutoring and tutoring centers will emerge, increasing hagwon education [private supplementary education] costs" (28.6%), "increased weekday study time burden" (7.1%), other reasons (5.4%), and "violation of business freedom for hagwons and other hagwon education workers" (3.6%).

When asked about the scope of application for the hagwon Sunday closure system, the most participants answered "all elementary, middle, and high school students" (39.8%) by school level, and "only general subjects excluding arts and physical education" (58.5%) by subject area.

As for implementation methods, 43.9% of participants said "the National Assembly should create legislation."

33.9% of participants believed it could be implemented through ordinance enactment that the education office could pursue at its level, while 18.7% said "the system should not be implemented regardless of whether legislation is created."

85.0% of participants stated they would "respect the final public deliberation results even if they differ from their own opinions."

Based on the deliberation results, the public deliberation committee recommended that the education office implement the hagwon Sunday closure system.

Seoul Metropolitan Superintendent of Education Cho Hee-yeon. [Yonhap News file photo]

Seoul Metropolitan Superintendent of Education Cho Hee-yeon stated, "I will humbly accept the opinions that emerged from the public deliberation," and "I will review the public deliberation results together with related policy research results coming out in the first half of next year so they can be reflected in education policy." The hagwon Sunday closure system is a core campaign promise that Superintendent Cho put forward in both local elections.

However, education circles predict it will take considerable time until the education office decides to introduce the system. This is because opposition opinions are also substantial, and there are no adequate measures to ensure effectiveness after system introduction due to problems such as insufficient enforcement personnel.

Particularly, according to current hagwon law, there is already an authoritative interpretation from the Ministry of Government Legislation stating that hagwon closure days cannot be set by ordinance, so the prevailing view is that hagwon Sunday closure introduction is only possible through legislation, but whether the National Assembly will act remains uncertain.

There are no statistics on how many students attend hagwons on Sundays.

However, when the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education surveyed 4,213 middle and high school students in 2014, 34.9% (1,470 students) answered that they go to hagwons on Sundays either every week or when necessary.

According to the education office's survey of 1,133 hagwons and tutoring centers this year, 45.5% (516 places) were found to open on Sundays as well. Although this surveyed only 4.9% of all hagwons and tutoring centers, it shows that there are quite a few hagwons operating on Sundays.

This special lecture was organized to help test-takers and parents develop their own regular admissions application strategies, and college entrance exam experts Kim Jin-man and Song Min-ho, admissions columnists for EduIn News, are scheduled to reveal customized application strategy know-how based on understanding the principles of regular admissions.

The main content of the lecture includes the order and methods for finding universities eligible for regular admissions applications, how to extract cumulative percentiles from CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] score reports, how to find target university ranges using standard scores and cumulative percentiles, comparative analysis of characteristics and utilization methods of major entrance exam institutions, real-time application trend analysis through online mock applications and actual college application strategy methods, how to record mock application sample analysis forms, and methods for extracting admission possibilities considering applicant psychology.

Unlike large-scale hagwon [private academy] seminars, this will feature lectures that three-dimensionally analyze correlations between CSAT scores and applicants, running in three sessions from 11 AM to 1 PM.

Applications can be submitted by clicking the special lecture banner on the EduIn News homepage and filling out a Google application form by the 2nd, 9th, and 16th of next month, which are two days before each session begins.

Applicants will receive standard score frequency distribution table analysis results, Excel placement reference tables, mock application sample analysis forms, and the book "Principles of Regular Admissions" authored by columnists Kim Jin-man and Song Min-ho.

Instructor Kim Jin-man said, "I have already predicted test-takers' application tendencies through analysis of the 2020 academic year CSAT difficulty level," adding "I will explain in detail how to establish application strategies suited to individual scores based on analysis of this CSAT, including grade cutoffs and CSAT difficulty levels."

Instructor Song Min-ho said, "We plan to provide not only information offered by specialized hagwon education institutions for college entrance exams but also comparative analysis information so that students can develop their own college application strategies, so I hope you will attend and gain a lot of information." {
  "translated_title": "Prosecutors: "Cho Kuk's Brother Instructed Creation of False 'Fact Confirmation Letter' to Cover Up Allegations"",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Do-hoon = Cho (surname withheld), the younger brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54), enters the Seoul Central District Court in Seocho-gu, Seoul on the morning of the 31st of last month to undergo a substantive warrant review. superdoo82@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Sung Do-hyeon and Park Jae-hyeon = An investigation has revealed that Cho (surname withheld, 52), the younger brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54), had an acquaintance create a fact confirmation letter containing false information when reports emerged about allegations of corruption in teacher hiring at Ungdong Middle School, ahead of Cho Kuk's personnel hearing.

According to the indictment of Cho submitted by prosecutors to the National Assembly's Legislation and Judiciary Committee on the 19th, Cho, who serves as secretary-general of Ungdong Academy, was found to have made efforts to prevent the spread of the allegation reports through his elementary school junior A and A's acquaintance B.

After a media report on August 22nd titled "Cho Kuk's Brother Hired 2 Ungdong Middle School Teachers After Receiving 100 Million Won [approximately $75,000 USD] Each," Cho received contacts from former Minister Cho Kuk, Dongyang University Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57, indicted while detained), and officials from the Justice Minister nominee's personnel hearing preparation team seeking to confirm the facts.

Prosecutors determined that Cho instructed B to "bring a fact confirmation letter written in A's name stating that it [the report] is not true if you want to engage in media play to cover up the case," in order to refute the report's contents and prepare for potential criminal complaints or investigations.

At the time, Cho was investigated to have informed B of the specific content to be included in the fact confirmation letter. B sent a draft of the fact confirmation letter to Cho via text message the next day, and Cho received it and transmitted it to former Minister Cho Kuk, Professor Chung, and a prosecutor affiliated with the hearing preparation team, as stated in the indictment.

However, the personnel hearing preparation team did not issue a separate position statement regarding the media report at the time.
[Yonhap News file photo]

Prosecutors launched search and seizure operations at Ungdong Middle School and the residence of the Ungdong Academy board chairman from around 9 a.m. on the 27th of the same month. Prosecutors included in the indictment that on this day, B, acting on Cho's instructions, had A write a fact confirmation letter with false content and received the fact confirmation letter along with a seal certificate.

The indictment also included charges that Cho helped A and B flee to the Philippines in preparation for a full-scale investigation into corruption in teacher hiring at Ungdong Academy. According to the prosecution's investigation, Cho was found to have given them 3.5 million won [approximately $2,600 USD] as escape funds. Cho and B were identified as accomplices in harboring criminals.

Regarding this, Cho's side stated, "It is true that such a fact confirmation letter was created at the time, but Cho did not instruct its creation first," adding, "Since B first said he would create a fact confirmation letter during the discussion process, we will contest in court whether [Cho] took the lead in creating the document."

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Anti-Corruption Investigation Division 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) indicted Cho with detention the previous day, applying charges of ▲ breach of trust under the Act on the Aggravated Punishment of Specific Economic Crimes ▲ evasion of compulsory execution ▲ breach of trust and bribery ▲ obstruction of business ▲ destruction of evidence and instigation, in addition to the charge of harboring criminals. Former Minister Cho Kuk's name appears seven times in Cho's indictment, but no evidence of conspiracy was revealed.

Cho, who was detained after prosecutors' two warrant requests, admits to only some of the hiring corruption charges while denying all others. During the investigation process, Cho cited health reasons such as herniated discs to refuse attendance requests or requested suspension of questioning even when present.

Cho's side stated, "He originally had depressive symptoms and was receiving medication, but his condition worsened after detention (on the 31st of last month)," adding, "Since his health is poor, we are considering requesting medical bail from the court."

  "translated_text": "[Provided by Seoul Seocho District]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lim Hwa-seop = Following the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) held on the 14th for the 2020 academic year, Seoul's autonomous districts are consecutively holding district-specific university regular admission information sessions. University regular admissions will proceed by individual universities starting December 26th.

Seoul's Seocho District will hold the '2020 Seocho University Regular Admission Strategy Information Session' on the 16th at 10 AM at the Seocho Culture and Arts Center in Yangjae-dong [a neighborhood in Seocho District], with 1,000 test-takers and parents in attendance.

This approximately 2-hour information session will feature experts analyzing preliminary CSAT scores and explaining regular admission strategies by score range, including medical and dental schools and top-tier universities.

Im Seong-ho, CEO of Jongro Hagwon, will explain ▲ 2020 academic year regular admission cutoff predictions ▲ customized top-tier university application strategies for test-takers ▲ application strategies based on preliminary CSAT results (essay-writing exams, interviews, etc.), followed by Jang Moon-seong, director of Jongro Academic Development Institute, who will explain ▲ analysis of regular admission Group A, B, C application trends by score range ▲ medical school, dental school, and Korean medicine school cutoff forecasts and strategies.

Starting at 12:30 PM, admissions consultants from Bangbae Education Support Center and Jongro Hagwon will provide free customized consultations to Seocho District residents who made advance reservations among information session applicants at the district office 2nd floor auditorium.

This information session is open not only to test-takers who took the CSAT but also to 1st and 2nd-year high school students and their parents. Advance reservations can be made through the Seocho District Education Support Center website (www.seochoedu.or.kr). Advance reservation holders can receive the '2020 Academic Year University Admission Information Session Materials' and 'CSAT Preliminary Score Placement Reference Chart' free at the information session venue.

Seocho District has also arranged for specialized admissions consultants to provide 1:1 free consultations to district residents at four area-based education support centers (Bangbae, Seocho, Banpo-Jamwon, Yangjae-Naegok) from the 20th of this month through the 31st of next month. Participation is limited to 400 Seocho District residents and will close on a first-come, first-served basis. Reservation applications can be made on the Seocho District Education Support Center website.

Gangbuk District Office will hold a 2020 academic year regular admission strategy information session on December 12th from 3-5 PM at the district office building 4th floor auditorium.

The session speaker is Woo Yeon-cheol, evaluation team leader of Jinhaksa Admissions Strategy Research Institute and expert committee member of the tbs program 'Get Counseling and Go to University.' There will be a Q&A session after the lecture.

Those wishing to attend can enter without advance reservation, and the first 200 people can receive regular admission strategy materials. For detailed inquiries, contact Gangbuk District Education Support Division (☎02-901-6296).

Dongjakgu District Office will hold '2020 Academic Year Regular Admission Customized 1:1 Admissions Consulting' on December 13th and 14th at the district office auditorium.

Twenty-four current teachers from the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education's University Advancement Guidance Team will provide 1:1 customized admissions strategy consultations. Participation is limited to 144 people, and applications will be accepted on a first-come, first-served basis through the Dongjak District website from November 20-28.

Consultations will be conducted for approximately 40 minutes per person based on CSAT score reports and individually prepared consultation basic materials, covering 2020 university admission prospects, characteristics of school-specific admission processes, and desired university application strategies. Inquiries can be made to Dongjak District Education Policy Division (☎02-820-9094).

{
  "translated_title": "[CSAT] Teachers and Test Prep Companies: "English Easier Than Last Year... Grade 1 Likely to Exceed 6%" (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "[Photo by Lee Jae-young]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Jae-young and Lee Hyo-seok = The English section of the 2020 College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT, Korea's national university entrance exam), administered on the 14th during the third period, was evaluated as easier and more straightforward than last year's CSAT.

School teachers and test prep companies generally analyzed that "English was somewhat easier than last year's CSAT and this year's September mock exam."

Since the 2018 CSAT, the English section has been changed to absolute evaluation. Grades are assigned by score range: 90 points or above is Grade 1, 80-89 points is Grade 2, 70-79 points is Grade 3, and so forth.

Kim Chang-mook, a teacher at Gyeongsin High School and member of the Korean Council for University Education's college admissions counseling teacher group, predicted at a briefing held at the Government Complex Sejong after the English section ended, "I estimate that the proportion of Grade 1 students in the English section will be somewhat higher than last year's CSAT and this year's September mock exam."

The proportion of students who received Grade 1 in the English section was 5.3% on last year's CSAT and 5.9% on this year's September mock exam.

The university council's counseling teacher group projected that more than 6% of students would achieve Grade 1 in this year's CSAT English section.

Teacher Kim evaluated, "There were no new question types and many relatively straightforward passages, so the overall difficulty level likely dropped significantly. However, there were questions requiring high-level inference abilities, showing efforts to secure discriminatory power as an assessment tool."

Test prep companies also observed that the proportion of Grade 1 English students would likely exceed 6%.

Uway Educational Assessment Research Institute evaluated, "Previously difficult question types like blank inference came out relatively easy, so the perceived difficulty wouldn't have been high. It appears similar in difficulty to this year's June mock exam, where 7.8% of students received Grade 1."

Lim Seong-ho, representative of Jongno Hagwon Haneul Education, analyzed, "It was more difficult than the 2018 academic year when 10% of test-takers achieved Grade 1. While the Grade 1 proportion may increase somewhat from last year's 5.3%, it likely won't expand significantly to Grades 2 and 3 since there was discriminatory power."

Yu Seong-ho, a teacher at Sungdeok Girls' High School, said, "Students who studied centered on EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) linked materials would have found the passages easy to approach. Some sentences were difficult, so mid-level students may have felt the difficulty was somewhat high, but since the answer choices weren't harder than last year's CSAT, they likely maintained their usual grades."

The most difficult problems in the English section were identified as Question 34 (odd-numbered version), which required inserting a sentence into a blank, and Question 37, which required arranging paragraph order appropriately.

Chae Hyeon-seo, a teacher at Bongdam High School, said, "Question 37 in particular has long sentences with complex structure plus difficult vocabulary, requiring inference while reading. It likely secured discriminatory power for high-achieving test-takers."

Teacher Chae added, "The Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation usually didn't make EBS links in long reading comprehension where two questions come from one passage, but this year there was linking, so students who faithfully studied the linked materials would have felt a high connection rate."

Test prep companies including Daesung Hagwon and Uway evaluated that Questions 30 and 42, vocabulary problems asking students to choose underlined words whose usage is contextually inappropriate, had discriminatory power.

{
  "translated_title": "[CSAT] "No killer questions but not easy"...Both mid-tier and upper-tier students troubled over application strategies",
  "translated_text": "(Gwangju=Yonhap News) Reporter Jo Nam-soo = Students exit the testing site after finishing the 2020 College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT, Korea's national university entrance exam) at Donga Girls' High School in Nam-gu, Gwangju on the afternoon of the 14th. 2019.11.14 iso64@yna.co.kr

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Hyo-seok and Lee Jae-young = The 2020 College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT, Korea's national university entrance exam) held on the 14th was evaluated as having no ultra-high difficulty questions called 'killer questions' in the Korean and mathematics sections that have become decisive factors since the English section switched to absolute evaluation, but still maintaining discriminative power.

As the boundary between top-tier and upper-tier students, which was previously divided by whether they could solve ultra-high difficulty questions or not, has become blurred, a fierce 'psychological warfare' is expected during regular admission application submissions.

Mid-tier students are expected to often worry after receiving lower scores than expected on this discriminative test.

Kim Chang-muk, a school teacher at Kyungshin High School and member of the Korean Council for University Education's counseling teacher group, explained, "Since the difficulty of Korean, mathematics, and English all decreased compared to last year, so-called upper-tier test-takers would have been able to solve problems relatively easily," adding, "However, for mid-tier test-takers, there were questions in mathematics or English that were difficult to approach."

Nam Yun-gon, director of Megastudy Education's admissions strategy research institute, said, "The score differences among upper-tier test-takers are expected to be small," adding, "Upper-tier test-takers will also need to examine each university's CSAT score reflection methods more carefully than before."

Woo Yeon-cheol, evaluation team leader at Jinhak Corporation's admissions strategy research institute, stated, "Since there were no killer questions this year, upper-tier test-takers will inevitably perform well," adding, "For the upper tier, whether they get one or two questions right or wrong will determine whether they can attend their desired universities."

Lee Man-gi, director of Uway Educational Assessment Research Institute, said, "The importance of mathematics, which came out similar to or slightly more difficult than last year, has relatively increased," adding, "Especially for mid-tier test-takers, along with mathematics, Korean—which was easier than last year but still had discriminative power—will act as a variable."

Director Lee added, "Repeat test-takers [students retaking CSAT after high school graduation] appear to have performed well, so their dominance in regular admissions is expected."

Lim Sung-ho, CEO of Jongno Academy Sky Education, also analyzed, "Although this year's Korean was easier than last year, that's only in comparison to last year—it was definitely not easy, and mid-tier test-takers would have found it particularly difficult," adding, "For humanities track test-takers, both Korean and mathematics will be important, while for science track students, since mathematics difficulty was similar to last year, the importance of Korean will increase."

CEO Lim also predicted repeat test-taker dominance in regular admissions.

Experts advised test-takers to "not give up until the end" whether in early or regular admissions.

Director Lee Man-gi advised, "Among currently enrolled high school students, those with excellent grades likely passed early admissions or focused on early admissions," adding, "The possibility of regular admission acceptance could be unexpectedly high, so students shouldn't hastily give up just because their scores are lower than expected."

CEO Lim Sung-ho said, "The dominance of repeat test-takers in regular admissions is likely to be more pronounced than ever," adding, "Therefore, high school seniors shouldn't give up on applying for early admission programs just based on predictions that they won't meet the minimum CSAT requirements for early admissions, but should actively apply."

  "translated_text": "Cho: "Answers would be tedious...will reveal in court"...Prosecution: "Additional summons investigation necessary" Weighing bribery charges for wife's proxy investment and daughter's scholarship allegations
(Seoul=Yonhap News) The prosecution announced on the 14th that it was investigating former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, who is suspected of being involved in his wife's proxy stock investment and children's college entrance fraud. The photo shows former Minister Cho leaving Seoul Detention Center in Uiwang City on the 24th of last month after visiting his wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim. Former Justice Minister Cho Kuk leaving. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Kye-yeon = The prosecution summoned and investigated former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54) on the 14th, who is suspected of being involved in his wife's proxy stock investment and children's college entrance fraud.
This comes 79 days after launching a forcible investigation with massive searches and seizures on August 27th, and one month since former Minister Cho resigned.
Minister Cho completely refused to answer prosecutors' questions and left the prosecution building after 8 hours. His legal team revealed immediately after the investigation that "he judged it would be tedious and unnecessary to answer and explain each point" and indicated they would not make statements to the prosecution in the future.
With the suspect interrogation procedure completed for former Minister Cho, who is at the center of the allegations, the direction and intensity of judicial processing, including whether to request an arrest warrant against him, is expected to be the final hurdle of this investigation.
The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Anti-Corruption Investigation Division 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyung-gon) questioned former Minister Cho starting at 9:35 AM about the facts surrounding various allegations raised so far.
Former Minister Cho's appearance at the prosecution was not disclosed to the media. He is known to have been investigated as a suspect with his attorney present.
Former Minister Cho exercised his right to remain silent and returned home around 5:35 PM after completing the investigation review. Through his legal team, he stated: "I have repeatedly made clear my position that I firmly deny all charges being discussed in relation to me in my wife's indictment and the media, as they are contrary to the facts" and "Since the investigation has been conducted for a long time, once the investigation team decides whether to prosecute, I intend to clarify the truth by determining right and wrong about everything in court."
This is interpreted as effectively refusing future prosecution investigations. However, the prosecution stated that "additional summons investigation is necessary," suggesting further attendance requests will be made.
Former Minister Cho appears to be involved in a significant portion of the 15 criminal charges against his wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57, detained), who was indicted for the second time on the 11th. The prosecution is expected to intensively question whether he knew that Professor Chung purchased stock in secondary battery company WFM under borrowed names.
WFM is an investee company of Kolink Private Equity (Kolink PE), the private fund management company in which Professor Chung invested 1.05 billion won [approximately $788,000 USD] under her name and her two children's names. The prosecution determined that Professor Chung obtained undisclosed information from Cho Beom-dong (36, arrested and indicted), former Minister Cho's second cousin who was the actual operator of Kolink PE, and purchased 144,304 shares of WFM stock under borrowed names from January to November last year.
The prosecution has secured financial transaction records showing 50 million won [approximately $37,500 USD] was withdrawn from former Minister Cho's account on the same day Professor Chung purchased 120,000 WFM shares over-the-counter at the end of January last year, and has been tracking the flow of this money.
If he knew the transferred money would be used for stock investment, it would violate the Public Officials Ethics Act's direct investment prohibition and could also result in charges of false property reporting. Professor Chung's illicit profits of 280.83 million won [approximately $211,000 USD] from stock investment or 'favorable information provision' could be viewed as bribes given to former Minister Cho by WFM.
[Provided by Busan Medical Center]

Allegations surrounding his daughter's (28) scholarship at Pusan National University Medical School are also a key investigation target that could lead to bribery charges.
Former Minister Cho's daughter received scholarships of 2 million won [approximately $1,500 USD] per semester for 6 semesters from 2016, totaling 12 million won [approximately $9,000 USD]. Noh Hwan-jung, current director of Busan Medical Center who provided the scholarship as her supervising professor, is known to have personally written a document stating that he played 'a role' in the process of selecting President Moon Jae-in's personal physician.
The prosecution recently summoned Director Noh on the 11th and 13th consecutively to investigate the circumstances of scholarship provision, considering the possibility that former Minister Cho's influence, who was then Senior Presidential Secretary for Civil Affairs, affected the process of his appointment as Busan Medical Center director last June.
The prosecution is also verifying whether former Minister Cho was involved in the process of his daughter and son (23) fraudulently obtaining internship certificates from Seoul National University Law School's Public Interest Human Rights Law Center.
The daughter in 2009 and son in 2013 each received certificates stating they had interned at Seoul National University's Public Interest Human Rights Law Center and submitted them for college applications. The prosecution secured internship certificate files from former Minister Cho's home PC and has been investigating former Minister Cho's involvement as he was a law school professor at the time.
Professor Chung's indictment includes charges of submitting her daughter's false internship certificate for college applications (uttering of falsely prepared official document). The prosecution wrote in the indictment that she "gave her daughter an internship confirmation letter containing false information" but did not reveal the certificate issuance process.
Whether he was involved in or aided evidence destruction is also under investigation.
The prosecution secured testimony from Kim Kyung-rok (37), a Korea Investment & Securities private banker who managed the couple's assets, that when replacing the hard disk of the PC at their Bangbae-dong home in Seoul, former Minister Cho told him "thank you for helping my wife."
Since Professor Chung led the response to private fund-related allegations during the confirmation hearing process, whether former Minister Cho himself knew that his explanations were false is expected to be a key issue.
(Seoul=Yonhap News) The prosecution announced on the 14th that it was investigating former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, who is suspected of being involved in his wife's proxy stock investment and children's college entrance fraud. The photo shows former Justice Minister Cho Kuk leaving the Ministry of Justice at the Government Complex Gwacheon on the 14th after announcing his resignation. [Yonhap News file photo] photo@yna.co.kr

Former Minister Cho received and used management status reports prepared by Kolink Private Equity (Kolink PE), a private fund management company, to explain the allegations. The prosecution indicted Professor Chung on charges of instructing evidence fabrication, believing she instructed the false preparation of this report.
The prosecution also considers investigation necessary regarding charges of hiring irregularities and sham litigation at Ungdong Academy involving his younger brother Cho (52, detained).
Ungdong Academy is a school foundation in Gyeongnam Province operated by former Minister Cho's family, with his late father Cho Byeon-hyeon followed by his current mother Park Jung-sook (81) serving as chairwoman. Former Minister Cho served as a board member of Ungdong Academy from 1999-2009. The prosecution secured legal review documents regarding Korea Asset Management Corporation's (KAMCO) provisional seizure of Ungdong Academy from former Minister Cho's PC and has been verifying his involvement in sham litigation.
Former Minister Cho acknowledges some involvement in the hiring process, including receiving requests from Ungdong Academy to prepare teacher employment exam questions and re-delegating them to professors in relevant fields. However, his position is that he does not precisely remember when he was requested to prepare questions and that it is unrelated to hiring irregularities.
The prosecution reportedly could not complete all prepared questioning despite former Minister Cho's refusal to testify. Accordingly, they plan to summon former Minister Cho again soon to complete the interrogation. The prosecution is expected to carefully decide future investigation procedures, including requesting an arrest warrant, by comprehensively considering former Minister Cho's testimony attitude and other factors.

{
  "translated_title": "[CSAT] This Year 'Easy' for Top Students, 'Hard' for Middle-Tier Students… "Overall Moderate" (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Daegu=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Hyeon-tae = On the morning of November 14, the 2020 academic year College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT) day, test-takers wait for the exam to begin at Namsan High School in Suseong-dong, Suseong-gu, Daegu, which serves as a CSAT test site. 2019.11.14 mtkht@yna.co.kr

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporters Park Seong-jin, Lee Jae-young, Lee Hyo-seok = The 2020 academic year College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT, Korea's national university entrance exam) administered on November 14 was analyzed as being overall easier or more moderate than last year, which was called the 'hellish CSAT.'

While high-difficulty problems became somewhat easier, making it feel moderate for top-tier students, there appeared to be quite a few difficult problems for middle-tier students in the mathematics and English sections.

Kim Chang-muk, a school teacher at Gyeongsin High School and member of the Korean Council for University Education's counseling teacher group, said at a trend briefing held at the Sejong Government Complex that day, "The difficulty levels of Korean, mathematics, and English all decreased compared to last year, so so-called top-tier test-takers would have been able to solve problems relatively easily."

Teacher Kim added, "However, for middle-tier test-takers, there were questions in mathematics or English that were difficult to approach."

The first period Korean language section, which was criticized as the 'culprit of the hellish CSAT' last year due to ultra-high difficulty problems, was predominantly evaluated as easier than last year.

Kim Yong-jin, a school teacher at Dongguk University Teachers College Affiliated Girls' High School, said, "The Korean language section exam was easier than last year's CSAT" and "It can be evaluated as easier than even this year's September mock evaluation."

Education officials unanimously agreed that there were no ultra-high difficulty questions like last year's controversial Korean language question 31 related to universal gravitation.

Shim Bong-seop, a professor of French education at Seoul National University and the 2020 academic year CSAT chief examiner, stated definitively, "The examination committee's decision not to include such questions this year became the hottest issue. (This year's CSAT) naturally has no such ultra-high difficulty questions."

College entrance exam preparation companies also evaluated this year's Korean language section as easier than last year, but analyzed that the reading comprehension part was somewhat tricky, so it did not lose its ability to differentiate students.

High-difficulty Korean language problems identified included question 19 based on odd-numbered form humanities text on Bayesian epistemology, question 22 based on the classical gasa [traditional Korean poetic form] 'Wolseonheon Sixteen Scenes,' and questions 37-42 requiring reading an economics text dealing with the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) capital adequacy ratio.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Han Jong-chan = On the afternoon of November 14, a test-taker who finished the 2020 academic year College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT) hugs family members while leaving the test site at Deokseong Girls' High School in Jongno-gu, Seoul. 2019.11.14 saba@yna.co.kr

The second period mathematics section was similar in difficulty to last year's somewhat difficult CSAT for both Type Ga (mainly taken by science track students) and Type Na (taken by humanities track students), but there are observations that upper-middle tier students may have found it difficult as the difficulty gap between hard and easy problems decreased.

Choi Young-jin, a school teacher at Geumchon High School in Gyeonggi Province, said about Type Ga, "The difficulty was similar to last year's CSAT or this year's September mock evaluation."

Oh Su-seok, a school teacher at Somyeong Girls' High School, said, "Questions that could be classified as high-difficulty decreased while medium-difficulty questions increased," adding "Upper-middle tier test-takers may have felt pressed for time and found the test somewhat difficult."

College entrance exam preparation companies also generally agreed that mathematics difficulty was similar to last year while analyzing that test-takers may have felt it was difficult.

Jinhaksa said, "For Type Ga, the variable is that numerous problems were presented that would take middle-tier students considerable time to solve," while Daesung Hagwon [a major test preparation hagwon] stated, "While the difficulty of ultra-high difficulty questions decreased, the difficulty of the remaining questions increased, so test-takers may have felt it was slightly more difficult than last year's CSAT."

The third period English section was evaluated as having moderate difficulty, easier than last year's CSAT.

The Korean Council for University Education's college entrance counseling teacher group analyzed, "English was somewhat easier than last year's CSAT and this year's September mock evaluation" and "There were no new question types this year."

Yu Seong-ho, a school teacher at Sungdeok Girls' High School, said, "Students who studied focusing on EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) linked textbooks would have found it easy to approach the passages," adding "Some sentences were difficult, so middle-tier students may have felt the difficulty was somewhat high, but since the answer choices were not difficult compared to last year's CSAT, they would have maintained their usual grades."

The English section has used absolute evaluation since the 2018 academic year CSAT.

In this year's CSAT, the number of test-takers fell below 500,000 for the first time in history due to declining school-age population and expansion of university early admission recruiting.

According to the Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation, the number of test-takers for the CSAT's third period was 482,348, marking the lowest figure and falling below 500,000 for the first time since the CSAT was implemented in 1993.

The evaluation institute will receive objections to questions and answers from immediately after the CSAT ends until the 18th, and will finalize and announce the answers on the 25th.

CSAT scores will be notified to test-takers on the 4th of next month.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Young-eun = The 2020 academic year College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT) is administered simultaneously at 1,185 test sites in 86 test districts nationwide on the 14th. CSAT score reports will be distributed on the 4th of next month. 0eun@yna.co.kr

{

  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) The prosecution announced on the 14th that it is investigating former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, who is suspected of being involved in his wife's proxy stock investments and children's college admissions irregularities. (Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Kye-yeon = The prosecution summoned and investigated former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54) on the 14th.
This comes 97 days after he was nominated as Justice Minister candidate on August 9th.
The following is a major timeline related to former Minister Cho.
◇ August 2019
▲ August 9 = President Moon Jae-in nominates former Blue House Civil Affairs Senior Secretary Cho Kuk as Justice Minister.
▲ August 14 = President Moon submits personnel hearing request for candidate Cho to the National Assembly. Facts revealed about spouse and children's 7.4 billion won [approximately $5.5 million USD] private equity fund investment agreement.
▲ August 16 = Allegations raised regarding candidate Cho's family involving fake divorce, fake real estate transactions, fake address registration, and Woongdong Academy 'fake lawsuit' suspicions.

{
  "translated_title": "[CSAT] Motel stays and restaurant lunch boxes... How long will island test-takers face inconvenience?",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yeosu Yeonam High School. Resale and DB storage prohibited]

(Muan=Yonhap News) Reporter Son Sang-won = There are calls to address the inconveniences faced by test-takers who travel to the mainland every year to take the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam).

Students from island villages, who couldn't even visit college prep hagwons [private academies] throughout their three years of high school, are taking the CSAT on an 'uneven playing field.'

According to the South Jeolla Provincial Office of Education on the 14th, 139 students from 7 high schools in South Jeolla Province traveled to the mainland for the CSAT.

These include 79 from Sinan County (64 from Docho, 6 from Imja, 9 from Haui), 25 from Wando County (15 from Nohwa, 10 from Geumil), 23 from Yeosu Yeonam High School, and 12 from Jindo Jodo High School.

The students came to the mainland where testing centers are located on the 13th and stayed overnight at motels and other accommodations.

Haui High School students began their journey on the 12th.

The provincial education office provided each student with 100,000 won [approximately $75 USD] (150,000 won [approximately $113 USD] for Haui High School students) for transportation and accommodation costs, and decided to provide additional support if students need to stay on the mainland longer.

Although teachers accompany them, many students are entering a motel for the first time in their lives.

Lunch boxes are packed by asking restaurants that the students use.

Unlike students who can adjust their condition until the last moment under their families' care, these students must endure the inconvenience of adapting to unfamiliar environments.

Lee Chang-gyun, principal of Sinan Docho High School, said, "It's heartbreaking for students because not only do they lack good study conditions on the island, but they also face discrimination in taking tests and even eating. While practical alternatives don't readily come to mind, I hope we can find solutions such as active support from the Navy."

Many students engage in cultural activities and return home the next day because ferry schedules are not convenient even after the test ends.

[Yonhap News file photo]

On Ulleungdo Island, where ships cannot operate for long periods, students head to Pohang, North Gyeongsang Province a week in advance.

In 2017, it took a whopping 17 days for test-takers to return home due to earthquakes and rough seas.

Requests to establish testing centers on islands come up every college entrance exam season, but they are blocked by arguments that making exceptions in a national-level exam could create another fairness issue.

Considering the reality that test papers must be delivered to testing centers at dawn on the test day for security reasons and dozens of supervisory and management personnel must be deployed, it's not easy to accommodate such requests.

Regulations that prevent students from one school from exceeding 40% of test-takers at a single testing center, implemented to prevent cheating, also make it difficult to establish island testing centers.

At island testing centers, collecting and transporting answer sheets might not be possible on the same day depending on sea conditions.

An official from the South Jeolla Provincial Office of Education said, "There are many factors to consider to ensure students take the test under the most equal conditions. However, as students' inconveniences continue to repeat, we will persistently make suggestions so that improvement measures that can reduce them even a little can be developed."

{
  "translated_title": "Cho Kuk Summoned by Prosecutors One Month After Resigning as Justice Minister...Investigated as Suspect (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Prosecutors announced on the 14th that they are investigating former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, who is suspected of being involved in his wife's stock investments under borrowed names and his children's university admission fraud. The photo shows former Minister Cho leaving Seoul Detention Center in Uiwang City on the 24th of last month after visiting his wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim. Former Justice Minister Cho Kuk leaving. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Gye-yeon = Prosecutors are investigating former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54), who is suspected of being involved in his wife's stock investments under borrowed names and his children's university admission fraud, after summoning him on the 14th.
This comes 79 days after launching a forcible investigation with large-scale raids and searches on August 27, and one month after former Minister Cho's resignation.
As prosecutors directly investigate former Minister Cho, who is at the center of the allegations, the direction and level of judicial processing, including whether to seek an arrest warrant against him, is expected to be the final hurdle of this investigation.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Anti-Corruption Investigation Division 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) has been questioning former Minister Cho about the facts surrounding various allegations raised so far since 9:35 AM today.
Former Minister Cho's appearance at the prosecutors' office was not disclosed to the media. It is known that former Minister Cho is being investigated as a suspect with his lawyer present.
Former Minister Cho appears to be involved in a significant portion of the 15 criminal charges against his wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57, detained), Dongyang University, who was indicted for the second time on the 11th. Prosecutors are expected to focus on questioning whether he knew that Professor Chung purchased shares of secondary battery company WFM under borrowed names.
WFM is an investee company of Colink Private Equity (Colink PE), a private fund management company in which Professor Chung invested 1.05 billion won [approximately $790,000 USD] under her own name and those of her two children. Prosecutors have determined that Professor Chung obtained undisclosed information from Cho Beom-dong (36, indicted while detained), the actual operator of Colink PE and former Minister Cho's second cousin, and purchased 144,304 shares of WFM stock under borrowed names from January to November last year.
Prosecutors have secured financial transaction records showing that 50 million won [approximately $38,000 USD] was withdrawn from former Minister Cho's account on the same day Professor Chung purchased 120,000 WFM shares over-the-counter at the end of January last year, and have been tracking the flow of this money.
If he knew the transferred money would be used for stock investment, it would violate the Public Officials Ethics Act's prohibition on direct investment and could also face charges of false property reporting. The improper profit of 208,832,109 won [approximately $157,000 USD] that Professor Chung made from stock investment or the 'favorable information provision' could be viewed as bribes that WFM gave to former Minister Cho.
[Provided by Busan Medical Center]

Allegations surrounding his daughter's (28) scholarship at Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine are also a key subject of investigation that could develop into bribery charges.
Former Minister Cho's daughter received scholarships of 2 million won [approximately $1,500 USD] each semester for 6 semesters from 2016, totaling 12 million won [approximately $9,000 USD]. Noh Hwan-jung, current director of Busan Medical Center who gave the scholarship as her supervising professor, is known to have personally written a document stating that he played 'a role' in the process of selecting President Moon Jae-in's personal physician.
With the possibility that former Minister Cho's influence as presidential secretary for civil affairs at the time may have affected the process of being appointed as Busan Medical Center director in June, prosecutors recently summoned Director Noh on the 11th and 13th consecutively to investigate the circumstances of the scholarship payment.
Prosecutors also plan to ask former Minister Cho whether he was involved in the process of his daughter and son (23) fraudulently obtaining internship certificates from Seoul National University Law School's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center.
The daughter received a certificate in 2009 and the son in 2013, each stating they had interned at Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center, which they submitted for university admissions. Prosecutors have secured internship certificate files from former Minister Cho's home PC and have been investigating whether former Minister Cho, who was serving as a law professor at the time, was involved.
Professor Chung's charges include submitting her daughter's false internship certificate for university admissions (exercising falsely prepared official documents). Prosecutors wrote in the indictment that she 'handed her daughter an internship confirmation letter with false content,' but did not reveal the certificate issuance process.
Whether he was involved in or aided evidence destruction is also subject to investigation.
Prosecutors have secured testimony that former Minister Cho told Kim Kyung-rok (37), a Korea Investment & Securities private banker who managed the couple's assets, 'Thank you for helping my wife' when the hard disk of the PC at their Bangbae-dong home in Seoul was replaced.
Since Professor Chung led the response to private fund-related allegations during the confirmation hearing process, whether former Minister Cho himself knew that the explanations he provided were false is expected to be a key issue.
(Seoul=Yonhap News) Prosecutors announced on the 14th that they are investigating former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, who is suspected of being involved in his wife's stock investments under borrowed names and his children's university admission fraud. The photo shows former Justice Minister Cho Kuk leaving the Ministry of Justice at the Government Complex Gwacheon on the 14th after announcing his resignation. [Yonhap News file photo] photo@yna.co.kr

Former Minister Cho received and used operation status reports prepared by Colink Private Equity (Colink PE), a private fund management company, to explain the allegations. Prosecutors believe Professor Chung instructed the false preparation of this report and indicted her on charges of instructing evidence fabrication.
Prosecutors also believe investigation is necessary regarding the hiring irregularities and sham litigation charges involving his younger brother Cho (52, detained while indicted) at Ungdong Academy.
Ungdong Academy is a Gyeongnam regional school foundation operated by former Minister Cho's family, with his late father Cho Byeon-hyeon and currently his mother Park Jeong-suk (81) serving as board chairperson. Former Minister Cho served as a board member of Ungdong Academy from 1999 to 2009. Prosecutors have secured legal review documents regarding Korea Asset Management Corporation's (KAMCO) provisional seizure of Ungdong Academy from former Minister Cho's PC and have been confirming his involvement in sham litigation.
Former Minister Cho acknowledges that he was partially involved in the hiring process, including receiving requests from Ungdong Academy to prepare teacher recruitment exam questions and re-delegating them to professors in related fields. However, his position is that he does not accurately remember when he was asked to prepare the questions and that this is unrelated to hiring irregularities.
Given the wide range of allegations raised against former Minister Cho, additional summons and investigations are highly likely. Prosecutors are expected to carefully decide on future investigation procedures, including seeking an arrest warrant, by comprehensively considering former Minister Cho's statement attitude and other factors.

{
  "translated_title": "Accomplice Who Delivered Bribes to Cho Kuk's Brother Requests Bail, but Court Rejects",
  "translated_text": "Mr. Cho [brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk], who is suspected of committing hiring corruption and fabricated lawsuits at Woongdong School Foundation operated by former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's family, enters Seoul Central District Court in Seocho-gu, Seoul on the morning of the 31st of last month to undergo a warrant review hearing. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Ko Dong-wook = An accomplice indicted on charges of delivering bribes to former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's brother requested to receive a non-detention trial, but the court rejected it.

Seoul Central District Court Criminal Division 4 Judge Hong Jun-seo held a bail hearing (release on conditions such as deposit) for Mr. Cho (45), a person involved in the Woongdong School Foundation hiring corruption case, on the 11th and then rejected the request.

Mr. Cho's side requested bail at the end of last month, saying "The prosecution is not providing copies of case records due to accomplice investigations."

They also argued that he had faithfully cooperated with the prosecution investigation and, unlike his accomplices, was not indicted on charges of harboring criminals, so there was little concern about evidence destruction.

At the bail hearing held on this day, Mr. Cho appealed, saying "I reflect that my actions were wrong" and "Please give me the opportunity to go outside and serve students even a little (as a school baseball coach)."

However, the court appears to have determined that Mr. Cho's side's arguments do not constitute legal grounds for granting bail.

Mr. Cho was indicted under detention along with another accomplice, Mr. Park (52), on charges of receiving bribes from parents of Woongdong School Foundation teacher hiring applicants, taking some as commission fees, and then delivering them to former Minister Cho's brother, who is the administrative director of Woongdong School Foundation.

He is also charged with providing teacher hiring exam questions and answers received from former Minister Cho's brother to applicant parents in exchange for money and goods.

  "translated_text": "(Cheongju=Yonhap News) Reporter Jeon Chang-hae = A hagwon director who sexually assaulted a hagwon instructor at his own hagwon has been sentenced to prison.
[Yonhap News file photo]

The Cheongju District Court Criminal Division 11 (Presiding Judge Na Gyeong-seon) announced on the 11th that it sentenced A (32), who was indicted on charges of quasi-rape resulting in injury, to 5 years in prison.
The court also ordered A to complete a 40-hour sexual violence treatment program and imposed a 5-year employment restriction from facilities related to children, adolescents, and disabled persons.
The court stated, "The defendant's crime of sexually assaulting and injuring a victim who was in an incapacitated state due to intoxication carries heavy guilt," and "Considering that the victim, who has suffered great psychological shock and is having difficulty with normal daily life, is petitioning for severe punishment, corresponding punishment is necessary."
A was brought to trial on charges of sexually assaulting hagwon instructor B, who had fallen asleep while intoxicated, at around 3 AM on July 21st in the office of a hagwon he operates in Cheongju, and causing injuries requiring one week of treatment in the process.
It was investigated that A committed this crime using a company dinner held after a hagwon event as a pretext.
It was revealed that when B regained consciousness during the crime and tried to leave the office, A restrained her and continued the assault.
A appealed the verdict in disagreement with this ruling.

{
  "translated_title": "Autonomous Private High Schools and Foreign Language High Schools: "Witch Hunt Without Public Discussion... We'll Resist to the End" (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Ji-eun = Officials from the Seoul Autonomous Private High School Principals' Association and Parents' Association hold a press conference on the afternoon of the 7th at the Ewha Girls' High School Centennial Memorial Hall in Jung-gu, Seoul, condemning the conversion of autonomous private high schools to regular high schools. The Ministry of Education announced on this day a 'Plan to Eliminate High School Hierarchies' that includes converting three types of high schools—foreign language high schools (foreign language highs), international high schools, and autonomous private high schools (autonomous private highs)—to regular high schools all at once in 2025. 2019.11.7 jieunlee@yna.co.kr

(Suwon·Seoul·Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Young-ju, Lee Jae-young, Lee Hyo-seok = When the government plan to convert autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to regular high schools all at once in 2025 was announced on the 7th, the affected schools reacted with fierce opposition.

The Seoul Autonomous Private High School Principals' Association and Seoul Autonomous Private High School Parents' Association held a press conference on the afternoon of this day at Ewha Girls' High School in Jung-gu, Seoul, condemning the government's conversion plan to regular high schools.

The Principals' Association criticized the government plan as "an outrageous act that damages the consistency of education policy by considering only political gains and losses with next year's general election in mind" and "a policy that regresses to uniform equality under the false pretense of securing fairness and eliminating high school hierarchies."

They added, "We will resist to the end against the government's blanket abolition policy for autonomous private high schools" and "We will also hold them responsible for losses and tangible and intangible damages resulting from investments made believing that government policy would be consistent."

On this day, Principal Jeong Young-woo of Yongin University of Foreign Studies High School told Yonhap News, "The government has never once asked for our position," adding "We will respond by mobilizing every possible method."

Principal Jo Gyu-cheol of Ansan Dongsan High School, which is currently in litigation to cancel the autonomous private high school designation revocation against Gyeonggi Provincial Office of Education, also criticized, "The government unilaterally announced the plan without listening to the schools' opinions," saying "Since education policy changes according to popular sentiment, only students suffer damage."

The National Foreign Language High Schools and International High Schools Parents' Association held a press conference on the 5th demanding the immediate withdrawal of the foreign language high school and international high school conversion policy.

In their statement, they criticized, "Foreign language high schools and international high schools are schools established to complement the problems of uniform education," and "Students simply chose foreign language high schools and international high schools within public education according to their aptitudes and specialties, yet they are being misunderstood as having received special privileges."

They continued, "Without any public discussion process involving the parties concerned—schools, students, and parents—they are driving public opinion as if conducting a 'witch hunt,'" and expressed outrage that "the government has treated education issues from a political perspective and reached conclusions through the logic of power."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Seung-du = Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education Yoo Eun-hye (third from right) announces the 'Plan to Eliminate High School Hierarchies and Strengthen Regular High School Educational Capacity' on the afternoon of the 7th at the Government Complex Seoul, with the main content being the conversion of autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to regular high schools all at once in 2025. From left: Superintendents Do Seong-hun of Incheon Metropolitan Office of Education, Jang Hee-guk of Gwangju Metropolitan Office of Education, Choi Gyo-jin of Sejong Metropolitan Office of Education, Deputy Prime Minister Yoo, Lee Jae-jeong of Gyeonggi Provincial Office of Education, and Cho Hee-yeon of Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education. 2019.11.7 kimsdoo@yna.co.kr

Reactions from teacher organizations were mixed.

The Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations (KFTA) criticized it as "a measure that damages the Constitution, which requires matters related to school systems and operations to be determined by law, and a declaration to abandon diversity in education," adding "The major framework and direction of national education is not something to be decided by enforcement ordinances."

They continued, "The introduction of the high school credit system is a matter for the next administration, and there are skeptical circumstances about whether the credit system can take root in the field after introduction," and pointed out that "promoting the abolition of autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools on the premise of introducing the credit system is out of order."

On the other hand, KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) stated, "Eliminating high school hierarchies is something KTU has consistently advocated," and "Though it's regrettably late, we welcome the Ministry of Education's recognition of the seriousness of high school hierarchization and its move toward blanket conversion of autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to regular high schools."

Jeon Gyeong-won, director of KTU's True Education Research Institute, welcomed the government plan, saying "Because students have been separated and educated in various schools using 'excellence education' as a shield, signs have appeared that students naturally accept class-based separation," but added "Doubts remain about whether (policy continuity) will be guaranteed as (plan realization) extends to the next government."

The Teachers' Association for Educational Practice welcomed the government plan while urging that "affirmative actions such as personnel and budget support for vulnerable regions and schools to enable substantial equalization, and withdrawal of the expansion of regular admissions [university entrance based on CSAT scores] that conflicts with the equalization direction are necessary."

The civic education organization No Worries About Private Education welcomed "the Ministry of Education's decision to improve student selection methods for science high schools and schools for the gifted in addition to the blanket conversion of autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to regular high schools," and urged that "effective detailed measures must be prepared going forward."

College entrance exam experts predicted that autonomous private high schools and foreign language high schools with long traditions are likely to continue their legacy as prestigious regional schools even after converting to regular high schools, so areas around these schools will become 'prestigious school districts' with concentration phenomena.

Lim Seong-ho, representative of Jongro Academy Sky Education, predicted, "Schools like Hana High School, Daewon Foreign Language High School, Hanyeong Foreign Language High School, and Myeongdeok Foreign Language High School will become even more difficult to enter after converting to regular high schools," adding "There's a possibility that demand will emerge for moving to school districts where these schools are located.""
}

{
  "translated_title": "How to prepare for college entrance exams amid expansion of regular admissions and abolition of autonomous private high schools... Anxiety increases interest in hagwon education↑",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = The Ministry of Education is expected to announce measures to eliminate high school hierarchies and strengthen fairness in college admissions in succession soon.
The core of the measures to eliminate high school hierarchies will be the abolition of autonomous private high schools (jasago) and foreign language high schools (oego), while the measures to strengthen college admission fairness will center on increasing the proportion of regular admissions at major universities.
Parents are paying keen attention to how the college entrance landscape will change depending on the timing of implementation and specific details.
According to the education sector on the 3rd, the abolition of jasago and oego will likely be pursued with a target of the 2025 school year, while the expansion of regular admissions at major universities will likely target the 2022 school year.
From the students' perspective, the expansion of regular admissions will be applied starting with college entrance exams for current first-year high school students (born in 2003), and the abolition of jasago and oego will be applied starting with high school entrance exams for current fourth-grade elementary students (born in 2009).
The year 2025, when jasago and oego will be abolished, is also the year the current government has announced as the first year of full implementation of the high school credit system. When the high school credit system is introduced, the college entrance system that matches it will change starting from the 2028 school year.
Synthesizing this roadmap, the conclusion is that students born from 2003 to 2008, currently first-year high school to fifth-grade elementary students, will receive secondary education and take college entrance exams under the current college entrance system where student record-based admissions (susi) and CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam]-based admissions (jeongsi) form the two pillars.
This age group is expected to become the 'half regular admissions, half early admissions generation.' The government is expected to announce a plan to expand regular admissions centered on major universities soon, with dominant speculation that it will raise the current regular admissions ratio of 20-30% to a maximum of 40-50%.
[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

So how will college entrance preparation for students born from 2003 to 2008 differ from current test-takers?
The current college entrance system centers on comprehensive student record evaluation (hakjong), with CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] regarded as a 'second chance.' Top-tier students prepare mainly focused on school records [GPA] and extracurricular activities rather than CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], while mid-to-upper tier students and below 'go all-in' on CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] afterward if they judge they ruined their first-year high school GPA.
When regular admissions expand and the ratio of regular and early admissions becomes similar, students are expected to maintain both school records [GPA] and CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] throughout their entire first to third year of high school.
One college entrance specialist said, "Since only about 10% of students go to university through school records [GPA] anyway, the number of 'regular admissions track' students will increase dramatically," observing that "the government also plans to reduce extracurricular activities, so the importance of school records [GPA] will grow even more."
Students and parents initially welcome the expansion of regular admissions.
Parent Kang (46), who has a third-year middle school son, said, "Anyway, since regular admissions are increasing, if we maintain school records [GPA] while continuing to send him to a comprehensive hagwon, wouldn't there be opportunities whether in early or regular admissions?" adding, "It's better than vaguely preparing for hakjong, where both the process and results are unclear."
However, there are major concerns in school settings that problem-solving classes will increase instead of presentation and discussion classes.
High school teacher Lee (35) said, "Schools also consider entrance exam performance important, so if CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] becomes important again, we'll have no choice but to increase the proportion of problem-solving and memorization," lamenting.
[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

Elementary students born after 2009 will become the 'high school credit system generation' if current government plans proceed. Parents with children in this age group are also busy with premature college entrance concerns.
When their children become high school students, the high school credit system will be introduced where students choose classes like university students, but jasago and oego are scheduled to be eliminated, so the number of top-tier students in regular high schools will increase. Policies that would overhaul the existing system, such as essay-type CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] and integration of regular and early admissions, are being discussed as college entrance systems that match the high school credit system.
Anxious parents are turning their attention to hagwon education. One hagwon education industry official hinted, "Whether it's essay-type CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], early admission interviews, or CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] killer questions, advanced subject learning and prerequisite learning are ultimately the answer," adding, "Recently, as education policy announcements have followed one after another, hagwon inquiries have surged."
Parent Kim (37), whose child is in third grade elementary school, said, "Looking around, fast kids are already going to Korean, English, and math prerequisite learning hagwons in second or third grade elementary school," adding, "I heard that the high school credit system is ultimately a system where you choose between advanced and basic classes, so I'm gradually looking into hagwons."
