  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Seong Do-hyeon and Park Jae-hyeon = With prosecutors arresting the younger brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54), who faces charges including hagwon teacher hiring corruption and sham litigation at Woongdong Hagwon, future investigations are expected to focus on the former minister and his mother.

Following the consecutive arrests of Cho's fifth cousin Cho Beom-dong (36) and his wife Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57) of Dongyang University, prosecutors have now secured the arrest of Cho's younger brother, bringing the total number of arrested family members to three.

According to legal circles on the 1st, Seoul Central District Court Chief Judge Shin Jong-yeol, who is in charge of warrants, issued an arrest warrant after conducting a pre-arrest interrogation (warrant substantive review) of the younger brother the previous day. The younger brother was arrested after prosecutors' second arrest warrant request.

Chief Judge Shin stated, "Considering the investigation progress before and after the previous arrest warrant request, additional criminal charges, and materials related to grounds for arrest, the necessity and reasonableness of arrest can be recognized."

After the first arrest warrant was rejected, prosecutors conducted supplementary investigations on the younger brother's breach of trust charges, which the court had indicated were "subject to dispute," while investigating related parties.

Prosecutors also detected circumstances of the younger brother's instructions for overseas flight and added charges of harboring criminals and evading compulsory execution to the arrest warrant's criminal facts, ultimately securing warrant approval.

During the warrant substantive review, prosecutors reportedly focused on proving charges that Cho, as Woongdong Hagwon's administrative director, secured construction payment claims based on fraudulent construction work and filed sham litigation against the school foundation, causing damages of approximately 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD] to the school foundation.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Do-hoon = The younger brother of former Minister Cho, suspected of committing Woongdong Hagwon hiring corruption and sham litigation, enters Seoul Central District Court in Seocho-gu, Seoul on October 31 for warrant substantive review. superdoo82@yna.co.kr

Prosecutors reportedly defined the younger brother's charges as serious private school corruption in their 30-page A4 arrest warrant request, emphasizing them as anti-social crimes with high culpability.

After winning the sham litigation, the younger brother transferred the claims to his wife and divorced her. Prosecutors suspect he staged the divorce to avoid compulsory execution by Korea Asset Management Corporation (KAMCO).

The younger brother admitted only to some hiring corruption charges while denying all charges related to sham litigation and staged divorce. Despite this, the issuance of the arrest warrant suggests the court recognized prosecutors' arguments based on investigation findings.

Like with Professor Chung's arrest warrant, the court did not mention health issues. Despite the younger brother's continued complaints of herniated discs, the court appears to have determined he could serve prison time based on verification materials submitted by prosecutors. The backdrop for warrant approval likely included controversies over malingering amid frequent hospital admissions and discharges, and the burden of another rejection with two accomplices already arrested.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Anti-Corruption Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) will summon the younger brother from Dongbu Detention Center in Songpa-gu, Seoul this afternoon to investigate whether former Minister Cho and other family members were involved in Woongdong Hagwon corruption.

Prosecutors plan to continue investigating allegations that in 2015, the younger brother received tens of millions of won [approximately $15,000–75,000 USD] from a Busan construction company president under the pretext of service fees, claiming he would arrange project financing (PF) loans.

Woongdong Hagwon is currently chaired by Park Jeong-sook (81), Cho's mother, following the late Cho Byeon-hyeon, Cho's father. Former Minister Cho served as a board member from 1999 to 2009.

A statement posted on Woongdong Middle School's website on August 23 by Park Jeong-sook, chairwoman of Woongdong Hagwon school foundation and mother of Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk. [Captured from Woongdong Middle School website. Resale and DB prohibited]

Prosecutors suspect Chairwoman Park may be involved in the younger brother's hiring corruption and sham litigation charges and question whether she is an accomplice. As Park served as board member and chairwoman during the younger brother's crimes, she is considered the person most knowledgeable about the overall details.

While prosecutors have not yet notified Park's side about summons investigation schedules, her summons is considered imminent following the younger brother's arrest. Park is also reportedly preparing to hire legal counsel for her response.

The ultimate destination of the investigation is expected to be former Minister Cho. Final investigations are expected to focus on clarifying whether former Minister Cho was involved in his family's corruption allegations.

Prosecutors reportedly secured legal review documents regarding KAMCO's provisional seizure of Woongdong Hagwon from a PC during a search and seizure of former Minister Cho's residence, and are confirming his involvement.

Former Minister Cho's position is that while he was partially involved in the hiring process by receiving requests from Woongdong Hagwon to set exam questions for teacher hiring and re-delegating this to professors in relevant fields, he was not involved in hiring corruption.

Regarding Woongdong Hagwon litigation, former Minister Cho has previously stated during personnel hearings that he was not involved in the litigation at all and knew almost nothing about its content.

Meanwhile, prosecutors did not conduct separate investigations of Professor Chung today, following yesterday. Prosecutors attempted to summon Professor Chung for investigation yesterday, but she did not comply, citing health reasons.

Prosecutors extended Professor Chung's detention period until the 11th with court approval yesterday. Prosecutors plan to file additional charges against Professor Chung before the 11th.

{
  "translated_title": "'Is Study Money?' Production Team: "Not a Show That Promotes Hagwon Education"",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by MBC]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Song Eun-kyung = Education and college entrance exams, topics of national concern, are being addressed in a terrestrial regular variety show.

MBC TV's 'Is Study Money?', which will begin its first broadcast on the 1st of next month at 9:50 PM following regular scheduling, is an educational variety show that seeks the most efficient study methods at the lowest cost.

As the program title includes 'money', the broadcast argues that education expenses should be spent in 'certain and accurate' places. The format involves listening to the concerns of clients appearing on the show and providing solutions based on expert advice.

During the pilot episode, the broadcast faced harsh criticism for being filled with college entrance exam-focused consulting and promoting hagwon education.

PD Sun Hye-yoon repeatedly emphasized at a press conference held on the 31st at MBC headquarters in Sangam-dong, Mapo-gu, Seoul, "This is not a program that promotes hagwon education."

PD Sun stated, "During the pilot, it may have appeared to emphasize hagwon education because the clients who appeared, actor Lim Ho and his wife, had concerns about hagwon education, but we are absolutely not promoting it."

The regularly scheduled 'Is Study Money?' will not be limited to solving celebrity families' concerns. Various age groups and topics will be covered, including general families, educational blind spots like remote mountainous areas, specialized high school students, and preschool children. It encompasses everything related to education, from how kindergarteners open milk cartons to the pros and cons of early admission and regular admission for college entrance.

[Provided by MBC]

Regarding the controversy about only covering hagwon education, PD Sun emphasized, "We've completed recording up to episode 3, and in episode 2, a current elementary school teacher appears to provide solutions," adding "We will not exclude public education."

To concerns that specific educational products or hagwon education experts might unintentionally gain promotion by leveraging the program, he reassured, "Through the broadcast, we will minimize the appearance of specific hagwons, workbooks, or study materials."

However, he added, "That said, we can't just ignore (parents' concerns), so if it helps interested people even a little, we are considering revealing (products) through channels other than the broadcast."

In episode 1 of 'Is Study Money?', former Seoul National University admissions officer Jin Dong-seop, EduMom Mentoring CEO Choi Seong-hyeon, child psychology expert Son Jeong-seon, and Megastudy College Entrance Strategy Research Institute Director Nam Yun-gon will appear to discuss the college entrance exam system. Shin Dong-yeop and Eugene will serve as MCs.

First broadcast tomorrow night at 9:50 PM.

  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lim Hwa-young = Chung Kyung-sim, Dongyang University professor and wife of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, heads toward a transport vehicle after completing a warrant substantive review at Seoul Central District Court in Seocho-gu, Seoul on the afternoon of the 23rd. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Kim Kye-yeon, Park Jae-hyeon = As speculation grows that the summoning investigation of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54) is imminent, prosecutors are focusing on building conspiracy charges against former Minister Cho through his wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57) of Dongyang University.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Division 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyung-gon) has been investigating Professor Chung since 9:40 AM on the 29th, summoning her from Seoul Detention Center.

This is the third summoning investigation of Professor Chung following her arrest on the 24th, with previous sessions on the 25th and 27th. Even before her detention, Professor Chung frequently appeared at the prosecutors' office every other day.

Prosecutors reportedly focused primarily on university admissions fraud and evidence destruction charges in the previous two investigations. Additional investigation into private equity fund-related allegations, one of the three branches of criminal charges against Professor Chung, is expected to follow.

Prosecutors are expected to set a schedule for summoning former Minister Cho after investigating Professor Chung one or two more times. Since Professor Chung continues to deny most charges against her, as she did before her arrest, additional investigations are not expected to take long.

Former Minister Cho appears to be implicated in nearly half of the 11 criminal charges listed in Professor Chung's arrest warrant.

Prosecutors are investigating whether former Minister Cho was involved in the false issuance of internship certificates from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his daughter (28) and son (23). Prosecutors applied charges of exercising falsely prepared official documents to Professor Chung for submitting the forged certificates for her daughter's university admissions. However, they did not mention the subject of the document forgery in the arrest warrant.

Prosecutors confirmed that 50 million won [approximately $38,000 USD] was withdrawn from former Minister Cho's account on the same day Professor Chung purchased 120,000 shares of KOSDAQ-listed company WFM at 5,000 won [approximately $3.80 USD] per share under a borrowed name in January last year, and are tracking whether this money was used for the stock purchase.

If former Minister Cho was aware of the stock investment situation and sent the money, he could be subject to direct investment prohibition regulations under the Public Service Ethics Act and face charges of false asset reporting.

Prosecutors are reportedly reviewing the legal principles of whether the difference, estimated at over 100 million won [approximately $76,000 USD], could be considered a bribe if WFM sold the stocks below market price based on expectations of business assistance from former Minister Cho, who was then Senior Presidential Secretary for Civil Affairs at the Blue House [the presidential office].

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Choi Jae-gu = Former Justice Minister Cho Kuk converses with his son and a woman inside Seoul Detention Center in Uiwang City after finishing a visit with his wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim, on the 24th. [Yonhap News file photo]

Former Minister Cho also faces allegations that he aided in evidence concealment despite knowing that asset manager Kim Kyung-rok (37) replaced the hard disk of a PC at his Bangbae-dong home in Seoul immediately after the investigation began in late August.

Kim previously accompanied Professor Chung to her Dongyang University office in Yeongju, North Gyeongsang Province, removed an entire PC, and voluntarily submitted it to prosecutors along with the home PC hard disk. Professor Chung reportedly maintains the position that "Kim acted on his own" regarding evidence destruction. However, prosecutors obtained an arrest warrant for Professor Chung, also applying charges of instructing evidence concealment.

Prosecutors also summoned Kim today to re-investigate circumstances before and after evidence destruction. They continue tracking the whereabouts of a laptop Professor Chung used. Prosecutors secured Kim's statement that he "went to Kensington Hotel in Yeouido, Seoul, at Professor Chung's request on the morning of the 6th of last month, the day of former Minister Cho's confirmation hearing, and handed over the laptop," but Professor Chung denied the facts.

Prosecutors plan to soon resubmit an arrest warrant for Cho's younger brother, Mr. Cho (52), who faces charges of hiring irregularities and sham litigation at Woongdong Academy [a hagwon]. The timing of the warrant resubmission will depend on how much progress is made in investigating a complaint case received last week regarding another instance of Mr. Cho allegedly receiving money and goods.

Mr. Cho also faces allegations that in 2015, he received tens of millions of won [approximately $15,000–75,000 USD] from a Busan construction company president under the pretext of fees, claiming he would "arrange project financing (PF) loans."

Mr. Cho's side stated, "While settling business contracts with the construction company, we received claims, but we cannot accurately remember the company's name and specific amounts. If prosecutors summon us, we will investigate in detail and provide explanations."

If he knew the transferred money would be used for stock investment, it would violate the Public Service Ethics Act's direct investment prohibition and could also face charges of false property reporting.

Legal circles analyze that if WFM provided stocks below market price expecting help related to former Minister Cho's duties as senior presidential secretary for civil affairs at the time, bribery charges could also apply. WFM, which originally operated an English education business, entered the secondary battery field, a national policy project, after being taken over by Colink PE in October 2017.

Former Minister Cho maintains the position that he "never purchased WFM stock." Prosecutors plan to summon former Minister Cho soon to investigate whether he directly made the account transfer and how much he was involved in the stock purchase process.

Former Minister Cho also faces allegations of illegally issuing internship certificates at Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his daughter (28) and son (23), and of aiding in evidence destruction by replacing the hard disk of a PC at his Bangbae-dong residence in Seoul. Prosecutors plan to maximize the specificity of circumstances linking former Minister Cho to various allegations through Professor Chung. Professor Chung, who was arrested on the 24th, was summoned to prosecutors on the following day and the 27th for investigation related to admissions fraud and evidence concealment charges, but reportedly continues to completely deny the charges.

{
  "translated_title": "Hagwon Director Who Assaulted 12-Year-Old Children, Saying They 'Fought and Caused a Disturbance,' Receives Suspended Sentence",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Jeong Rae-won = A first-instance court sentenced a supplementary education hagwon director to a suspended prison sentence for forcing hagwon children to kneel and assaulting them on the grounds that they were fighting with each other.

Seoul Eastern District Court Criminal Division 2 Presiding Judge Lee Hyeong-ju announced on the 26th that he sentenced Mr. A (54), who was indicted on charges of violating the Special Act on the Punishment of Child Abuse Crimes, to 4 months in prison with a 1-year suspended sentence.

Mr. A was indicted without detention on charges of assaulting two 12-year-old students at a supplementary education hagwon he operated in Songpa District, Seoul, in October last year.

It was investigated that when the two male students, who were twins, fought with each other, he took them to a small room, made them kneel, and then hit them on the cheek and other areas. At the time, the younger of the twins reported to police, saying "the hagwon director is abusing children."

During the trial, Mr. A also spoke incoherently, saying "I think adults are those who wait for children," "I have absolutely no memory of hitting them," and "I don't remember, but if the kids say I hit them, then I hit them."

However, when the court asked why he had admitted to hitting the children during the prosecution's investigation, he answered, "I admit to hitting them on the cheek" and "I didn't step on [the children], but I did make them kneel."

The court explained, "Although [a hagwon director] cannot have the same heart as parents, as a hagwon director in a position to care for children, [he] must play the role of a guardian," adding, "That's why the law provides for heavier punishment when people in such positions (child guardians) abuse children."

The court also ordered Mr. A to attend 40 hours each of child abuse prevention lectures and community service.

{
  "translated_title": "[Yonhap Editorial] If Regular Admissions Must Be Expanded, Find the 'Golden Ratio'",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Is there any other system in our society that generates as much controversy as university admissions? This time, suspicions surrounding former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's children's college admissions have triggered debates about the fairness of the current admissions system. In particular, the education community appears startled by President Moon Jae-in's sudden statement about 'expanding the proportion of regular admissions [jeongsihji].' The expansion of regular admissions directly contradicts a series of policies that the Ministry of Education has prepared for normalizing high school education. President Moon appears to be accelerating university admissions system reform centered on expanding the proportion of regular admissions by convening a meeting of ministers related to educational reform on the 25th, just three days after mentioning the expansion of regular admissions in the National Assembly. This appears intended to quickly proceed with direction-setting work to minimize confusion for test-takers and parents due to frequent admissions system reforms. Despite much controversy, the fact that President Moon is willing to roll up his sleeves and directly address the sensitive issue of university admissions likely means he has positioned this issue as a core matter for creating a fair society.

While presiding over the meeting of ministers related to educational reform, President Moon clarified the intent behind his statement on expanding regular admissions. President Moon drew a line, saying "(expanding the proportion of early admissions [susi]) should only be pursued after fairness and transparency in school records and trust in university evaluations have been established first." At the same time, he emphasized, "Until then, while I know regular admissions aren't a panacea, we should still listen to the voices of test-takers and parents who say that regular admissions are fairer than early admissions for now." The President's remarks reflect his perception that the sense of loss felt by the people following the 'Cho Kuk incident' stems from distrust in early admission processes. He views unfair university admissions and other educational systems as having deteriorated into means for passing down parents' social and economic status and privileges to the next generation. The main target of expanding regular admissions appears to be Seoul's top-tier universities, which have high proportions of early admissions centered on comprehensive school record evaluation [hakjong].

The Ministry of Education now faces the task of finding both the proportion of regular admissions expansion that can guarantee fairness in university admissions and measures to normalize public education. Regarding the expansion of regular admissions, it's difficult to find an 'answer' that satisfies everyone because the interests of admission stakeholders—high schools, universities, parents, the hagwon industry, and educational organizations—differ from each other. Fortunately, there is a verified reference point for discussing the expansion of regular admissions. This is the result of public opinion surveys released by the National Education Council's Public Deliberation Committee on University Admission Reform last year. What received much support in the public opinion survey at the time was a plan to raise the proportion of regular admissions to 45% or higher. Additionally, the citizen participation group considered 39.6% to be an appropriate ratio for CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam]-centered admissions. The Ministry of Education should find the golden ratio between regular and early admissions based on such data. It should also present groundbreaking improvement measures that completely eliminate so-called 'golden spoon' elements from comprehensive school record evaluation.

Measures to normalize high school public education should also be refined to get back on track. The Moon Jae-in administration presented the 'Three-Stage Roadmap for High School System Reform' and the 'High School Credit System' early in its term. The roadmap is divided into Stage 1: improving high school admission systems, Stage 2: converting autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to general high schools, and Stage 3: high school system reform. The High School Credit System, which will be fully introduced in 2025 to eliminate high school hierarchies, is a system that allows high school students to select and attend classes they want like university students, and graduate if they meet certain credit standards. The High School System Reform Roadmap and High School Credit System are intended to change the foundation of high school education. The Ministry of Education should revise and supplement these two pillars to ensure that public education normalization and innovation are implemented without disruption. The phrase the Ministry of Education must be tired of hearing is 'education is a hundred-year plan.' We hope that the university admission reform plan the Ministry of Education will present in November will include both short and long-term measures that guarantee fairness in admissions while normalizing high school education.

{
  "translated_title": "Educational Organizations Pour Out Concerns Over College Entrance Regular Admission Expansion Policy: "Swayed by Public Opinion"",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jeong-hoon = Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye announces the results of the Education Reform-related Ministers' Meeting at the Government Complex Seoul on the morning of the 25th. 2019.10.25 uwg806@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = As the government reiterated its policy to expand regular admissions at Seoul-area universities on the 25th, educational organizations voiced concerns in unison, saying "the government is being swayed by public opinion."

Parents are confused but generally welcoming.

Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye said at a briefing after the Education Reform-related Ministers' Meeting held at the Blue House that day, "We will adjust upward the proportion of regular admissions centered on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) for Seoul-area universities with high proportions of comprehensive student record admissions and essay-writing exam admissions," and "The rate of increase will be announced next month after listening to the contents of last year's college entrance exam reform public deliberation agreement and field opinions."

The education sector poured out concerns that the government is once again pursuing an increase in regular admission ratios just one year after deciding, through last year's major confusion and unprecedented public deliberation process, to raise the regular admission ratio to over 30% for the 2022 academic year college entrance exams.

Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations spokesperson Cho Seong-cheol said, "This is a time to settle the direction decided through last year's public deliberation, but hasty reform plans should not emerge due to political demands or prejudgments," and "The college entrance system should be decided with the Ministry of Education at the center, listening to various stakeholders' opinions and considering various aspects such as university autonomy and public education normalization."

Earlier, when the President mentioned entrance exam system reforms including increasing the proportion of regular admissions in his policy address, the Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations expressed concern, saying "This revealed discord between the party, government, and Blue House, which is worrying in that it caused confusion and mixed signals for students and parents" and "It could be seen as politics intervening in education."

Progressive educational organizations such as the National Association of Provincial and Metropolitan Superintendents of Education and KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) are criticizing that if the fairness of comprehensive student record admissions is in doubt, the comprehensive student record system should be improved rather than using this as an excuse to expand regular admissions.

The superintendents' association stated, "Regular admissions centered on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) encourage curriculum disruption and create problem-solving-centered classes," and "As comprehensive student record admissions have taken root, results showing curriculum normalization are emerging, so we oppose expanding regular admissions."

The association emphasized, "After announcing the 2022 academic year college entrance exam reform plan (last year), the Ministry of Education repeatedly emphasized that it would not discuss expanding regular admissions on the grounds that it would increase confusion in school sites," and "We must listen to the voices of educational stakeholders so that college entrance system improvement plans for normalizing school education can be prepared."

KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) also argued in a statement, "Education is not a sacrifice for breaking through the current situation," and "The regular admission expansion policy should be immediately withdrawn and the entrance exam system should be improved with a focus on public education normalization."

Private Education Concern-Free World pointed out, "If regular admissions are expanded, the high school credit system that allows high school students to choose and take classes according to their career paths and aptitudes will face difficulties even before implementation," and "Rather than just solving the 'microscopic problem' of securing fairness in college entrance exams, a big picture is needed to solve the problem of parents' privileges being passed down to their children through education."

[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

Parents are confused but generally welcoming the expansion of regular admissions.

One parent with a third-year middle school child said, "If you go to a general high school, it's difficult to keep up with the 'early admission spec-building' of autonomous private high schools or special purpose high schools," and "In general high schools, students with good school records generally do well on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) too. For general high school parents who can't prepare for early admissions (as much as autonomous private schools, etc.), it's good that the balance between early admission and regular admission ratios is matched (with regular admissions being expanded)."

Lee Man-gi, director of Uway Educational Evaluation Research Institute, said, "Parents in Seoul's Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] area like the expansion of regular admissions," and "Even if they didn't expect it, they are welcoming it for now."

However, Director Lee added, "Among students who entered high school this year, in the case of students who gave up autonomous private high schools or special purpose high schools and went to general high schools because the regular admission ratio was only increased to 'over 30%' level, they might feel wronged if the regular admission ratio is greatly expanded."

He predicted, "Universities also prefer early admissions out of greed to secure excellent students first, but in terms of student selection convenience, they prefer regular admissions more," and "Universities will increase the regular admission ratio considering the number of students who are not selected in early admissions and are carried over to regular admissions."

Oh Jong-un, evaluation director of Jongno Academy Sky Education, explained, "There are bound to be more students with poor school records than good students. That's why parents and test-takers have no choice but to welcome the expansion of regular admissions."

Director Oh predicted, "If the regular admission ratio is suddenly raised a lot, the major framework of the college entrance system will shake," and "Universities will adjust the regular admission ratio to around 30-40%."

{
  "translated_title": "Justice Minister Cho Kuk's Wife Jung Kyung-shim Faces Detention Review Tomorrow...Expected to Stand Before Media (2nd Report)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim In-cheol = Jung Kyung-shim, Dongyang University professor and wife of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, heads toward the former minister's car to leave from her residence in Seocho-gu on the morning of the 22nd. 2019.10.22 yatoya@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Lim Su-jung, Park Cho-rong = The detention of Jung Kyung-shim (57), Dongyang University professor and wife of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54), will be decided on the 23rd.

Professor Jung's detention status is expected to serve as a watershed moment for the prosecution's two-month investigation into former Minister Cho's family, which began on August 27.

Seoul Central District Court announced on the 22nd that the pre-detention suspect interrogation (warrant substantive review) for Professor Jung will be conducted at 10:30 AM on the 23rd under presiding warrant-exclusive chief judge Song Kyung-ho.

Attention had focused on whether chief judge Myeong Jae-kwon, who rejected the detention warrant for former Minister Cho's younger brother Cho (52) on the 9th, would again handle Professor Jung's detention review, but the review will be handled by chief judge Song.

Seoul Central District Court has four chief judges exclusively handling warrants: Shin Jong-yeol (47, Judicial Research and Training Institute 26th class), Myeong Jae-kwon (52, 27th class), Lim Min-sung (48, 27th class), and Song Kyung-ho (49, 28th class). The warrant-exclusive judge is determined through random computer assignment.

Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Department 2 (chief prosecutor Ko Hyung-gon) applied 11 criminal charges to Professor Jung on the morning of the 21st, requesting a detention warrant for obstruction of business, obstruction of official duties through deception, capital markets law violations, and embezzlement in the course of duty, related to suspicions of children's college admission irregularities, private equity fund investments, and evidence destruction.

Professor Jung is expected to appear before the media at the court photo line for the first time since this investigation began in late August. Her legal team announced that day, "Professor Jung is scheduled to appear tomorrow."

Whether a detention warrant is issued for Professor Jung could serve as a 'report card' for the prosecution's massive two-month investigation, as it would be the court's first judgment regarding Professor Jung.

If the warrant is issued, the prosecution will indict Professor Jung after a maximum 20-day detention period.

In Professor Jung's detention review, fierce arguments are expected regarding her health condition, separate from whether criminal charges are established.

While Professor Jung has complained of brain tumor and cerebral infarction symptoms, the prosecution determined that Professor Jung's health can withstand the detention review and subsequent procedures.

A prosecution official stated, "We thoroughly verified Professor Jung's health condition through objective and fair procedures," adding, "We will explain in detail the verification procedures and results (regarding Professor Jung's health) during the pre-detention suspect interrogation process."

Professor Jung's legal team countered, "We submitted the necessary materials requested by the prosecution, including CT (computed tomography), MRI (magnetic resonance imaging), and neurosurgical diagnosis reports."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lim Hun-jung = A photo line is set up at Seoul Central District Court in Seocho-gu, Seoul on the 22nd, one day before the pre-detention suspect interrogation (warrant substantive review) of Jung Kyung-shim, Dongyang University professor and wife of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk. 2019.10.22 kane@yna.co.kr

In the case of former Minister Cho's younger brother Cho, who faces charges of hiring irregularities at Woongdong hagwon, the prosecution viewed his health as capable of withstanding detention investigation. However, among the reasons chief judge Myeong cited for rejecting Cho's detention warrant was 'the suspect's health condition.'

Chief judge Song is also expected to examine Professor Jung's health condition as she appears in court, along with objective materials such as medical certificates, when deciding on detention.

Chief judge Song, who graduated from Jeju National University High School and Seoul National University Law School, is evaluated as having decided warrant issuances based on conviction and legal principles in major cases. The general assessment in legal circles is that there have been no 'standout judgments.'

Recently, in the Club Burning Sun case, he issued a detention warrant for superintendent Yoon (49), called the 'police chief,' stating "substantial parts of criminal charges are proven and there are concerns about evidence destruction."

He also issued a warrant for conservative YouTuber Kim Sang-jin (49), who made threatening broadcasts in front of Prosecutor General Yoon Seok-yeol's (then Seoul Central District Prosecutor's Office chief) house.

Conversely, he rejected the detention warrant for Samsung Biologics CEO Kim Tae-han (62), who faces charges of instructing evidence destruction related to Samsung Biologics accounting fraud suspicions, drawing prosecution backlash.

Coincidentally, he shares the same name and age as Song Kyung-ho (49, 29th class), the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office 3rd deputy chief prosecutor who is responsible for this investigation. While they are Seoul National University Law School alumni, chief judge Song is one year senior in training institute class.

Professor Jung's side effectively denied all charges, calling them "blaming the suspect for the wrongdoings of former Minister Cho's fifth cousin" and "a fundamental misunderstanding of the facts."

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyung-gon) requested an arrest warrant on this day, stating that Professor Jung faces 11 criminal charges related to children's college admission fraud, private equity fund-related suspicions, and evidence tampering suspicions.

Based on the laws applied to the alleged facts, there are 10 types of criminal charges, but when the Capital Markets Act violations are divided by specific charges such as 'false reporting' and 'use of undisclosed information,' it becomes a total of 11 criminal charges. Including the already indicted document forgery charges, the matters Professor Jung will face trial for increase to 12 charges.

Professor Jung faces charges (obstruction of business, obstruction of public duty through deception, exercising falsely prepared official documents, exercising forged private documents) for forging or falsely obtaining documents such as commendation certificates under the name of Dongyang University president and submitting them to Pusan National University and Seoul National University Medical School admission processes for her daughter Cho (28) in 2013-2014, thereby obstructing the universities' admission operations.

Prosecutors reportedly confirmed evidence that, beyond supporting documents such as Dongyang University commendation certificates and Seoul National University Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center internship certificates, a considerable portion of the content in materials submitted for admissions was false.

There are also charges (violation of Subsidy Management Act) for falsely receiving subsidies worth millions of won [approximately $2,000–8,000 USD] by registering Ms. Cho as a research assistant for English gifted education programs and textbook development while working as director of Dongyang University's English Gifted Center in 2013. Prosecutors reportedly suspect that the daughter, who was an undergraduate student at the time, did not participate in research and development.

Regarding private equity fund investment suspicions, charges of occupational embezzlement, false reporting and use of undisclosed information under the Capital Markets Act, and violation of the Proceeds of Crime Control Act were applied.

Prosecutors believe that Professor Jung, together with her younger brother, invested in private equity management company Kolink Private Equity (Kolink PE), then made a false consulting contract under her brother-in-law's name and pocketed approximately 157.95 million won [approximately $119,000 USD] under the pretext of profits from March 2017 to September last year.

The criminal facts against Professor Jung also include evidence of obtaining undisclosed internal information about listed company WFM, which was invested in by Kolink PE funds, making equity investments and holding stocks under borrowed names. Prosecutors suspect Professor Jung used others' names to circumvent the Public Service Ethics Act, which prohibits public officials from directly investing in stocks.

Kolink PE is a company where Cho Beom-dong (36), former Minister Cho's fifth cousin, has been identified as the actual owner. The fifth cousin was arrested and indicted on the 3rd of this month on charges including stock manipulation and embezzling 7.2 billion won [approximately $5.4 million USD] in company funds.

There are also charges of false reporting for agreeing to invest 7.455 billion won [approximately $5.6 million USD] while actually investing 1.05 billion won [approximately $790,000 USD] in the Blue Core Fund managed by Kolink PE. This provision is designed to punish fund managers, not investors. Prosecutors have previously arrested Mr. Cho, identified as the actual operator of Kolink PE, on these charges.

Professor Jung also faces charges (aiding and abetting evidence concealment) for having Kim Kyung-rok (37), a Korea Investment & Securities private banker (PB) who served as her asset manager, remove an entire PC from her Dongyang University research office and hide hard disks from two PCs at her home in Bangbae-dong, Seoul [a district in Seoul], when the prosecution investigation began in late August.

Prosecutors also applied charges of aiding and abetting evidence fabrication, believing Professor Jung played a role in the creation of a management report containing false information stating that the family's 1.05 billion won [approximately $790,000 USD] private equity fund investment was a blind fund whose investment details were unknown during former Minister Cho's personnel hearing.

Professor Jung was investigated six times between the 3rd and 16th of this month. The investigation was prolonged as she sometimes returned home during questioning due to health problems, and prosecutors also took the position of avoiding late-night investigations when possible. Professor Jung reportedly denied most of the suspicions raised against her.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Hong Hae-in = Reporters are filming at the entrance of the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office in Seocho-gu, Seoul on the morning of the 21st. The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Unit 2 submitted Professor Jung's arrest warrant request to the court on this morning. Prosecutors applied charges of obstruction of business, obstruction of public duty through deception, exercising falsely prepared official documents, exercising forged private documents, and violation of the Subsidy Management Act regarding children's internship and college admission fraud suspicions. For private equity fund suspicions, charges of occupational embezzlement, false reporting and use of undisclosed information under the Capital Markets Act, and violation of the Proceeds of Crime Control Act were specified. hihong@yna.co.kr

Prosecutors typically request arrest warrants citing concerns about evidence tampering such as 'coordinating stories' when suspects deny charges. However, around the time of former Minister Cho's resignation, Professor Jung's side revealed she had been diagnosed with brain tumor and cerebral infarction and submitted hospitalization and discharge confirmation documents to prosecutors, making Professor Jung's health a variable in the arrest warrant request.

Prosecutors determined that Professor Jung's health condition could withstand the arrest review and subsequent procedures. A prosecution official said, "We received materials to check her health condition and conducted verification procedures," adding, "We plan to explain the verification procedures and results in detail at the upcoming substantive warrant review."

Apart from health issues, there is analysis that prosecutors had no other choice, as not requesting Professor Jung's arrest warrant could appear as prosecutors themselves admitting they had no significant results despite extensive investigations.

The pre-arrest suspect interrogation (substantive warrant review) is expected to be held around the 23rd. If an arrest warrant is issued, criticism that prosecutors conducted excessive investigations targeting former Minister Cho's family and political controversy could subside. If rejected, responsibility questions regarding Prosecutor General Yoon Seok-youl could intensify, potentially raising questions about his position.

Lawyer Kim Jong-min, a former prosecutor, said, 'Prosecutors' investigation target was former Minister Cho from the beginning,' adding, 'Since there are various allegations that former Minister Cho was involved in criminal charges, prosecutors are expected to focus on proving this going forward.'

Lawyer Kang Shin-eop said, 'The fact that Professor Chung denies the charges and there are concerns about evidence destruction and coordinating stories are grounds for warrant issuance,' but added, 'However, since the investigation has already progressed considerably and considering Professor Chung's health problems, there's also a possibility the court could reject the warrant. {
  "translated_title": "Prosecutors Request Warrant for Chung Kyung-sim Amid Brain Tumor Controversy… A Strategic Gamble Based on Principles",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lim Su-jung = Prosecutors who have been investigating allegations surrounding former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's (54) family requested an arrest warrant on the 21st for Chung Kyung-sim (57), Dongyang University professor and wife of former Minister Cho, after much deliberation.

Despite intense pressure from the ruling party and Seocho-dong [a Seoul district where pro-prosecution rallies were held] rallies, and amid recent controversy over Professor Chung's diagnosis of brain tumor and cerebral infarction, prosecutors are interpreted as having made a strategic gamble by invoking investigative principles as their justification.

The prosecution's investigation, which has proceeded on a large scale since the first search and seizure on August 27, is evaluated as having its initial success or failure hinge on whether an arrest warrant is issued for Professor Chung, a key figure.

◇ Applied charges reach 11... Prosecutors appear not to view health issues as 'grave circumstances'

Above all, prosecutors take the position that requesting a warrant was unavoidable given that Professor Chung is a key figure involved in most of the allegations related to former Minister Cho's family, and considering that evidence destruction circumstances—a major reason for detention investigation—have been revealed multiple times.

The charges applied by prosecutors today alone number 11.

Regarding allegations of children's college admission irregularities including forging Dongyang University commendation certificates, the applied charges are obstruction of business, obstruction of public duties by deception, exercise of falsely prepared official documents, exercise of forged private documents, and violation of the Subsidy Management Act. Regarding private equity fund investment, charges of occupational embezzlement, violation of the Capital Markets Act (false reporting, use of undisclosed information), and violation of the Act on Regulation of Criminal Proceeds Concealment were applied.

Regarding mobilizing asset managers to replace hard disk drives in PCs at her home and Dongyang University research office, charges of instigation of evidence fabrication and instigation of evidence concealment were applied.

Prosecutors are known to have deliberated extensively over this warrant request.

Prosecutors requested a warrant for Professor Chung 55 days after initiating the forced investigation, nearly two months later. While speculation about the imminent timing of the warrant request had continuously circulated inside and outside legal circles since last month, prosecutors are known to have been unable to accelerate their investigation as initially planned due to health issues raised by Professor Chung's side.

Factors included Professor Chung's side expressing difficulties with lengthy investigations due to aftereffects of brain injuries from past accidents. As a result, the number of summons investigations, initially expected to proceed only 1-2 times, increased to 7 times through the 17th.

Recently, as it became known that she received diagnoses of brain tumor and cerebral infarction, speculation emerged that prosecutors might shift to 'indictment without detention.'

Professor Chung's side submitted hospitalization/discharge confirmation documents listing symptoms similar to brain tumor and cerebral infarction, but concealed the hospital and doctor names, leading prosecutors to engage in a war of nerves by requesting submission of objective materials.

Prosecutors appear to have determined, after reviewing submitted medical materials, that Professor Chung's health condition is at a level that can withstand detention. This means they did not view Professor Chung's health condition as being at a serious level.

◇ Watershed moment for prosecution investigation... Fierce aftermath expected if rejected

There is much speculation that this arrest warrant request will effectively become an important 'decisive moment' for the prosecution's investigation.

Depending on whether it is issued, the investigation could gain momentum or effectively enter its conclusion phase.

First, if Professor Chung's warrant is rejected, the prosecution's investigative momentum will drop sharply, and calls for accountability regarding Prosecutor General Yun Seok-yeol could even be raised.

Voices claiming this investigation was ultimately excessive investigation aimed at blocking prosecution reform could gain strength, and the intensity of reform efforts could intensify further.

While prosecutors typically re-request arrest warrants through supplementary investigation when arrest warrants for major suspects are rejected, considering worsening public opinion, re-requesting a warrant for Professor Chung is analyzed as being nearly impossible.

Conversely, if the court recognizes that Professor Chung's charges have been demonstrated to some degree and issues the warrant, prosecutors can shake off some of the controversy over the legitimacy of their investigation thus far.

Prosecutors are expected to overcome criticism of excessive investigation and open a path to move one step further toward investigating former Minister Cho.

Prosecutors are investigating the possibility that former Minister Cho directly participated in issuing internship certificates from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his daughter and son, where false allegations have been raised, or intervened in the debt lawsuit process involving Ungdong Academy [a hagwon].

{
  "translated_title": "Cho Kuk's Brother: "150 Million Won for Teacher Hiring... Find Applicants" (Comprehensive 2nd Report)",
  "translated_text": "(Uiwang=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = Mr. Cho (surname withheld), the younger brother of Justice Minister Cho Kuk who is suspected of corruption related to Ungdong Educational Foundation operated by Minister Cho's family, is leaving Seoul Detention Center in Uiwang on the morning of the 9th after his arrest warrant was rejected. 2019.10.9 hama@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Gye-yeon = Prosecutors have determined that Mr. Cho (52), the younger brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk who is suspected of leading hiring corruption at Ungdong Educational Foundation, offered 150 million won [approximately $113,000 USD] as payment for hiring a teacher at Ungdong Middle School and sought out applicants.

Prosecutors captured evidence that the exam questions for teacher hiring that Mr. Cho handed to applicants after receiving bribes were prepared at Dongyang University where Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57), Minister Cho's wife, works. They plan to verify whether other family members also knew about the hiring corruption.

According to the indictment of hiring corruption brokers A and B on the 16th, brother Mr. Cho instructed his elementary school junior A in fall 2015: "We are hiring a regular full-time social studies teacher at Ungdong Middle School. Find out if there's anyone who wants to be hired as a regular teacher even if they have to pay between 100 million and 150 million won [approximately $75,000-113,000 USD]. If you bring the money, I'll give you an introduction fee."

On December 31 of the same year, A met with an applicant's parents at a hotel coffee shop in Changwon, Gyeongnam, together with B who was preparing to establish Ungdong Middle School's baseball team. They proposed: "We'll make sure you pass the hiring exam if you give us 130 million won [approximately $98,000 USD]. First, give us 30 million won [approximately $23,000 USD] as a down payment, then give us the remaining 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] when we hand over the written exam questions and answer sheet." They also conveyed plans to provide the practical exam assignments and interview questions in advance after passing the first written exam.

A and B received the 30 million won down payment in 10 million won [approximately $7,500 USD] checks four days later. On January 13 of the following year, they exchanged the written exam questions and answer sheet they received from Mr. Cho for 100 million won. This applicant, who paid a total of 130 million won, passed the written exam with a perfect score among 24 test-takers. They also received the highest score of 95.5 points among 5 candidates in the second practical and interview evaluation and were hired as a regular teacher.

The 2017 hiring corruption followed the same pattern.

A met with the father of an applicant who was working as a temporary teacher at another nearby middle school and proposed '100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD].' When the applicant's side hesitated, saying "the amount is too large," they reached an agreement after negotiations to receive 10 million won [approximately $7,500 USD] as a down payment and 70 million won [approximately $53,000 USD] as success fee. This applicant also passed the Ungdong Middle School social studies teacher appointment exam as the 'top scorer.'

(Changwon=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Dong-min = Ungdong Middle School in Jinhae-gu, Changwon, Gyeongnam on the afternoon of the 19th. This school is a private middle school owned by Ungdong Educational Foundation, which is owned by Justice Minister candidate Cho Kuk's family. 2019.8.19 image@yna.co.kr

The appointment plan secured by prosecutors states that written exams would be commissioned to Dongyang University. Also, to prevent exam question leaks, the board chairman would directly commission the written exam questions, store the questions, and deliver them to the administrative office director 1 hour before the exam starts. The practical assignments and interview questions were to be finalized through consultation between only the vice-principal and principal.

Mr. Cho reportedly told prosecutors that he secretly took exam questions from his mother Park Jung-sook's (81) house, who is the board chairman. Prosecutors plan to verify how Mr. Cho found out about practical assignments and whether other family members involved in Ungdong Educational Foundation operations, including Ms. Park and Professor Chung, were also related to the hiring corruption.

Mr. Cho is also suspected of destroying evidence and helping accomplices flee. When hiring corruption allegations were raised by media in late August, he instructed A: "Meet B and get a fact confirmation document stating that the media reports are not true." A had B write a falsely prepared fact confirmation document and even obtained a seal certificate.

After receiving this report, Mr. Cho again instructed through A: "Tell B to go to the Philippines until things quiet down," ordering overseas flight. B departed for Manila, Philippines through Gimhae International Airport that same day. Mr. Cho also handed 3.5 million won [approximately $2,600 USD] to the brokers as flight funds.

A and B kept some of the 210 million won [approximately $158,000 USD] they received from applicants as hiring payment as commission fees and delivered most of it to Mr. Cho. Prosecutors identified circumstances where Mr. Cho led the crimes through the arrested brokers and referred the two brokers to trial the previous day on charges of breach of trust, bribery, and obstruction of business.

Meanwhile, when an arrest warrant was requested for Mr. Cho, he requested postponement of interrogation on the 7th, the day before the pre-arrest suspect interrogation (warrant substantive review), claiming he needed lumbar disc surgery. When prosecutors forcibly summoned him the next day by visiting a Busan hospital where he was hospitalized, he gave up the interrogation but received a decision rejecting the arrest warrant.

Prosecutors view that custodial investigation is inevitable as Mr. Cho is the main culprit of hiring corruption who planned and instructed the crimes and took most of the bribes, and also has breach of trust charges for causing tens of billions of won [approximately $75 million-750 million USD] in damages to Ungdong Educational Foundation through false construction payment lawsuits, so they plan to request an arrest warrant again soon. Mr. Cho is known to still claim surgery is necessary while not presenting objective records to support this to prosecutors.

Liberty Korea Party lawmaker Kim Do-eup claimed that Seoul Central District Court warrant-dedicated chief judge Myeong Jae-kwon rejected the arrest warrant despite knowing about Mr. Cho's 'malingering.' He said that even after receiving medical opinions stating surgery was unnecessary and hospital closed-circuit TV analysis data supporting this from prosecutors, the judge cited 'health condition' as grounds for rejecting the arrest warrant.

Lawmaker Kim revealed that Mr. Cho freely moved the arm he complained of having muscle abnormalities and paralysis, and was even caught by medical staff smoking in his hospital room. There was reportedly a hospital visitor who said they "thought a gangster was hospitalized" after hearing him shout "F*ck, why do I have to be hospitalized in a place like this!"

  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Gye-yeon = It has been revealed that the Ungdong Academy teacher hiring exam questions that Cho (52), the younger brother of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk, leaked in exchange for bribes were created at Dongyang University where Minister Cho's wife works.

Mr. Park and another Mr. Cho, who are accused of taking some money as commission fees and delivering most of the bribes to Mr. Cho, were arrested before him. Prosecutors included circumstances of Dongyang University's involvement in teacher hiring exam questions in the indictment when they formally charged these brokers yesterday on charges including breach of trust and accepting bribes.

Mr. Cho is also accused of instructing accomplice Mr. Cho to flee to the Philippines in August when hiring corruption allegations were raised, providing escape funds. He initially denied the allegations during prosecution investigation but admitted most of the facts after the brokers were arrested and detained one after another.

Mr. Cho reportedly testified that he took exam questions from the home of his mother Park Jeong-suk (81), who is the chairwoman of Ungdong Academy, and delivered them to applicants. Prosecutors plan to directly investigate Ms. Park soon to confirm whether she was aware of the hiring corruption.

In addition to hiring corruption, Mr. Cho is also charged with filing a lawsuit against Ungdong Academy demanding construction payment and then causing damage to the school foundation by losing the case without argument (breach of trust under the Act on the Aggravated Punishment of Specific Economic Crimes). The construction payment that Goryeo City Development, the construction company Mr. Cho represented, did not receive in the 1990s was 1.6 billion won [approximately $1.2 million USD], but through two lawsuits in 2006 and 2017, it grew to over 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD] in claims due to accumulated interest.

When an arrest warrant was requested, Mr. Cho requested a postponement of questioning on the 7th, the day before his pre-arrest suspect interrogation (warrant review), claiming he needed to undergo herniated disc surgery. Prosecutors obtained a medical opinion from the attending doctor stating that Mr. Cho had not scheduled surgery and was not in a condition requiring immediate surgery, which they submitted to the warrant review court.

Mr. Cho, whose arrest warrant was rejected once due to health conditions and other reasons, continues to claim that surgery is necessary while reportedly not providing objective records to support this to prosecutors. Prosecutors plan to conduct additional investigation of Mr. Cho and then request a warrant again."

{
  "translated_title": "University 1st-2nd Year Students Still Cannot Work as Korean-English-Math Hagwon Instructors... Ministry Withdraws Regulation Amendment",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = The Ministry of Education has decided to withdraw a regulation amendment that would have allowed university 1st-2nd year students to work as instructors at hagwons teaching school subjects such as Korean, English, and math.

The Ministry of Education announced on the 14th that it decided to remove the content regarding the relaxation of hagwon instructor qualification standards from the amendment to the enforcement decree of the 'Act on the Establishment and Operation of Hagwons and Extracurricular Tutoring.'

Currently, 1st-2nd year students at 4-year general universities cannot work as hagwon instructors according to the Hagwon Act and the Higher Education Act enforcement decree.

Due to this, criticisms have been raised that university 1st-2nd year students work as instructors at college entrance exam hagwons through irregular and underground means.

In response, the Ministry of Education announced legislation last July to add 'persons who are currently enrolled as students at universities and equivalent schools, or have been enrolled' to the qualification standards for hagwon instructors stipulated in the Hagwon Act enforcement decree.

However, during the legislative announcement period, some education offices and education-related organizations such as 'Citizens' Coalition for Economic Justice in Education' [a civic group advocating against excessive hagwon education] raised concerns that a significant increase in university student hagwon instructors could expand the hagwon education market.

The Ministry of Education reported that there were also criticisms that an increase in 1st-2nd year university student instructors could lower the quality of hagwon instruction or lead to hiring based on academic prestige.

Consequently, the Ministry of Education judged that relaxing instructor qualification standards requires more social consensus and decided to remove the related content from this enforcement decree amendment.

Other amendment contents from the same regulation that were announced for legislation will proceed as planned, including provisions to establish separate refund standards for reading room usage fees distinct from hagwon tuition fees, and establishing standards for tuition refunds when hagwon operators implement quarantine measures for students with infectious diseases.

{
  "translated_title": "Education sector divided over '2025 bulk conversion of autonomous private high schools to regular high schools' (comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "On the 6th of last month, a closed-door ruling party-government-administration meeting on 'directions for university admissions system improvement' was held at a restaurant in Yeouido, Seoul, where participants including Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye discussed university admissions system improvement plans including enhancing transparency in the comprehensive school record evaluation system. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Sejong·Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Hyo-seok and Lee Jae-young = The education sector responded that the government's plan to convert autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools all at once to regular high schools in March 2025 was an "expected sequence of events." However, opinions for and against were divided by organization.

According to the Democratic Party of Korea on the 14th, the Ministry of Education discussed a plan to collectively convert autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to regular high schools in 2025 at a ruling party-government-administration consultative meeting on the 18th of last month. The Ministry of Education said it would revise the Elementary and Secondary Education Act enforcement ordinance at the end of this year or early next year for the bulk conversion.

The government is presenting the necessity of bulk conversion by citing that the high school credit system will be fully introduced in the 2025 school year. The high school credit system, where students choose and take classes they want, must be implemented together with 'absolute evaluation of high school grades' (achievement evaluation), and if absolute evaluation of school records is implemented, autonomous private high schools are likely to occupy a very advantageous position compared to regular high schools in university admissions.

Lee Man-ki, director of the Uway Education Evaluation Research Institute and a university admissions expert, explained, "To introduce the high school credit system, absolute evaluation of high school grades must be implemented," adding, "When absolute evaluation of school records is implemented, autonomous private high schools become greatly advantaged, so the credit system cannot be introduced without eliminating autonomous private high schools."

Progressive-leaning education superintendents and education organizations have consistently argued for revising laws to convert autonomous private high schools all at once to regular high schools.

Especially as major confusion arose during this year's re-designation evaluation (operational performance evaluation), voices have grown louder that bulk conversion is necessary to prevent such confusion from repeating.

Jeon Gyeong-won, director of the KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) True Education Research Institute, said, "The government has set the right direction for now," explaining, "If autonomous private high schools are not converted to regular high schools before the full introduction of the credit system, the situation would become unmanageable later."

He analyzed, "I understand that voices saying it's difficult are coming from within autonomous private high schools as applicants decrease," adding, "(The government plan) also coincides with the current trend of autonomous private high schools wanting to convert to regular high schools due to financial problems and other issues."

Ku Bon-chang, policy director of Citizens' Coalition for Economic Justice in Education, said, "The government plan is rational in that it set a 'grace period' to convert to regular high schools in 2025 after revising laws at the end of this year or early next year," adding, "I evaluate this as a plan moving toward 'upward equalization' where each regular high school operates diverse curricula through the credit system, rather than 'educational diversification' through the high school system."

On the other hand, Cho Seong-cheol, spokesperson for the Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations, pointed out, "Before converting autonomous private high schools to regular high schools, proof is needed that regular high schools can also provide diverse education suited to students' talents and aptitudes," adding, "If they had said they would convert autonomous private high schools to regular high schools after gaining trust that regular high schools can also provide diverse education, there would have been no one to oppose it."

He argued, "There are concerns from the education field that even if the credit system is implemented, it will only result in a slight increase in elective subjects because it's difficult to realize a credit system at the high school level where students choose and take all classes like in universities," adding, "It's unreasonable to eliminate schools that already operate diverse curricula when it's unclear at what level the credit system will operate (just because the credit system will be implemented)."

Spokesperson Cho added, "The high school system should not change just because the administration changes," saying, "The high school system should be designed in a direction that can provide diverse curricula to students and nurture talent suitable for the Fourth Industrial Revolution, and this should be specified in law."

The government's bulk conversion plan for autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools is expected to affect the popularity of autonomous private high schools starting from this year's high school admissions.

Lee Young-deok, director of the Daesung Academic Development Research Institute at Daesung hagwon, predicted, "The preference for not only autonomous private high schools but also foreign language high schools and international high schools, which was already declining due to reduced special talent admissions, will fall further," adding, "There's a possibility that preference for so-called 'prestigious regular high school' areas like Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] and Mok-dong will emerge again."

Director Lee Man-ki also predicted, "Would students apply to schools that are obviously going to close?" adding, "Since the Ministry of Education is also reviewing plans to abolish extracurricular areas in the comprehensive school record evaluation for university early admissions, if even curricular areas disappear, autonomous private high schools will have no advantages in university admissions, so their popularity will decline, if not by a large margin."

On the other hand, there's also a prediction that popularity will be maintained based on the fact that if autonomous private high schools are converted to regular high schools in 2025 as the Ministry of Education plans, students who entered before then are likely to maintain their autonomous private high school student status until graduation.

This view suggests that even if autonomous private high schools and foreign language high schools are converted to regular high schools, they may maintain their standing as 'prestigious regular high schools' in their respective regions due to differentiated curricula or teacher quality.

Yu Seong-ryong, director of the STUnitas Education Research Institute, pointed out, "2025 is during the next administration, and education policies have always changed later depending on the president or administration," adding, "From the perspective of current elementary and middle school parents, there's still time, but they would be concerned about whether there might be confusion later.""
}
