{
  "translated_title": "Unusual warrant dismissal due to wife and younger brother's health issues... Variable in 'Cho Kuk investigation' (Comprehensive 2nd report)",
  "translated_text": "(Uiwang=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = Mr. Cho (surname withheld), younger brother of Justice Minister Cho Kuk who is suspected of corruption related to Ungdong School Foundation operated by Minister Cho's family, leaves Seoul Detention Center in Uiwang City on the morning of the 9th after his arrest warrant was dismissed. hama@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Gye-yeon = With the dismissal of the arrest warrant for Mr. Cho (52), Justice Minister Cho Kuk's younger brother suspected of Ungdong School Foundation corruption, on the 9th, some disruption to the prosecution's investigation surrounding Minister Cho's family appears inevitable.

Analysts note that the court accepted Mr. Cho's claims of suffering from herniated disc, while dismissing the warrant with logic substantially similar to criticisms that the hiring corruption charges constitute 'separate case investigation,' creating variables in decisions regarding other suspects' custody.

◇ Prosecution: "Both fraudulent litigation and hiring corruption are core charges... not separate case investigation"

Judge Myeong Jae-kwon, warrant-dedicated chief judge at Seoul Central District Court, cited as the first reason for dismissing Mr. Cho's warrant early that morning "the existence of room for dispute regarding the establishment of the main crime (breach of trust)."

Mr. Cho's breach of trust charges involve filing a civil lawsuit demanding construction fees from a construction company he previously operated while serving as Ungdong School Foundation's administrative director, allowing the school foundation to lose without defense to secure claims.

The 1.6 billion won [approximately $1.2 million USD] construction fee from a project that Goryeo City Development, where Mr. Cho served as representative, undertook in the mid-1990s ballooned into a claim worth over 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD] through two lawsuits with added delay interest.

However, the court appears to have partially considered the counterargument from some quarters that "Ungdong School Foundation had no possibility of winning the lawsuit, and conversely, responding to the lawsuit by hiring lawyers and incurring legal fees would constitute breach of trust."

Within and outside the prosecution, there had been much speculation that the custody decision would depend on how the court viewed the hiring corruption charges of receiving around 200 million won [approximately $150,000 USD] in bribes for teacher hiring, considering the characteristic of breach of trust crimes being heavily contested for guilt even after indictment. However, Judge Myeong cited regarding the hiring corruption charges that "[Mr. Cho] is generally acknowledging the facts" as a reason for warrant dismissal.

(Changwon=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Dong-min = Ungdong Middle School in Jinhae-gu, Changwon City, Gyeongsangnam-do Province in the afternoon. This school is a private middle school owned by Ungdong School Foundation, which is owned by Justice Minister candidate Cho Kuk's family. [Yonhap News file photo]

Reactions of bewilderment emerge from within and outside the prosecution. They argue it lacks equity to not arrest Mr. Cho, the final destination of the money, when two others—another Mr. Cho and Mr. Park—who acted as brokers delivering money to him have both been arrested.

Professor Lee Choong-sang of Kyungpook National University Law School, who previously served as warrant-dedicated chief judge at Seoul Central District Court, criticized in a letter sent to acquaintances: "Today, when the arrest warrant request for Minister Cho's younger brother was dismissed, will be a day when the court itself created a blemish," adding "Based on the (hiring corruption) crime alone, there are concerns about flight, so arrest should be made, not dismissal."

The brokers also generally acknowledged the facts during prosecution investigation, and the amounts they received as commission fees were small sums under 10 million won [approximately $7,500 USD]. However, strong indications of attempts at evidence destruction including overseas flight influenced their arrests. The court stated when issuing Park's arrest warrant on the 4th that "there are concerns about flight or evidence destruction." However, it made no particular judgment on Mr. Cho's charges of instructing such evidence destruction (instructing evidence destruction).

Judge Myeong distinguished Ungdong School Foundation fraudulent litigation charges as 'main crimes' and hiring corruption charges as 'breach of trust bribery portion.' The judgment was that 'main crimes' are disputable while the 'breach of trust bribery portion' is acknowledged by Mr. Cho himself, so it's not a matter requiring custody investigation.

This is interpreted as aligning with claims that 'Mr. Cho's hiring corruption is separate case investigation.' The implication is that the prosecution, to arrest Mr. Cho temporarily, sought out hiring corruption charges not directly related to the fraudulent litigation charges that were originally the main suspected issues and included them in the warrant's criminal facts.

The prosecution maintains that hiring corruption suspicions also began investigation through the same process as other branches of investigation like private equity funds and Ungdong School Foundation, following media reports and criminal complaints based on informant tips in late August. A prosecution official stated: "Fraudulent litigation and hiring corruption are two pillars of Ungdong School Foundation-related suspicions. We view both as Mr. Cho's core charges, and criticism of separate case investigation doesn't make sense."

(Gwacheon=Yonhap News) Reporter Ahn Jeong-won = Justice Minister Cho Kuk announces prosecution reform measures at the Ministry of Justice briefing room in the Government Gwacheon Complex in Gwacheon City, Gyeonggi Province on the afternoon of the 8th. jeong@yna.co.kr

◇ Possibility of warrant request for Chung Kyung-sim also... "Health issues influence public opinion battle"

Mr. Cho is a key figure holding the key to Ungdong School Foundation-related corruption, a core investigation target alongside private equity funds and admissions fraud. During the period when hiring corruption occurred, Minister Cho's mother Park Jeong-sook (81) served as chairwoman and his wife Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57) of Dongyang University served as director. The prosecution planned to trace the whereabouts of money Mr. Cho received based on financial transaction records around him while confirming how much other family members were involved in decision-making processes.

Regarding fraudulent litigation suspicions, it's known that a legal review document from Korea Asset Management Corporation (KAMCO) regarding Ungdong School Foundation's provisional seizure was secured from Minister Cho's PC. However, with Mr. Cho's arrest warrant dismissed, the opportunity to expand the investigation network to other family members has been blocked for now.

The prosecution is likely to request Mr. Cho's arrest warrant again after reinforcing evidence supporting fraudulent litigation suspicions. However, given the plan to complete the entire investigation within this month if possible, there's room to modify strategy toward concentrating remaining investigative capacity on proving private equity fund and admissions fraud charges involving Professor Chung.

The prosecution is considering requesting an arrest warrant for Professor Chung, who has been summoned for investigation three times until the previous day, as early as this week. However, concerns have increased as considerable portions of Mr. Cho's arrest warrant dismissal reasons overlap with Professor Chung's investigation situation.

When Mr. Cho's pre-arrest suspect interrogation (warrant substantive review) date was set, he requested postponement citing herniated disc surgery. When the prosecution executed a writ of summons by visiting the hospital where he was admitted, he gave up the interrogation.

Mr. Cho's claim that he "was scheduled to receive surgery on the 8th" was also determined to be false. The prosecution confirmed this fact while considering forced summons and also informed the warrant-dedicated court. However, the court stated it "took into consideration the investigation process including multiple suspect summons investigations, the suspect's health condition, and criminal record." Mr. Cho, who had been awaiting the warrant substantive review results, left Seoul Detention Center early that morning wearing a neck brace.

The warrant dismissal is evaluated as unusual given that Mr. Cho was suspected of using 'delay tactics' by being hospitalized, and giving up warrant substantive review is typically interpreted as acknowledging charges and accepting the arrest decision. According to Supreme Court data, among 32 suspects who did not appear at warrant substantive reviews held at Seoul Central District Court from 2015-2017, there was never a case where an arrest warrant was dismissed.

Judge Myeong also stated he considered "the fact that extensive evidence collection including residential searches and seizures has already been conducted." Ms. Chung is also complaining of health problems including brain surgery aftereffects and optic nerve disorders, similar to Mr. Cho. Her Dongyang University research office, Bangbae-dong [a neighborhood in Seoul] residence, and even the workplace of an asset manager who participated in evidence destruction became targets of searches and seizures.

A lawyer in Seocho-dong [a district in Seoul] said: "The family's health problems serve as a kind of fuel for the candlelight rally public opinion battle, and Minister Cho's prosecution reform measures could influence not only the prosecution but also court judgments."

Minister Cho announced prosecution reform measures the previous day including 'restrictions on improper separate case investigations and prolonged investigations' and 'improvement of repetitive and extensive warrant requests.' Kim Young-jae, senior research fellow at the Democratic Research Institute, the think tank of the ruling Democratic Party of Korea, proposed a 'Second Judicial Reform Promotion Committee' the same day, targeting both courts and prosecution simultaneously.

The Democratic Research Institute stated in an issue briefing: "Not only is the prosecution's rampant searches and seizures a problem, but the court's rampant approval of search and seizure warrants is a more serious problem," pointing out that "despite Chief Justice Kim Myeong-soo's pledge for 'judicial reform,' [the court] has fallen to a bystander regarding reckless abuse of prosecutorial power."

{
  "translated_title": "Arrest Warrant for Cho Kuk's Brother Rejected…'Ungdong Hagwon Suspicions' Investigation Setback Inevitable (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Uiwang=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = Mr. Cho (name withheld), the younger brother of Justice Minister Cho Kuk who faces corruption allegations related to the Ungdong Hagwon educational foundation operated by Minister Cho's family, leaves Seoul Detention Center in Uiwang City on the morning of the 9th after his arrest warrant was rejected. hama@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Cho-rong = The arrest warrant for Mr. Cho (52, name withheld), the younger brother of Justice Minister Cho Kuk who faces corruption allegations related to the Ungdong Hagwon educational foundation operated by Minister Cho's family, has been rejected.

Some setback to the prosecution's investigation, which is comprehensively examining suspicions including fraudulent litigation over construction payments and hiring irregularities, appears inevitable.

Critical public opinion that the prosecution is conducting excessive investigations targeting Minister Cho's family is also expected to intensify.

Seoul Central District Court Warrant Judge Myeong Jae-kwon rejected the arrest warrant at 2:23 AM on the 9th after reviewing the necessity of Mr. Cho's detention on the 8th.

Judge Myeong cited the following reasons for rejecting the warrant: ▲ There is room for dispute regarding the main criminal charges (breach of trust) ▲ Extensive evidence collection, including searches of residences, has already been conducted ▲ He generally acknowledges the facts regarding the breach of trust and bribery portion.

While Mr. Cho acknowledges receiving back-money from applicants for teaching positions at Ungdong Hagwon (breach of trust and bribery charges), there is room for dispute regarding whether fraudulent litigation involving Ungdong Hagwon (breach of trust under the Act on the Aggravated Punishment of Specific Economic Crimes) occurred.

Judge Myeong stated, "Considering the investigation progress including multiple suspect summons and questioning, the suspect's health condition, and criminal history, it is difficult to recognize the grounds, necessity, and reasonableness of detention at this stage."

The court decided to reject Mr. Cho's arrest warrant through document review after Mr. Cho waived his pre-detention suspect interrogation (warrant substantive review).

On the 7th, one day before the detention review, Mr. Cho requested the court to postpone the review, claiming he needed to undergo disc surgery.

However, the prosecution sent a doctor-prosecutor to a Busan hospital where Mr. Cho was admitted to check his health condition, then executed an arrest warrant and brought him to Seoul. After reviewing medical opinions and meeting with Mr. Cho's attending physician, they determined there was no problem with him undergoing the detention review.

Mr. Cho's health condition also influenced the rejection of the arrest warrant.

Mr. Cho, who served as business manager of Ungdong Hagwon, is suspected of conducting fraudulent litigation regarding school construction payments and causing damage to Ungdong Hagwon.

Ungdong Hagwon commissioned construction of Ungdong Middle School in 1996, and Goryeo City Development, where Mr. Cho served as representative, participated in the construction. Later, Ungdong Hagwon claimed financial difficulties due to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) foreign exchange crisis and did not pay 1.6 billion won [approximately $1.2 million USD] in construction costs to Goryeo City Development.

Subsequently, Mr. Cho and his ex-wife Ms. Cho (name withheld) filed construction payment lawsuits against Ungdong Hagwon in 2006 and 2017, obtaining judgments ordering payment of a total of 5.2 billion won [approximately $3.9 million USD] including delayed interest.

Ungdong Hagwon abandoned its defense in both lawsuits and lost. This raised suspicions that Minister Cho's family conducted fraudulent litigation to transfer Ungdong Hagwon assets to Mr. Cho. The construction payment debt is reportedly now worth around 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD] due to accumulated interest.

Mr. Cho also faces charges (breach of trust and bribery) for receiving back-money from parents of teaching applicants at Ungdong Hagwon in exchange for hiring. The suspicion is that he received 200 million won [approximately $150,000 USD] - 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] per person - for hiring two Ungdong Middle School teachers, and the applicants who paid money were actually hired.

Two other individuals, Ms. Cho (name withheld) and Mr. Park (name withheld), who delivered back-money from teaching applicants to Mr. Cho and received service fees, have already been detained.

The court's rejection of the arrest warrant also serves as evidence that the prosecution's evidence regarding Ungdong Hagwon fraudulent litigation is not solid. The possibility that the overall Ungdong Hagwon investigation - one branch of the three major suspicions surrounding Minister Cho's family - could be shaken cannot be ruled out.

The prosecution expressed opposition to Mr. Cho's arrest warrant rejection and announced plans to reapply for the warrant.

The prosecution stated, "Given the seriousness of the charges, the degree of evidence including acknowledging core charges and even waiving warrant interrogation, the fact that two accomplices have already been detained, and extensive evidence destruction, the arrest warrant rejection is a difficult decision to accept," adding "We plan to consider reapplying for an arrest warrant."

The detention decision is expected to come out late tonight.

Judge Myeong had originally scheduled Mr. Cho's substantive warrant review for 10:30 AM today. However, the schedule was delayed when Mr. Cho filed an application to change the interrogation date the previous day, claiming he needed to undergo herniated disc surgery.

Prosecutors sent investigative personnel, including a prosecutor with medical background, to the hospital where Mr. Cho was admitted to check his health condition before executing the summons warrant. With accumulated late interest, the current construction payment claim is known to be around 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD].

Mr. Cho is also suspected of taking approximately 200 million won [approximately $150,000 USD] in bribes, 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] from each of two applicants, in exchange for teacher hiring at Ungdong School Foundation.

Prosecutors have detained another Mr. Cho and Mr. Park on charges of receiving money from applicants, keeping some as commission fees, and passing the rest to Mr. Cho (breach of trust bribery, etc.), and are investigating the specific details of the crimes.

Mr. Cho is expected to undergo warrant substantive review at Seoul Central District Court sometime today.
The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) executed Mr. Cho's arrest warrant around 9 AM today at a hospital in Busan where he was hospitalized and is currently transporting him to Seoul Central District Court in Seocho-dong, Seoul.
Mr. Cho, for whom a detention warrant was requested, submitted a request to the court through his attorney the day before the warrant substantive review to change the interrogation date. The gist was to request postponement of the warrant substantive review because he needed to undergo herniated disc surgery that morning.
Prosecutors sent investigative personnel, including a prosecutor with medical background, to the hospital where Mr. Cho was admitted to check his health condition before executing his arrest warrant. A prosecution official said, "After receiving a medical opinion and interviewing the attending physician, we determined there would be absolutely no problem with the warrant substantive review. He also agreed to undergo the warrant substantive review."
Mr. Cho's warrant substantive review, originally scheduled for 10:30 AM today, is expected to be somewhat delayed. The court plans to interrogate him as soon as he arrives to determine the necessity of detention. The warrant substantive review will be handled by Chief Judge Myeong Jae-kwon, who specializes in warrants.
Prosecutors requested a detention warrant for Mr. Cho on the 4th, applying charges of breach of trust and breach of trust with bribery under the Act on the Aggravated Punishment of Specific Economic Crimes, and instruction to destroy evidence.
Mr. Cho is suspected of causing damage to Ungdong Academy [a private school foundation] by conducting fraudulent litigation related to school construction payments.
Ungdong Academy commissioned new construction of Ungdong Middle School in 1996, and Korea City Development, where Mr. Cho served as representative, participated in the construction. Mr. Cho filed lawsuits against Ungdong Academy in 2006 and 2017 demanding 1.6 billion won [approximately $1.2 million USD] in construction payments and received judgments ordering payment of 5.2 billion won [approximately $3.9 million USD].
Ungdong Academy, operated by Minister Cho's family, lost the lawsuit without mounting a defense, and Mr. Cho was the secretary-general at the time of the first lawsuit. Suspicions have been raised that Minister Cho's family conducted fraudulent litigation to transfer Ungdong Academy assets to Mr. Cho. With accumulated interest, the current construction payment claim is known to be worth around 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD].
Mr. Cho is also suspected of receiving bribes totaling around 200 million won [approximately $150,000 USD], taking 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] each from two applicants in exchange for hiring them as teachers at Ungdong Academy.
Prosecutors have detained another Mr. Cho and Mr. Park on charges of receiving money from applicants, keeping some as commission fees, and passing the rest to Mr. Cho (breach of trust with bribery, etc.), and are pursuing the specific details of the criminal acts.

  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

Mr. Cho, who has served as the administrative director of Ungdong School Foundation, is suspected of breach of trust for filing false lawsuits related to school construction payments, causing damage to Ungdong School Foundation.

Subsequently, Mr. Cho and his ex-wife Ms. Cho filed lawsuits against Ungdong School Foundation in 2006 and 2017 demanding payment of construction fees, obtaining judgments for a total of 5.2 billion won [approximately $3.9 million USD] including late interest. At the time of the first lawsuit, Mr. Cho was the administrative director of Ungdong School Foundation. He filed a lawsuit against the school foundation where he was working.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = Justice Minister Cho Kuk is getting into his car after leaving his home in Seocho-dong on the morning of the 4th for work. 2019.10.4 hama@yna.co.kr

Ungdong School Foundation gave up defending in both lawsuits and lost. This raised suspicions that Minister Cho's family filed false lawsuits to transfer Ungdong School Foundation assets to Mr. Cho. With accumulated late interest, the current construction payment claim is known to amount to around 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD].

Ungdong School Foundation is a school foundation in the Gyeongnam region where Minister Cho's mother, Park Jung-sook, currently serves as chairwoman, following his late father, Cho Byeon-hyeon.

Mr. Cho is also suspected of receiving bribes from parents of school teacher applicants in exchange for hiring.

Allegations have been raised that Mr. Cho received 200 million won [approximately $150,000 USD], 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] per person, as payment for hiring at Ungdong Middle School, and that the teacher applicants who paid the money were actually hired.

Ms. Cho and Mr. Park, who delivered the bribes received from teacher applicants to Mr. Cho and received service fees, have already been detained.

Prosecutors have also applied charges of instructing destruction of evidence after identifying circumstances where Mr. Cho instructed those involved in the hiring corruption to destroy related materials and to go abroad and return.

The decision on whether to detain Mr. Cho is expected to be made as early as late on the evening of the 8th.

  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Im Su-jung and Park Cho-rong = Prosecutors have requested an arrest warrant for Mr. Cho (54), the brother of Justice Minister Cho Kuk, in connection with corruption at Woongdong Academy, a school foundation that has been operated by Minister Cho's family.

Following yesterday's summoning and questioning of Minister Cho's wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim of Dongyang University, investigators appear to be gradually tightening their investigative net around the family.

If the court issues the arrest warrant, this would be the first arrest case among Minister Cho's close family members. Minister Cho's fifth cousin, a key figure in the private equity fund allegations, was indicted and detained yesterday on charges including embezzlement and stock manipulation worth 7 billion won [approximately $5.3 million USD].

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Division 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyung-gon) announced on the 4th that it had requested an arrest warrant for Mr. Cho on charges of breach of trust, breach of trust with acceptance of bribes, and instructing destruction of evidence under the Act on the Aggravated Punishment of Specific Economic Crimes.

Mr. Cho is suspected of securing construction payment claims from Woongdong Academy based on fraudulent construction work and engaging in sham litigation with school foundation officials.

Woongdong Academy is a school foundation in the Gyeongnam [South Gyeongsang Province] region where Minister Cho's mother, Park Jung-suk, currently serves as chairwoman, following his late father, Cho Byeon-hyeon.

Mr. Cho and his wife won construction payment claim lawsuits against Woongdong Academy twice, in 2006 and 2017, and hold claims worth 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD].

Woongdong Academy responded to the lawsuits without presenting arguments and lost, raising suspicions that Minister Cho's family may have attempted to siphon off private school assets through 'fraudulent litigation' among family members.

The litigation originated from Woongdong Academy's failure to pay 1.6 billion won [approximately $1.2 million USD] in construction costs to Goryeo City Development, where Mr. Cho served as representative, for school relocation construction performed in the mid-1990s. With accumulated interest, the construction payment claims have now grown to approximately 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD].

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = Justice Minister Cho Kuk gets into his car after leaving his residence in Seocho-dong on the morning of the 4th to go to work. 2019.10.4 hama@yna.co.kr

After winning the 2006 lawsuit, Mr. Cho transferred the claims to his wife and divorced in 2009. Prosecutors suspect that Mr. Cho staged a fake divorce to avoid transferring the claims to the Korea Technology Credit Guarantee Fund.

At the time of the lawsuit, Mr. Cho held the position of administrative director at Woongdong Academy and has continued to serve as the school foundation's administrative director. Minister Cho was a board member of Woongdong Academy in 2006.

Mr. Cho is also suspected of receiving hundreds of millions of won [approximately $150,000-750,000 USD] from parents of Woongdong Academy teacher employment applicants as payment for hiring.

Prosecutors launched an investigation after allegations arose that a Busan-area sports industry figure received 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] each from two parents of Woongdong Academy teacher employment applicants and delivered the money to Minister Cho's brother.

Another Mr. Cho, who delivered bribes related to the hiring corruption, was arrested on the 1st, and his accomplice Mr. Park underwent an arrest review today.

Prosecutors identified circumstances suggesting that Minister Cho's brother Mr. Cho attempted to destroy evidence in connection with the Woongdong Academy fraudulent construction payment lawsuit allegations and hiring corruption case, and included charges of instructing destruction of evidence in the arrest warrant.

{
  "translated_title": "Prosecutors investigate Cho Kuk's wife following daughter and son... 'Deliberating' first summons of sitting minister (comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jung-hoon = Justice Minister Cho Kuk leaves his home in Bangbae-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul on the morning of the 2nd to go to work. 2019.10.2 uwg806@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Cho-rong = Prosecutors investigating allegations related to Justice Minister Cho Kuk's family summoned Cho's wife, Dongyang University Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57), on the 3rd, meaning most of Cho's family members implicated in the allegations have now appeared before prosecutors for questioning.
The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) summoned Professor Chung at 9 a.m. that day and questioned her for 8 hours. Prosecutors plan to summon Professor Chung again.
As the prosecution investigation is effectively targeting Minister Cho and his wife, there is speculation that depending on the results of Professor Chung's questioning, direct summons and investigation of Minister Cho could take place.
Attention is focused on whether the unprecedented situation of a sitting Justice Minister sitting in a prosecutor's interrogation room will unfold.
Professor Chung's summons came 37 days after prosecutors launched a forced investigation on August 27, conducting massive raids and searches related to allegations about the Cho family's private equity fund investments, children's college admissions, and Woongdong Hagwon [a private academy] debt litigation.
Minister Cho has maintained that he was not involved in major family-related allegations that have been raised, explaining that he didn't properly know about private equity investment destinations because Professor Chung handled the family's asset management.
However, prosecutors are investigating with the possibility open that Minister Cho was directly involved in issuing internship certificates from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his daughter and son, where false allegations have been raised, or that he was involved in the Woongdong Hagwon debt litigation process.
(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Yoon Dong-jin = Reporters wait in front of the entrance of Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office in Seocho-gu on the morning of the 2nd. Professor Chung Kyung-sim of Dongyang University, wife of Justice Minister Cho Kuk, was reported to appear before prosecutors this week. 2019.10.2 mon@yna.co.kr

The area where allegations of Minister Cho's involvement are most prominent is the issuance of internship certificates from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his children. This is because Minister Cho, who was serving as a Seoul National University law professor at the time, was affiliated with the Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center.
It was reported that the hard disk of Minister Cho's home computer, which prosecutors secured, contained Seoul National University internship documents for Minister Cho's daughter, the son of Dankook University Professor Jang Young-pyo who listed the daughter as first author on a medical paper, and Mr. A, who was a high school student at the time, stored as word processor files without the center director's official seal stamped on them. Mr. A's father is known to be Minister Cho's classmate from Seoul National University law school.
Minister Cho has stated, 'Reports that I created Seoul National University internship-related documents are truly malicious,' and 'I have never requested the issuance of (internship certificates) and never created them myself or forged or stamped official seals.'
Minister Cho's daughter also denied in a media interview that day, saying 'Allegations that I did intern activities at home or that my father self-issued certificates are not true.' She said she formally interned at Seoul National University and received certificates.
Minister Cho, who later learned of his daughter's internship, said 'Since you're a science student, why are you doing an internship here? Don't go there and act like you know people,' according to what Ms. Cho revealed.
(Yeongju=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Hyun-tae = With prosecutors having indicted Professor Chung Kyung-sim, wife of Justice Minister candidate Cho Kuk, on charges of forging private documents, Professor Chung's faculty research office at Dongyang University in Yeongju, North Gyeongsang Province, is closed on the 8th. 2019.9.8 mtkht@yna.co.kr

Allegations have also been raised that Minister Cho knew about and aided Professor Chung when she replaced PC hard disks at her home and Dongyang University research office immediately after the prosecution's first raid and search. Prosecutors are considering charges of aiding and abetting destruction of evidence regarding Professor Chung's hard disk replacement and removal.
When replacing her PC hard disk, Professor Chung received help from Kim, a private banker (PB) at Korea Investment & Securities who had been managing the family's assets.
Prosecutors have secured testimony that when PB Kim replaced the PC hard drive at Minister Cho's Bangbae-dong home on August 28, the day after the first raid and search of Seoul National University and Korea University, Minister Cho was in his study and told Kim 'Thank you for helping my wife.'
It is known that Professor Chung had a phone conversation with Minister Cho when she went down to Yeongju, North Gyeongsang Province, to replace her Dongyang University research office PC hard drive three days after replacing her home PC hard disk.
Allegations have also emerged of 'organized destruction of evidence' including PC replacement after Professor Chung, her lawyer, her younger brother Mr. Chung, and securities company employee Kim held a meeting.
Regarding this, Professor Chung's lawyer said, 'There was absolutely no discussion related to destruction of evidence,' and 'I only learned about the replacement of Minister Cho's home PC hard disk from media reports.' He continued, 'The Dongyang University research office PC was immediately voluntarily submitted upon receiving contact from prosecutors.'
Even if there are circumstances suggesting Minister Cho was involved in various allegations, if prosecutors summon Minister Cho without clear evidence while he is driving forward prosecution reform, there could be strong backlash. From this perspective, prosecutors are also expected to repeatedly deliberate over summoning Minister Cho while observing the results of Professor Chung's investigation.
When asked during a government audit at the National Assembly on the 26th of last month whether he would resign from his ministerial position if summoned by prosecutors, Minister Cho said, 'If a summons notice comes to me, I will think about it.'
Earlier, prosecutors summoned Minister Cho's daughter (28) twice for questioning on the 16th and 22nd of last month regarding allegations including being listed as first author on a medical paper during high school and false internship allegations at Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center. His son (23) was investigated on the 24th of last month.
Regarding Woongdong Hagwon's 'false debt litigation' and allegations of receiving bribes from parents wanting teacher employment, Minister Cho's younger brother Mr. Cho (52) and his ex-wife have been summoned for investigation.
Cho Beom-dong (36), Minister Cho's fifth cousin identified as the actual representative of Colink Private Equity, the private fund management company the Cho family invested in, went abroad in what appeared to be an escape attempt but was arrested immediately upon returning to the country on the 14th of last month. He is currently under investigation while in custody.

  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jung-hoon = Justice Minister Cho Kuk leaves his home in Bangbae-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul on the morning of the 2nd to go to work. 2019.10.2 uwg806@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Cho-rong = Prosecutors investigating allegations related to Justice Minister Cho Kuk's family summoned Cho's wife, Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57) of Dongyang University, on the 3rd, meaning most of Cho's family members implicated in the allegations have now appeared before prosecutors for investigation.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Unit 2 (headed by Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyung-gon) summoned Professor Chung at 9 a.m. on this day.

As the prosecution investigation is effectively targeting Minister Cho and his wife, some observers suggest that depending on the results of Professor Chung's investigation, a direct summons investigation of Minister Cho could be conducted.

Attention is focused on whether an unprecedented situation will unfold where a sitting Justice Minister sits in a prosecutor's interrogation room.

Professor Chung's summons came 37 days after prosecutors launched forced investigations on August 27, conducting large-scale raids and searches related to allegations involving the Cho family's private equity fund investments, children's college admissions, and Woongdong Academy debt litigation.

Minister Cho has maintained his position that he was not involved in major family-related allegations, explaining that Professor Chung handled the family's asset management and he did not properly know the private equity fund investments.

However, prosecutors are keeping open the possibility that Minister Cho was directly involved in issuing internship certificates from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his daughter and son, where false allegations have been raised, or that he was involved in the Woongdong Academy debt litigation process.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Yoon Dong-jin = Reporters wait in front of the entrance of the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office in Seocho-gu on the morning of the 2nd. Professor Chung Kyung-sim of Dongyang University, wife of Justice Minister Cho Kuk, is known to appear before prosecutors this week. 2019.10.2 mon@yna.co.kr

The area where Minister Cho's involvement allegations are most prominent is the issuance of internship certificates from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center for his children. This is because Minister Cho was affiliated with the Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center while serving as a Seoul National University Law School professor at the time.

It has been reported that internship documents for Minister Cho's daughter, the son of Dankook University Professor Jang Young-pyo who listed the daughter as first author on a medical paper, and Mr. A, who was a high school student at the time, were stored on the hard disk of Minister Cho's home computer as word processor files without the center director's official seal. Mr. A's father is known to be Minister Cho's classmate from Seoul National University Law School.

Minister Cho has stated, "Reports that I created Seoul National University internship-related documents are truly malicious," and "I have never requested issuance of (internship certificates) and have never created them myself or forged or stamped official seals."

Minister Cho's daughter also denied in a media interview on this day, saying "Allegations that I did intern activities at home or that my father self-issued certificates are not true." She said she formally interned at Seoul National University and received certificates.

Minister Cho, who later learned of his daughter's internship, said according to Ms. Cho, "You're a science student, why are you interning here? Don't go there and act like you know people."

(Yeongju=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Hyun-tae = As prosecutors indicted Professor Chung Kyung-sim, wife of Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk, on charges of document forgery, Professor Chung's research office at Dongyang University in Yeongju, North Gyeongsang Province, is closed on the 8th. 2019.9.8 mtkht@yna.co.kr

Allegations have also been raised that Minister Cho knew about and aided Professor Chung when she replaced PC hard disks at her home and Dongyang University research office immediately after prosecutors' first raid and search. Prosecutors are considering charges of aiding and abetting evidence destruction regarding Professor Chung's hard disk replacement and removal.

When replacing her PC hard disk, Professor Chung received help from Kim, a private banker (PB) at Korea Investment & Securities who had been managing the family's assets.

Prosecutors have secured testimony that when PB Kim replaced the PC hard disk at Minister Cho's Bangbae-dong home on August 28, the day after the first raid and search of Seoul National University and Korea University, Minister Cho was in his study and told Kim, "Thank you for helping my wife."

It is known that Professor Chung made a phone call with Minister Cho while going down to Yeongju, North Gyeongsang Province, to replace her Dongyang University research office PC hard disk three days after replacing her home PC hard disk.

However, if prosecutors summon Minister Cho without clear evidence of involvement while he is driving forward with prosecution reform, fierce backlash could follow. In this regard, prosecutors are also expected to deliberate repeatedly over summoning Minister Cho while observing the results of Professor Chung's investigation.

When asked during a National Assembly government questioning session on the 26th of last month whether he would resign from his ministerial position if summoned by prosecutors, Minister Cho said, "If a summons notice comes to me, I will think about it."

Prosecutors previously summoned and investigated Minister Cho's daughter (28) twice on the 16th and 22nd of last month regarding allegations including her listing as first author on a medical paper during high school and false internship allegations at Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center. His son (23) was investigated on the 24th of last month.

Regarding allegations of 'false debt litigation' at Woongdong Academy and receiving bribes from parents wanting teacher employment, Minister Cho's younger brother Mr. Cho (52) and his ex-wife were summoned for investigation.

Cho Beom-dong (36), Minister Cho's second cousin identified as the actual representative of Colink Private Equity, the private equity fund management company in which the Cho family invested, attempted to flee overseas but was arrested upon his return on the 14th of last month. He is currently being investigated while in custody.

{
  "translated_title": "Jung Kyung-sim summoned after 37 days of forced investigation... disposition decision becomes 'watershed'",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lim Su-jung = As prosecutors suddenly summoned Jung Kyung-sim (57), a professor at Dongyang University and wife of Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54), on the 3rd, the investigation into suspicions regarding Minister Cho's family appears to be reaching its climax.

This is the first time in constitutional history that the wife of a sitting Justice Minister has appeared at the prosecutor's office for questioning.

Prosecutors are expected to decide on Jung's disposition, including whether to seek an arrest warrant, after completing their investigation.

Whether Professor Jung is arrested is expected to become the 'watershed' of the investigation. Whether prosecutors seek an arrest warrant and whether the court issues one is expected to have major repercussions on the political situation.

◇ Closed-door summons under tight security

Professor Jung appeared at the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office in Seocho-dong around 9 AM under thorough security.

Prosecutors had initially announced they would have Professor Jung "appear through the first-floor entrance of the building according to principle," leading to expectations of a public summons.

However, prosecutors suddenly reversed this policy the previous day and conducted a closed-door summons. Many analysts believe this was influenced by repeated warnings from the Blue House [Korea's presidential office] and the ruling party, as well as large-scale candlelight vigils.

Professor Jung's summons came 37 days after prosecutors began full-scale forced investigation on August 27, conducting massive search and seizure operations related to suspicions about Minister Cho's family regarding private equity funds, his daughter's fraudulent university admission, and Woong-dong Academy [a hagwon].

As Professor Jung is at the center of various suspicions, prosecutors were expected to summon her since last month, but the timing was delayed longer than initially anticipated.

While prosecutors cited Professor Jung's health condition as the ostensible reason, it's known that there was a 'tug-of-war' with her legal counsel over the advantages and disadvantages of the summons timing.

For prosecutors as well, considering the practical difficulties of repeatedly summoning the wife of a sitting Justice Minister, they reportedly summoned her today after solidifying the facts they would confront Professor Jung with through peripheral investigations.

◇ More than 5 potential charges mentioned... Issues include 'co-conspiracy with 5th cousin nephew' and 'Public Officials Ethics Act'

While prosecutors chose a closed-door summons method to prevent unnecessary controversy such as 'disgrace investigation,' they are not expected to moderate the level and intensity of questioning Professor Jung.

Prosecutors are expected to conduct intensive 'compressed investigation' based on evidence gathered through continuous summoning of related persons and five rounds of massive search and seizure operations.

Observations from within and outside legal circles suggest that Professor Jung could face more than five charges.

First, Professor Jung has already been indicted for forging a commendation letter from the Dongyang University president (document forgery) to help her daughter Cho (28) gain admission to Pusan National University School of Medicine and other institutions.

Prosecutors are also examining additional charges such as using the forged commendation letter in multiple domestic medical school admissions (uttering forged documents) and obstructing universities' admission processes (obstruction of official duties/business obstruction).

Regarding private equity fund suspicions, Professor Jung is suspected of holding stocks under borrowed names in Colink Private Equity (PE), a private fund management company where Minister Cho's 5th cousin nephew Cho Beom-dong (36, arrested) is identified as the real owner, and of intervening in investee company management.

Charges could include violations of the Capital Markets Act, which requires separation of fund management and investment, and violations of the Public Officials Ethics Act, which prohibits direct investment by public officials and their spouses.

Prosecutors suspect that Professor Jung received 1 billion won [approximately $750,000 USD] out of the 1.3 billion won [approximately $975,000 USD] that Cho allegedly embezzled from investee company WFM in August last year. This means they are examining the possibility that Professor Jung was an accomplice to 'embezzlement.' The nature of the 14 million won [approximately $10,500 USD] she received monthly at 2 million won [approximately $1,500 USD] per month under the name of consulting fees from WFM is also a point of investigation.

Prosecutors are expected to decide whether to include Professor Jung's conspiracy relationship in the indictment when they indict Cho, whose detention period expires today.

Professor Jung is also charged with instructing a securities company employee who managed her assets to replace her home computer hard disk and remove an entire computer from her Dongyang University office (instructing destruction of evidence).

Given the numerous types and contents of charges, prosecutors are also considering calling Professor Jung for questioning at least once more.

◇ Weight on prosecutors' plan to seek Jung warrant... Cautious voices also raised

Analysis suggests that prosecutors will seek an arrest warrant after questioning Professor Jung.

Given that prosecutors view Professor Jung as central to various suspicions and have conducted massive investigations while confronting the Blue House and ruling party, it would be realistically difficult to choose non-detention indictment.

Under these circumstances, the result of Professor Jung's disposition is observed to become the 'watershed' of this investigation. It is also expected to cause major repercussions for the political situation, including Minister Cho's fate.

For this reason, attention focuses on whether prosecutors will seek a warrant and the court's judgment. If the court, which is not directly related to controversies surrounding the Cho family investigation, recognizes grounds for Professor Jung's arrest and issues a warrant, prosecutors are expected to significantly reduce their burden regarding criticism related to 'forced investigation.'

Conversely, cautious voices are reportedly being raised given that if the warrant is rejected, prosecutors are likely to face unbearable backlash.

If the warrant is rejected, this investigation will inevitably face criticism as excessive investigation aimed at 'blocking prosecutorial reform.' Calls for accountability regarding Prosecutor General Yoon Seok-youl are expected to intensify, with questions about his fate likely to arise.

Prosecutors are also contemplating directly summoning Minister Cho to investigate whether he was involved in various suspicions as soon as they complete their investigation of Professor Jung.

However, as prolonged investigation could intensify political controversy and factional confrontation while reducing investigative momentum, there are predictions that prosecutors will conclude their investigation within this month.

{
  "translated_title": "Seoul's Ilkwang Academy Accused of Unjustly Disciplining Staff Who Reported 'Misconduct' as Whistleblowers (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = Parents of Seoul's Uchon Elementary School are holding an 'Ilkwang Academy Corruption Eradication Rally' in front of the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education in Jongno-gu on the 2nd. 2019.10.2

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = Allegations have been raised that Ilkwang Academy, established by Ilkwang Group Chairman Lee Kyu-tae, unjustly disciplined staff at Seoul's Uchon Elementary School who reported the academy's 'misconduct' to the education office and media.

Uchon Elementary parents held an 'Ilkwang Academy Corruption Eradication Rally' in front of the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education in Jongno-gu, Seoul on the 2nd, protesting Ilkwang Academy's disciplining of 6 staff members including the principal. A considerable number of parents are also refusing to pay second semester tuition fees.

Parents demanded that the education office dismiss Ilkwang Academy board members (cancel executive appointment approvals) and dispatch interim board members.

The education office conducted an audit in May after receiving a complaint that Ilkwang Academy was trying to force Uchon Elementary's science lab coordinator to perform other duties against their will. When reports were received during the audit that the academy was trying to pursue a 'Smart School Environment Construction Project' worth approximately 2.4 billion won [approximately $1.8 million USD] despite the school's opposition, the education office conducted a total of 4 audits from May to August.

The audit results revealed circumstances showing that Ilkwang Academy improperly interfered in Uchon Elementary's academic operations through pursuing the Smart School project. In particular, the education office explained that circumstances emerged showing the academy selected a specific company as the Smart School project contractor despite procedural flaws serious enough to significantly violate public interest and fairness.

The education office also views the Smart School project cost of nearly 2.4 billion won [approximately $1.8 million USD] as excessive.

For example, Uchon Elementary allocated 150 million won [approximately $113,000 USD] for developing 3 volumes of English learning materials as part of the Smart School project, which is deemed unnecessary spending considering that many English textbooks already exist in the market.

The education office plans to soon request a police investigation into the process of pursuing Uchon Elementary's Smart School project.

After the education office audit, Ilkwang Academy imposed dismissal or suspension disciplinary actions on 6 staff members including Uchon Elementary's principal. The education office stated that the disciplined staff were whistleblowers who reported on the Smart School project, demanded the academy cancel the disciplinary actions, and also launched a special audit.

Uchon Elementary parents argue that Ilkwang Academy pursued the Smart School project using tuition fees paid by parents without explaining the project details or obtaining consent.

They also raise suspicions that the staff were disciplined because they reported problems with the Smart School project to the education office and media.

Chairman Lee Kyu-tae was indicted in 2009 on charges of inflating delivery prices to secure profits when the Air Force introduced electronic warfare training equipment, but was acquitted by the Supreme Court last year.

However, he was found guilty of bribery, tax evasion, and embezzling funds and educational expenses from Ilkwang Gongyeong, affiliates, and Uchon Elementary, receiving a sentence of 3 years and 10 months imprisonment plus a fine of 1.4 billion won [approximately $1 million USD] and served time.

Chairman Lee Kyu-tae stepped down as Ilkwang Academy board chairman in 2009, and his son currently serves as board chairman.

Ilkwang Academy sent a statement to media that afternoon, arguing that existing media reports were 'false facts,' stating that 'the contracting party for the Smart School project was the school principal, who also received advice from the school management committee and reported to the parent assembly.'

Regarding the unjust disciplinary allegations, they claimed that 'in the case of the principal, he illegally hired 30 people by deceiving even the education office without reporting to the corporation, despite having no authority to hire staff,' and that 'the academic affairs director and others committed wrongs by allowing reporters to enter the school during class time to help the principal and others, and by inciting parents as if the media reports were factual.'

The academy stated, 'If illegal acts continue that disrupt academic administration through rallies and tuition payment refusals, we will file complaints and accusations against the ringleaders with judicial authorities.'

{
  "translated_title": "Both High Schools and Universities Express 'Concerns' Over Holistic Admissions Investigation and Review of Extracurricular Abolition",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Choi Jae-gu = Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye gives remarks while attending a meeting of the Education Trust Recovery Task Force held at the Educational Facilities Disaster Mutual Aid Association in Yeouido, Seoul on the 26th. 2019.9.26 jjaeck9@yna.co.kr

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = Voices of concern are emerging from universities and high school sites regarding the Ministry of Education's decision to conduct investigations into the holistic admissions system (hakjong) and consider abolishing extracurricular components of holistic admissions to strengthen fairness in university entrance systems.

Universities are showing resistance to the Ministry of Education's announcement that it will investigate the holistic admissions processes of 13 universities that have high holistic admission ratios and admit many graduates from special purpose high schools and autonomous private high schools.

An admissions office official at University A, which is included in the investigation, expressed frustration, saying, "Early admissions have begun and we need to announce first-round document screening results by mid-October, so we were already working overtime every day, but now it seems our work will be paralyzed."

An official at University B criticized, saying, "They call it an investigation, but from the university's perspective, it's no different from an audit," and "Holistic admissions is a qualitative evaluation where admissions officers make professional judgments, so if they say there are problems with that, I question whether the evidence will be objective."

A Korean Council for University Education official said, "While holistic admissions is a system for excellent universities to select talent that fits their schools, from the perspective of mid-to-lower tier universities, it also has the effect of securing students first," adding, "We're concerned that this unprecedented holistic admissions audit (investigation) might shrink this year's early admissions."

However, one university official offered a different perspective, saying, "In the United States, admissions officers are professionals who select talent with high expertise, but in our country, the reality is that professors lead actual interviews while admissions officers help with high school data research and organizing admissions documents," and "I hope this opportunity will help correct the admissions officer system."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Ha Sa-heon = Democratic Party leader Lee Hae-chan and Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye attend a joint meeting between the Democratic Party's Special Committee on Educational Fairness Enhancement and the Ministry of Education held at the National Assembly on the morning of the 26th. 2019.9.26 toadboy@yna.co.kr

Among high school teachers, concerns emerged regarding the Ministry of Education's indication the previous day of the possibility of partially or completely abolishing extracurricular areas of student records.

A high school teacher in Seoul expressed concern, saying, "If extracurriculars are abolished from student records, holistic admissions would essentially become academic record-based admissions focused on school records [GPA], which means students would give up on top-tier universities even if they just fail their first-year, first-semester midterm exams," and "Students would be driven into infinite competition over school records [GPA] and hagwon dependency would increase, devastating high school sites."

Another teacher argued, "Even if extracurriculars are abolished, they say holistic admissions would still be possible through 'detailed achievement records' (seteuk) that teachers write, but performance assessments and discussion classes are important for seteuk," and "The reality is that performance assessments get help from parents or hagwons, and discussion is also advantageous for children who have been trained through hagwon education from a young age, so whatever is changed in student records, other side effects will emerge."

A Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations official criticized, saying, "Last year we even conducted a policy deliberation system to create a plan that would maintain the meaning of holistic admissions starting from the 2022 academic year, but they're shaking up the system without even trying it once," and "This will only add to confusion at education sites."

Jeon Gyeong-won, director of the True Education Research Institute at the Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union (KTU, a left-leaning teachers' organization), also pointed out that "if all extracurriculars such as 'jadongbongjin' (autonomous activities, club activities, volunteer activities, career activities) are abolished, the original purpose of introducing holistic admissions would be undermined."

Director Jeon stated, "For example, volunteer activities are criticized for having qualitative differences according to social class, but if we abolish them entirely, we give up the educational value of gaining awareness about living together through service," and "Rather than unconditionally abolishing them, we should present alternatives for a fair system, such as changing to a pass/fail system."

[Produced by Jang Hyun-kyung] Illustration

Concerns are also raised that the investigation will proceed hastily considering the vast amount of data, given that the Ministry of Education plans to complete investigations not only of the 13 universities' holistic admissions but also of overall university entrance processes by the end of October.

The Ministry of Education explained, "We will receive all admissions data from the past four years, but we're receiving secondary data such as acceptance rates by high school and region."

While this investigation began due to growing public anger over a privileged few using connections to enter universities, some point out that it is not actually investigating whether there are cases of privileged children gaining fraudulent admission.

When reporters asked the previous day whether they would examine individual applicant data to confirm privileged class corruption, Vice Education Minister Park Baek-beom denied this, saying, "Admissions data doesn't include parental occupations," and "We can't tell if they're children of high-ranking officials, National Assembly members, or wealthy people."

One education sector official commented, "The root cause of university admission problems lies in the social structure where universities are hierarchically ranked and quality jobs are limited to certain sectors like large corporations, public enterprises, and civil service," and "Trying to solve this by slightly fixing student records and early admission systems is like trying to cure cancer with stomach medicine."

{
  "translated_title": "Prosecutors Conduct First Forced Investigation of Justice Minister…Raid Home and 4 Universities Children Applied To (Comprehensive 3rd Report)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Han Jong-chan = On the afternoon of the 23rd, prosecution officials are leaving after completing a raid and search of Justice Minister Cho Kuk's home in Bangbae-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul. 2019.9.23 saba@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Gye-yeon = Prosecutors investigating allegations related to Justice Minister Cho Kuk (54) conducted a raid and search of Minister Cho's home on the 23rd.

This is the first time prosecutors have conducted a forced investigation targeting the residences of Minister Cho, his wife, and children since launching the investigation into Cho's associates at the end of last month. It is also unprecedented for the current head of the Ministry of Justice—which has administrative authority over prosecutors and holds investigative command authority over the Prosecutor General—to be subjected to a raid and search by prosecutors.

The specific targets, scope, suspects, and related charges of this home raid have not been confirmed. However, legal circles analyze that Minister Cho has effectively entered the prosecution's investigation network as a suspect. They suggest prosecutors have begun direct investigation into Minister Cho's own criminal charges, including suspected violations of the Public Service Ethics Act related to private equity fund allegations, suspected false issuance of an internship certificate for his daughter Cho (28) at Seoul National University Law School, and suspected aiding in evidence destruction surrounding PC hard drive replacement.

Prosecutors have so far conducted raids and searches of residences including that of Minister Cho's brother-in-law Jeong (56), who is implicated in private equity fund allegations, and the former wife of his brother, who is suspected of debt evasion and fraudulent real estate transactions at Woongdong Academy [a hagwon]. However, they had excluded Minister Cho's residence from targets, considering circumstances such as confirmation hearing preparations and his ministerial appointment.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Division 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) conducted a raid and search of Minister Cho's home in Bangbae-dong, Seoul, from around 9 AM, securing PC hard drives and work-related records.

Investigators waited in the apartment parking lot and began the raid and search after presenting a warrant around 8:40 AM, after Minister Cho left for work. His wife, Professor Jeong Kyeong-sim (57) of Dongyang University, and daughter reportedly remained at home and observed the search.

The raid and search, involving 6-7 investigators, continued for nearly 11 hours until around 7:50 PM. The area around the home was bustling with reporters, nearby residents, and even YouTubers. Minister Cho, who left the Gwacheon Government Complex around 6:30 PM, did not return home until the investigators had withdrawn.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = Justice Minister Cho Kuk is leaving his home in Bangbae-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul on the morning of the 23rd. 2019.9.23 hama@yna.co.kr

Prosecutors had previously received voluntary submission of two hard drives used in home PCs from securities company employee Kim (37), who served as an asset manager for Minister Cho and his wife. It is known that unreplaced PC hard drives remain at Minister Cho's home.

Prosecutors have secured testimony that after the investigation began, Professor Jeong asked Kim to replace hard drives, and that Minister Cho told Kim, who was replacing hard drives at the home, something to the effect of "Thank you for helping my wife."

Prosecutors are examining Professor Jeong's suspected charge of instructing evidence destruction while not ruling out the possibility that Minister Cho aided in evidence destruction and concealment, intensively questioning Kim and others about the facts.

As a result of analyzing the home PC hard drives received through voluntary submission, prosecutors secured files that appear to be internship certificates for Minister Cho's daughter and Jang (28), the son of Danukook University Professor Jang Young-pyo, and plan to confirm whether Minister Cho was involved in issuing the certificates.

Prosecutors are also confirming whether the internship preparation certificate and internship certificate that Minister Cho's son (23) received from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center in 2013 and 2017 respectively were falsely issued.

In relation to this, prosecutors conducted raids and searches of four universities that Minister Cho's son and daughter applied to—Ajou University and Chungbuk National University law schools, Yonsei University graduate school, and Ewha Womans University admissions office—securing admissions-related materials.

Ajou University, Chungbuk National University, and Yonsei University are known as places where Minister Cho's son took entrance exams for graduate school, while Ewha Womans University is where his daughter took undergraduate entrance exams. Prosecutors plan to confirm whether Minister Cho's children submitted documents suspected of being forged, such as Seoul National University Law School internship certificates or commendation letters under the name of the Dongyang University president where their mother works, in their university applications.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Seo Myeong-gon = Prosecutors investigating allegations related to Justice Minister Cho Kuk conducted raids and searches on the 23rd at four universities that Minister Cho's son and daughter applied to: Ajou University and Chungbuk National University law schools, Yonsei University graduate school, and Ewha Womans University admissions office. The photo shows Ewha Womans University admissions office, which prosecutors raided and searched on the afternoon of the 23rd to secure admissions-related materials. 2019.9.23 seephoto@yna.co.kr

As a result of calling in and investigating 2009 Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center officials regarding Cho and Jang's receipt of internship certificates from the center under Seoul National University Law School, prosecutors secured multiple testimonies stating "We never issued a certificate to Minister Cho's daughter." Seoul National University Law Professor Han In-seop (current director of the Korean Institute of Criminology), who was the center director at the time, also reportedly testified to the same effect when he appeared before prosecutors on the 20th.

Jang, who was in the same study abroad class as Cho at Hanyoung Foreign Language High School, reportedly recently testified to prosecutors that "I attended a Seoul National University-hosted seminar for one day and Cho submitted the certificate to Hanyoung Foreign Language High School." Prosecutors believe Cho's internship activities were also likely exaggerated and are investigating the facts with Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center officials and others.

Prosecutors have also detected circumstances that Cho submitted this internship certificate to Korea University admissions at the end of the same year and are analyzing the creation subject and timing of the certificate file through digital forensics work.

If Minister Cho was involved in issuing the certificate, charges of creating false official documents or forging private documents could apply. Minister Cho participated as a chairperson in an international academic conference in May 2009 when his daughter did the internship, and later became center director following Professor Han.

{
  "translated_title": "Income Tax Evasion by 'Public Welfare-Harming Tax Evaders' Including Entertainment Establishments Exceeded 1 Trillion Won Last Year",
  "translated_text": "(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Yoon Jong-seok = Last year, the National Tax Service conducted tax audits on 'public welfare-harming tax evasion' by entertainment establishments and others, detecting over 1 trillion won [approximately $750 million USD] in evaded income.

According to data on 'Tax Audit Results for Public Welfare-Harming Tax Evasion Over the Past 5 Years (2014-2018)' that Democratic Party Representative Kim Jung-woo received from the National Tax Service on the 23rd, the amount of income tax evasion by public welfare-harming tax evaders detected by the National Tax Service last year reached 1 trillion 104.7 billion won [approximately $826 million USD].

Among tax evasion cases, the National Tax Service classifies as public welfare-harming tax evasion and conducts annual crackdowns on acts that generate massive profits without paying taxes while earning high incomes from ordinary citizens, including entertainment and pleasure establishments, gambling venues, illegal loan sharks, wedding halls, mutual aid and funeral services, and high-fee hagwons and star instructors.

The total number of public welfare-harming tax evasion cases investigated by the National Tax Service over the past five years was 1,041 cases. These entities should have reported 4 trillion 531.2 billion won [approximately $3.4 billion USD] in income, but actually reported only 1 trillion 493.8 billion won [approximately $1.1 billion USD], getting caught for failing to report the remaining 3 trillion 37.4 billion won [approximately $2.3 billion USD] in evaded income.

Annual evaded income amounts surged nearly threefold over five years, from 374.9 billion won [approximately $280 million USD] in 2014 to 1 trillion 104.7 billion won [approximately $826 million USD] last year.

The tax amount the National Tax Service imposed on these evaders totaled 1 trillion 27.5 billion won [approximately $769 million USD] over five years, substantially increasing from 164.6 billion won [approximately $123 million USD] in 2014 to 249.6 billion won [approximately $187 million USD] last year.

However, the actual collection performance of taxes imposed on public welfare-harming tax evaders remains at a very poor level. The collection rate dropped significantly from 49.3% in 2014 to 17.1% last year.

Source: Representative Kim Jung-woo's office

Representative Kim Jung-woo emphasized that "public welfare-harming tax evasion causes harm to ordinary citizens who are economically vulnerable, so the government needs to respond actively," and pointed out that "tax audits and punishment of public welfare-harming tax evaders should be strengthened, and criminal proceeds should be actively recovered."

  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = On the morning of the 23rd, prosecution officials are entering the front entrance of Justice Minister Cho Kuk's residence in Bangbae-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul to conduct a search and seizure. hama@yna.co.kr

This marks the first time prosecutors have conducted forced investigations targeting Minister Cho, his wife, and children since beginning investigations into Minister Cho's associates late last month. It is also unprecedented for a sitting head of the Ministry of Justice, which has personnel and administrative authority over the prosecution, to be subjected to search and seizure by prosecutors.

The specific targets and scope of this residential search and seizure have not been confirmed. However, analysis from within and outside legal circles suggests that prosecutors have directly begun investigating Minister Cho himself on criminal charges including violations of the Public Service Ethics Act related to private fund allegations, allegations of false issuance of an internship certificate for his daughter Ms. Cho (28) at Seoul National University Law School, and aiding in evidence destruction.

Prosecutors had previously conducted search and seizures of locations including the residence of Minister Cho's brother-in-law Mr. Jeong (56), who is implicated in private fund allegations, and the residence of his brother's ex-wife who is suspected of debt evasion and real estate transaction fraud involving Woongdong Academy [hagwon]. However, they had excluded Minister Cho's residence from targets, considering circumstances such as confirmation hearing preparations and his ministerial appointment.

The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office Special Investigation Unit 2 (Chief Prosecutor Ko Hyeong-gon) sent prosecutors and investigators to Minister Cho's house in Bangbae-dong, Seoul around 9 AM to secure PC hard drives and work-related records.

Prosecutors had previously received voluntary submission of two hard drives used in home PCs from Mr. Kim, a securities company employee who worked as an asset manager for Minister Cho and his wife Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57) of Dongyang University. It is known that unreplaced PC hard drives remain at Minister Cho's residence.

Prosecutors have secured testimony that after the investigation began, Professor Chung asked Mr. Kim to replace hard drives, and that Minister Cho told Mr. Kim, who was replacing hard drives at their residence, words to the effect of "Thank you for helping my wife."

Prosecutors are reviewing charges of instructing evidence destruction against Professor Chung while not ruling out the possibility that Minister Cho aided in evidence destruction and concealment, intensively questioning Mr. Kim and others about the facts.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Shin Jun-hee = Justice Minister Cho Kuk is leaving his residence in Bangbae-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul on the morning of the 23rd. hama@yna.co.kr

As a result of analyzing home PC hard drives received through voluntary submission, prosecutors secured files that appear to be internship certificates for Minister Cho's daughter Ms. Cho and Mr. Jang (28), son of Dankook University Professor Jang Young-pyo, and plan to confirm whether Minister Cho was involved in issuing the certificates.

They are also confirming whether internship schedule certificates and internship certificates that Minister Cho's son (23) received from Seoul National University's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center in 2013 and 2017 respectively were falsely issued.

In relation to this, prosecutors today conducted search and seizures of four universities that Minister Cho's son and daughter applied to—Ajou University and Chungbuk National University law schools, Yonsei University graduate school, and Ewha Womans University admissions office—to secure admissions-related materials.

Ajou University, Chungbuk National University, and Yonsei University are known as places where Minister Cho's son took entrance exams, while Ewha Womans University is where his daughter took entrance exams. Prosecutors plan to confirm whether Minister Cho's children submitted documents suspected of forgery to these university admissions, such as Seoul National University Law School internship certificates or commendation letters issued under the name of the president of Dongyang University where their mother works.

As a result of summoning and investigating 2009 Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center officials regarding Ms. Cho and Mr. Jang receiving internship certificates from the center under Seoul National University Law School, prosecutors secured multiple testimonies stating "We never issued certificates to Minister Cho's daughter." Professor Han In-seop of Seoul National University Law School (current head of the Korean Institute of Criminology), who was the center director at the time, also reportedly came to the prosecution on the 20th and gave testimony to the same effect.

Mr. Jang, who was in the same overseas study program class as Ms. Cho at Hanyoung Foreign Language High School, reportedly recently testified to prosecutors to the effect that "I attended a Seoul National University-hosted seminar for one day and Ms. Cho submitted the certificate to Hanyoung Foreign Language High School." Prosecutors believe there is a high possibility that the content of Ms. Cho's internship activities was also exaggerated and are investigating the facts with Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center officials and others.

They have also detected circumstances that Ms. Cho submitted this internship certificate to Korea University admissions at the end of that year and are analyzing the creator and timing of the certificate file through digital forensic work.

If Minister Cho was involved in issuing the certificate, charges of creating false official documents could apply. In May 2009 when his daughter did the internship, Minister Cho participated as a chairperson in an international academic conference and later became center director, succeeding Professor Han.
