{
  "translated_title": ""Twins Could Score 100 Points at Sookmyung Girls' High"... Former Academic Affairs Director Refutes First Trial Verdict",
  "translated_text": "Former Sookmyung Girls' High School academic affairs director (CG)[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Ko Dong-wook = The defense team for the former Sookmyung Girls' High School academic affairs director, who received a prison sentence in the first trial for leaking exam questions and answers to her twin daughters, mobilized testimony from hagwon instructors and former students to refute the guilty verdict logic.

At the appellate court hearing held on the 18th at the Seoul Central District Court Criminal Appeals Division 2 (Presiding Judge Lee Kwan-yong), the defense attorney for former academic affairs director Ms. Hyun questioned witness hagwon teacher Mr. Park about Ms. Hyun's daughter's academic abilities.

Mr. Park, who taught mathematics to Ms. Hyun's daughter in the Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] hagwon district, compared schools in Gangnam's School District 8, saying "For example, Whimoon High, Joongdong High, Dankook University Affiliated High, and Eunkwang Girls' High have extremely difficult (school record exams)," adding "In Sookmyung Girls' High School's case, they coach students saying 'this is how questions come out, so just train on this.'"

This means that compared to surrounding Gangnam schools, Sookmyung tends to give ordinary problems faithful to the curriculum, making them relatively easy to solve.

When the defense attorney asked "Is it possible for students at Sookmyung Girls' High School to score 100 points if they prepare well for school record exams, even if they're not at the top level in hagwons?" Mr. Park answered "I think it's possible."

Regarding Ms. Hyun's daughter, he said "I think the reason her grades improved was diligence," adding "Based on judging the child's condition through review tests and such, I had expectations that she could reach the level of scoring 100 points."

Mr. Park also refuted the first trial's basis for determining that Ms. Hyun's daughter's grades were not based on 'ability.'

Regarding the fact that while her school grades rose sharply, her hagwon level test results only improved from Level 4 to Level 3, Mr. Park explained "At that time, Level 3 included both students ranking in the top 5 school-wide and students ranking over 100th."

He added "Level tests have very different question formats from school record exams, so they don't correlate with school grades," explaining "It's both funny and sad, but there are students who get private tutoring to do well on hagwon level tests."

Regarding Ms. Hyun's daughter's school exam problems, which received criticism in the first trial for having inadequate solution processes, Mr. Park testified that they were "problems embarrassing to write solutions for" or showed "a student who understands the solutions."

A former student of Ms. Hyun, now a college student, also attended court that day to testify.

When the defense attorney asked "Did the student who ranked first school-wide in first year continue to rank first?" this former student said "At Sookmyung Girls' High School, absolutely not."

Regarding Ms. Hyun's two daughters' previous rankings of 59th and 121st school-wide before they rose to first place, the student said "At that level, they would be evaluated as good students among their peers."

The former student also testified about having experience writing their answers in small letters in the corner of exam papers during school, saying "When answers were confusing, I was trying to check the overall answer distribution across all questions." The student also testified that this was a "common exam skill" taught by hagwon and school teachers.

This is identical to the explanation given by Ms. Hyun's two daughters during the first trial process.

This former student, who served as class president in a class Ms. Hyun once taught, defended their former teacher, saying "When I encountered this incident, I thought 'that can't be true,'" adding "Not just me, but many classmates think the same way."

Ms. Hyun watched her former student answer the defense attorney's questions from the witness stand without significant changes in expression.

{
  "translated_title": "'Hagwon Sunday Holiday System' to Begin Full Public Debate After Chuseok...Seoul to Reach Conclusion in November",
  "translated_text": "Hagwon district. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul·Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Jae-young and Lee Hyo-seok = Discussion on introducing the hagwon Sunday holiday system will begin in earnest after the Chuseok [Korean harvest festival] holiday. Fierce pro-and-con debates are expected to unfold.

The Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education announced on the 14th that it plans to conduct online and telephone surveys asking 22,500 citizens about their stance on the hagwon Sunday holiday system immediately after the Chuseok holiday ends.

The education office plans to compose about half of the survey subjects as students, viewing what students think about the hagwon Sunday holiday system as most important.

The Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education selected the hagwon Sunday holiday system as its second public debate topic following school uniforms, and has been proceeding with procedures including forming a public debate promotion committee last month with Myongji University Professor Lim Seung-bin as chairman. The survey is also part of the public debate process.

The promotion committee is currently discussing with an advisory group composed of parents, school teachers, hagwon officials, student rights experts, and others how to structure a citizen participation group that will recommend to the superintendent whether to introduce the hagwon Sunday holiday system and implementation plans if introduction is decided.

The citizen participation group's composition and scale has been set as '200 people including students, parents, school teachers, and general citizens,' but the 'composition ratio' is undetermined. Issues reportedly include what proportion should be students and whether to include elementary school students and hagwon officials.

The participation group plans to hold two rounds of 7-hour discussions on October 26th and November 9th, then present recommendations at the end of November. Separately from the participation group, discussion sessions involving stakeholders will also be held on the 27th of this month and the 22nd of next month.

In Gyeonggi [Province], Provincial Assemblyman Chu Min-kyu is preparing an ordinance for the hagwon Sunday holiday system.

Assemblyman Chu plans to request opinions from stakeholders such as hagwon associations immediately after the Chuseok holiday, go through necessary procedures including briefings and public hearings, then propose the ordinance around the end of October.

Those supporting the hagwon Sunday holiday system emphasize that students need rest.

The Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education commissioned research to examine the feasibility of introducing the hagwon Sunday holiday system in June, stating that "the burden on students and parents continues to increase due to excessive hagwon education and entrance exam competition" and "the necessity of introducing the hagwon Sunday holiday system is raised in terms of improving students' physical and mental health and reducing hagwon education costs."

Those opposing introduction of the hagwon Sunday holiday system cite as problematic that it would deprive students of opportunities to supplement at hagwons what they haven't fully mastered through school studies alone.

Restricting and infringing upon students' and parents' educational choice and hagwons' freedom of business operation is also a major basis for opposing introduction of the hagwon Sunday holiday system.

Questions are also raised about whether it's an effective measure.

As of April 1st last year, there were 7,791 entrance exam preparation and supplementary education hagwons in Seoul. This is about 1,400 more than the number of karaoke rooms (6,345) in Seoul, meaning that prohibiting and monitoring hagwons' Sunday operations would require 'enormous' administrative power. However, even hagwons' late-night instruction is not properly regulated due to education office staff shortages.

There are also criticisms that students can't rest not because of hagwons.

In last year's Korea Youth Policy Institute survey on children and youth human rights conditions, 52.4% of youth said they lacked sleep, with home study cited as the top reason (first priority) for insufficient sleep, followed by 'hagwons and private tutoring' (18.4%).

A considerable number of youth also cited chatting and text messaging (14.1%) or internet use (13.0%) as reasons, making it difficult to say hagwons alone are the reason for sleep deprivation.

Students studying at a hagwon. [Yonhap News file photo]

How to implement the hagwon Sunday holiday system is also controversial.

Superintendent Cho Hee-yeon plans to first request the Ministry of Education to revise the 'Act on the Establishment and Operation of Hagwons and Extracurricular Lessons' if public opinion converges toward introducing the hagwon Sunday holiday system.

However, the Ministry of Education is reportedly not planning to actively pursue introduction of the hagwon Sunday holiday system.

Superintendent Cho is thinking of enacting an ordinance to implement the hagwon Sunday holiday system in Seoul alone if the Ministry of Education doesn't accept the recommendation.

However, implementing the hagwon Sunday holiday system through ordinance could spark constitutional and legal controversies.

The Korea Legislation Research Institute issued an authoritative interpretation in 2017 that it's impossible under hagwon law for superintendents to designate hagwon closure days through ordinances. The reason was that hagwon law only has provisions allowing 'instruction hours' to be set by ordinance, but no provisions for closure days.

Superintendent Cho Hee-yeon previously promised in a July Yonhap News interview that "I well understand the hagwon Sunday holiday system is a very sensitive policy for the parties involved - students, parents, and hagwon operators" and "I will broadly accommodate public opinion."

{
  "translated_title": "Police Expand Investigation into Gwangju Goryeo High School Over Allegations of Special Treatment for High-Achieving Students",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Goryeo High School. Resale and database use prohibited] [Sent 2019.08.20]

(Gwangju=Yonhap News) Reporters Son Sang-won and Park Cheol-hong = Police have expanded the scope of investigation targets related to Gwangju Goryeo High School, which is suspected of giving special treatment to high-achieving students through test question leaks.

Police have decided to release all investigation results at once.

According to the Gwangju Bukbu Police Station on the 13th, there are a total of 6 investigation targets related to Goryeo High School.

One teacher has been booked without detention and is under investigation on charges of directly using 5 questions from the 3rd-grade mathematics final exam in handouts distributed to a mathematics club.

Additionally, when a civic group filed a police complaint against the Goryeo High School principal and vice principal, claiming "there was comprehensive misconduct in academic operations," these two individuals were summoned for investigation as complainees and were booked.

Furthermore, the Gwangju Metropolitan Office of Education referred 3 teachers (including 1 retiree) to police for investigation on charges of "obstruction of business."

Through a special audit, the city education office determined that in last year's 1st-grade mathematics exam, 8 questions were taken from a specific textbook and 1 question was taken from handouts provided to the "Saturday Essay-Writing Exam Class," and requested that the illegality of these question-setting teachers be determined.

They also requested investigation regarding a specific student's sudden improvement in mathematics grades.

It is reported that whether the 3 teachers related to this matter will be booked has not yet been decided.

[Yonhap News file photo]

Police initially planned to first send the originally booked teacher to the prosecution on charges of obstruction of business, but decided to postpone this as the number of investigation targets increased.

They plan to complete investigations of the remaining teachers including the principal and vice principal, then explain all investigation results at once.

There is particular interest in what punishment standards police will apply to these investigation targets.

Attention is focused on whether they will uncover evidence that test questions were provided in advance to specific students, or whether they will judge it as routine copying in question-setting.

While the education office claims that Goryeo High School provided special management for high achievers, the school argues this is unfair compared to audits of other schools, making police judgment on this matter another point of interest.

A police official stated, "We recently received audit-related documents from the Gwangju Metropolitan Office of Education and are proceeding with the investigation," adding "We intend to reach investigation conclusions all at once and send them to the prosecution."

Meanwhile, after allegations of test question leaks emerged, the education office conducted a special audit and demanded that the school discipline or take administrative action against about 50 of 60 teachers, including the principal (dismissal) and vice principal (removal), claiming they "provided special management for high-achieving students and turned the school into a college entrance exam hagwon."

The school has objected to this and requested a review.

[Yonhap News file photo]

{
  "translated_title": ""Unfair Treatment"... Goryeo High School, Where 80% of Teachers Face Disciplinary Action, Applies for Reconsideration",
  "translated_text": "(Gwangju=Yonhap News) Reporter Son Sang-won = Principal Moon Hyeong-su of Goryeo High School explains the school's position after applying to the Gwangju Metropolitan Office of Education for reconsideration of disciplinary action requests on the 10th. 2019.9.10

(Gwangju=Yonhap News) Reporter Son Sang-won = Goryeo High School in Gwangju, where over 80% of all teachers have been subject to disciplinary action or administrative punishment requests for reasons including giving special treatment to high-performing students, has applied for reconsideration.

On the 10th, Goryeo High School requested the Gwangju Metropolitan Office of Education to re-examine the audit results and disciplinary action requests.

Goryeo High School argued, "There were no serious violations serious enough to warrant heavy disciplinary actions such as dismissal or removal from office," and demanded, "Reconsideration should be conducted considering fairness with other schools that have undergone audits for similar cases."

The school claimed it had taken follow-up measures related to improvements in curriculum, assessment management, after-school programs, and dormitory operations.

Regarding the first semester final math exam for third-year students, where some questions were taken from materials distributed by clubs that high-performing students participated in, the school emphasized this was simply a teacher's mistake, and the audit results showed no evidence anywhere of grade manipulation for high-performing students.

Regarding the operation of ability-grouped classes, Goryeo High School stated, "These are level-based mobile classes according to Ministry of Education recommendations, and according to school information disclosure data, 23.3% of schools nationwide implement them," adding, "The results of early admission [university admissions based on school records and other factors] and regular admission [primarily CSAT-based university admissions] confirm that Goryeo High School did not provide education only for high-performing students."

The education office decided to convene an audit review committee to examine the validity of the school's arguments and determine whether to conduct a reconsideration.

After allegations of test question leaks surfaced, the education office conducted a special audit and concluded that the school "provided special management for high-performing students and turned the school into an exam-prep hagwon," requesting disciplinary action or administrative punishment for about 50 out of 60 teachers, including the principal (dismissal) and vice-principal (removal from office).

{
  "translated_title": "Cho Confirmation Hearing: Allegations and Explanations... "Criminal Act" vs "Not True" (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Ju-hyeong = Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk answers lawmakers' questions at the National Assembly Judiciary Committee confirmation hearing on the morning of the 6th. kjhpress@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Seul-gi, Lee Eun-jeong, Lee Dong-hwan = The National Assembly confirmation hearing for Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk on the 6th resembled a battlefield where spears and shields clashed, with various allegations surrounding Cho and his explanations exchanged.

The hearing addressed allegations including forgery of a Dongyang University president's commendation letter for Cho's daughter, PC removal by his wife Professor Chung Kyung-sim (57) of Dongyang University before a search and seizure, phone calls between Cho and Dongyang University President Choi Sung-hae, and private equity funds invested by Cho's family.

◇ Dongyang University President's Commendation Letter Forgery Allegations

The Liberty Korea Party claimed that Cho's daughter submitted a forged Dongyang University president's commendation letter for admission to Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine. The party's position is that this constitutes document forgery and obstruction of official duties.

The party also raised suspicions that 'the daughter did not perform volunteer work at all,' citing discrepancies between Professor Chung's tenure at Dongyang University (from July 2011) and the volunteer activity period specified in the commendation letter (2010-September 2012).

In response, Cho acknowledged that if his spouse's forgery of the commendation letter were true, he "thinks it could constitute a crime," but denied the allegations were factual and simultaneously refuted that his daughter definitely performed volunteer work.

Cho stated, "It is definitely true that our child performed various English-related volunteer activities such as proofreading English essays for youth in Gyeongbuk region," and regarding the volunteer period, he answered, "I think it was incorrectly recorded."

Democratic Party lawmakers Kim Jong-min and Park Ju-min also supported Cho's side by suggesting the possibility that Dongyang University's certificate and commendation letter formats were not standardized.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Ju-hyeong = Liberty Korea Party lawmaker Kim Do-eup discloses phone call records between Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk and the Dongyang University president at the National Assembly Judiciary Committee confirmation hearing resumed on the afternoon of the 6th. 2019.9.6 kjhpress@yna.co.kr

◇ Direct Phone Call with Dongyang University President

The Korea Party attacked that Cho's direct phone call with Dongyang University President Choi Sung-hae regarding the commendation letter forgery allegations was not only inappropriate but could even constitute charges of destruction of evidence and perjury instruction.

Korea Party lawmaker Jang Je-won said, "The Dongyang University president reportedly has a recording file of the phone call," and fellow party member Kim Jin-tae quoted the president's media interview, saying, "'The president will live and Professor Chung will live too' - what Cho said means if they don't speak as he wishes, 'Professor Chung will die and the president will die too,'" adding, "This is implicit intimidation and coercion, and I will file charges against the nominee today."

In response, Cho explained, "My wife was so shocked on the day of the search and seizure that she called the president to complain and said, 'Didn't you delegate this to me?'" He added, "At the end of the call, my wife was so agitated that I apologized to the president and only asked him to 'please investigate well.'"

Regarding accusations that he could face criminal charges for evidence destruction, he strongly denied, stating, "I don't think it falls under that category. No matter how much I think about it, I believe my actions do not meet the requirements for criminal liability."

The Korea Party also raised suspicions that Cho and his spouse called President Choi multiple times, to which Cho refuted, "In my case, I only had one brief phone call."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Ju-hyeong = Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk (right) listens to questions from Liberty Korea Party lawmaker Ju Gwang-deok regarding his daughter's Dongyang University president's award at the National Assembly Judiciary Committee confirmation hearing on the morning of the 6th. 2019.9.6 kjhpress@yna.co.kr

◇ Allegations of Involvement in Daughter's First-Author Paper at Dankook University Medical School and Spouse's PC Removal

The Korea Party pointed out that the file information creator and final saver for an English medical paper where Cho's daughter was listed as first author while attending Hanyoung Foreign Language High School's second year was recorded as 'Cho Kuk.'

This raised suspicions that Cho wrote his daughter's medical paper for her.

Lawmaker Kim Jin-tae attacked, "The file claimed to be created on a home PC was actually created on a Seoul National University College of Law PC, as revealed through forensics."

Cho explained that he brought a used PC from Seoul National University home for family use, stating, "Whether my son or daughter uses my PC, the file information appears under my information."

Regarding the opposition's pursuit that his spouse Professor Chung Kyung-sim faces evidence destruction charges for taking her PC from Dongyang University two days before the search and seizure, Cho explained, "She also needed to check and review the PC contents in her research office," adding, "She couldn't go to her research office due to the conditions, so she went to get her PC."

When the opposition pursued that Professor Chung's PC was found in a Korea Investment & Securities employee's car trunk, Cho stated, "My wife was not feeling well, so a Korea Investment employee drove. My wife went down to Pusan and told [the Korea Investment employee] to keep the PC until she returned, meeting after returning to Seoul," adding, "Later, the prosecution contacted us and we voluntarily submitted the PC as is."

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jin-wook = Democratic Party and Liberty Korea Party lawmakers engage in heated debate at the Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk confirmation hearing at the National Assembly Judiciary Committee meeting room in Yeouido, Seoul on the afternoon of the 6th. 2019.9.6 cityboy@yna.co.kr

◇ Allegations of Daughter's False Credentials at KIST, Seoul National University, KOICA Internships

The Korea Party claimed that Professor Chung Kyung-sim asked Professor Kim (surname) at Kongju National University, whom she knew from her Seoul National University undergraduate days, for her daughter's internship at Kongju National University's Biotechnology Research Institute.

This directly contradicts Cho's explanation that his daughter first sent an email to Professor Kim expressing interest in internship participation, leading to their meeting.

Lawmaker Jang Je-won stated, "It was confirmed that Professor Chung and Professor Kim exchanged emails multiple times, modifying some phrases to create a confirmation letter."

Cho avoided giving a direct answer about whether Professor Chung Kyung-sim called first, saying he "cannot confirm."

Suspicions also arose about credential padding as Cho's daughter performed Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) and Kenya internships during the same period.

Lawmaker Jang stated, "Looking at Cho's daughter's personal statement, she claims to have worked at KIST for 3 weeks, but KIST says she only came to work 3 days with a visitor pass, not even an entry card," claiming the KIST internship certificate was false.

Cho flatly denied the false internship allegations, stating, "I asked the KIST internship supervisor for understanding via email before going to Kenya."

Regarding the KIST 3-day attendance suspicion, Cho refuted, "She sometimes entered with people she went with without tagging her entry card. For example, on July 11, she met the center's responsible doctor without an entry record."

Meanwhile, regarding 'credential exchange' suspicions with Dankook University Medical School Professor Jang Young-pyo, he repeatedly explained, "I have never contacted Professor Jang about this matter."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Liberty Korea Party lawmaker Ju Gwang-deok announced at the National Assembly press room on the 6th that he confirmed from Seoul National University that Cho's daughter (28) never performed internship activities at Seoul National University Law School or Seoul National University Law School's Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center. 2019.9.6 [Provided by Lawmaker Ju Gwang-deok's office. Resale and DB prohibited] photo@yna.co.kr

Circumstances emerged that the Seoul National University Law School Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center internship career recorded in Cho's daughter's high school records was also false. Among 17 internship participants at the institution from 2007-2012, not a single high school student was found.

Cho stated, "The human rights club my child belonged to in high school connected with Public Interest and Human Rights Law Center staff to do small tasks like errands at international symposiums requiring English," adding, "It's true she received a certificate for that work."

Claims also emerged that Cho's daughter's name was not in KOICA (Korea International Cooperation Agency) Mongolia volunteer activity records.

Cho clarified this was groundless, stating, "There's a certificate showing the entire Hanyoung Foreign Language High School went. She really did go to Mongolia."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Ju-hyeong = Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk closes his eyes to Korea Party lawmakers' document submission requests at the National Assembly Judiciary Committee confirmation hearing on the morning of the 6th. On the right, the confirmation hearing preparation team is seen in discussion. 2019.9.6 kjhpress@yna.co.kr

◇ Daughter's Birth Date and Scholarship Receipt Allegations

Criticism continued over Cho's daughter receiving scholarships from Seoul National University Graduate School of Environmental Studies and Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine despite her family's comfortable financial situation.

Lawmaker Jang Je-won additionally disclosed that Cho's daughter received 169,000 won [approximately $127 USD] from Seoul National University under the name of living expenses scholarship.

Cho stated, "I didn't know about this item, and I understand it was sent collectively by the Seoul National University alumni association. I'm sorry," but added, "I wasn't scrambling to receive 169,000 won [approximately $127 USD]."

He continued, "I'm also very sorry to the people. This doesn't mean there's no problem because I did well or it was legal," adding, "If I had known earlier, I would have taken measures, but I deeply regret not doing so."

Korea Party lawmakers including Kim Jin-tae pointed out that Cho's daughter, whose actual birth date is September 1992 but was registered as February 1992, corrected her birth date to September 1992 before applying to Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine, questioning whether this was done with the medical school entrance exam in mind.

Cho dismissed this, stating, "There's no relation or benefit to school," adding, "My child often asked to change it because her actual and documented birth dates were different, and after waiting and waiting, she entrusted a lawyer with a lawsuit and received a court decision."

He also revealed that she applied to Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine with her pre-change birth date (February 1992), not her post-change birth date (September 1992).

Meanwhile, claims emerged that Cho's son also interned at Seoul National University Law School's Human Rights Law Center following his daughter.

Korea Party lawmaker Ju Gwang-deok pursued, "Looking at all internship activity certificates from Seoul National University Law School's Human Rights Law Center from 2006 to present, all were issued before 2014, with only one issued afterward. That's exactly the nominee's son," adding, "Moreover, only the nominee's son's certificate format is different."

Cho explained, "Other students must have received certificates too, but I cannot know what the center issued, so I'll check," adding, "My son was a school violence victim. That's how he became interested in victim human rights related to this."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lim Hwa-young = The appearance of Korea Investment & Securities Yeongdeungpo PB Center in Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul, where prosecution search and seizure is underway on the afternoon of the 5th to investigate the money flow of Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk's spouse Professor Chung Kyung-sim of Dongyang University's private equity fund investment and family funds. 2019.9.5 hwayoung7@yna.co.kr

◇ Private Equity Fund Investment Illegality Allegations

Claims were again raised that after Cho's family invested in funds, related companies won government contracts and saw surging sales, with Cho's family ultimately benefiting as a result.

Regarding lawmaker Kim Jin-tae's claim that 'companies in Cho Kuk's fund investment swept up all government contracts,' Cho stated, "I confirmed this opportunity and it's wrong," adding, "Because it's a blind fund, my family cannot see where it invests at all due to the structure."

Regarding accusations that only Cho's family invested in a specific private equity fund, he mentioned, "The policy was that individual stocks were not allowed when entering the Blue House, but funds including private equity funds were permissible," adding, "Accordingly, I entered the fund through my second cousin."

Regarding opposition lawmakers' claims that he should face prosecution investigation related to private equity fund investment, Cho raised his voice, stating, "It's news to me that I have charges," asking, "If I thought private equity fund investment was illegal, would I have directly reported it when registering public official assets?"

He denied that he first learned of Colink PE, which operates the 'family private equity fund,' during this confirmation hearing phase and had no involvement in the investment process.

Regarding claims that private equity funds became a channel for irregular gifts, he refuted, "The law changed so comprehensive gifts are not allowed."

When pressed about not knowing his wife Professor Chung Kyung-sim's investment as her husband, he answered, "My wife has considerable wealth and leads an independent economic life," adding, "Please consider as a premise that she inherited an apartment from her father-in-law in the 1990s, also inherited buildings, and has assets from working as a professional for a long time."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Ha Sa-heon = Woongdong Academy board member Kim Hyeong-gap testifies as the sole witness at Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk's confirmation hearing on the afternoon of the 6th. 2019.9.6 toadboy@yna.co.kr

◇ Woongdong Academy Debt and Self-Lawsuit Allegations

Allegations of passing Woongdong Academy's debt to state institutions through family 'self-lawsuits' were also contentious.

Cho explained, "When I agreed in the board meeting (to sell school revenue property), it was before my younger brother filed the lawsuit," adding, "It wasn't the board that decides school property disposal, but I applied for extension of disposal permission when Ministry of Education permission for school property disposal had already been granted."

Regarding criticism of 'no-defense self-lawsuit,' Cho stated, "My brother filed a construction payment lawsuit but couldn't receive payment, so my brother had no choice but to file the lawsuit," adding, "Not just my brother's case, but Woongdong Academy has practiced no-defense for cases where evidence is clear and there's absolutely no reason to argue."

{
  "translated_title": ""Is your IQ 70?" to elementary student... Hagwon instructor receives fine for child abuse",
  "translated_text": "[Yonhap News file photo]

(Changwon=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jung-hoon = Elementary student A (10) cannot forget what English hagwon instructor B (46) did to him at an English study room this past February.

During class, B told A, who was doing homework, "Either stay and do it, or go home and do it—close your notebook."

However, when A continued doing homework and asked questions, he made insulting remarks saying "Shut up, keep your eyes down."

Then he approached A, pointed to the homework content written in the textbook and said "Can't you even understand this? Is your IQ 70?" while throwing books and notebooks and ordering him to go home.

As A was leaving for home, he again hurled abuse at him, saying "A bastard who's not even human-like isn't worth studying."

Prosecutors indicted B without detention for violating the Child Welfare Act, charging that he emotionally abused the child through verbal violence.

Changwon District Court Criminal Division 4 Judge Cho Mi-hwa announced on the 5th that she sentenced B to a fine of 1 million won [approximately $750 USD].

Judge Cho stated in her ruling, "The child suffered considerable mental anguish and there is no evidence showing that damage has been recovered, but considering his remorseful attitude and other factors, I sentence him to a fine of 1 million won [approximately $750 USD]."

{
  "translated_title": "Confirmation Hearing for Cho Finally Opens After Twists and Turns...'Battle of Spear and Shield' Key Issues",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Do-hoon = Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk is stating his position regarding the confirmation hearing at the lobby of Jeokseon Hyundai Building in Jongro-gu, Seoul, where his confirmation hearing preparation office is located, on the afternoon of the 4th. The National Assembly Legislation and Judiciary Committee is expected to hold a plenary session this afternoon to confirm the schedule to conduct a confirmation hearing for Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk on the 6th. superdoo82@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Bang Hyun-deok = As the confirmation hearing for Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk has been tentatively scheduled for the 6th of this month after various twists and turns, attention is focused on what issues will heat up the hearing room.

The key issues regarding nominee Cho are broadly divided into ▲ suspicions regarding his daughter's thesis and scholarships related to university admissions ▲ suspicions regarding his family's private equity fund investments ▲ suspicions related to Ungdong hagwon owned by his family.

However, nominee Cho has already refuted or denied the suspicions surrounding himself and his family through a press conference held at the National Assembly on the 2nd, so fierce debates are expected at the hearing.

◇ Daughter's thesis suspicions...'2-week intern' controversy over being first author of medical paper

The thesis controversy involving nominee Cho's daughter, Ms. Cho (28), is a core issue of this hearing. Ms. Cho worked as an intern at Dankook University's Medical Science Research Institute for about 2 weeks during her second year at Hanyoung Foreign Language High School, and was subsequently listed as the first author of an English paper in the Korean Journal of Pathology.

Nominee Cho said, "It seems they evaluated that my daughter greatly contributed to organizing the research results in English," but the Korean Medical Association recommended on the 2nd that the paper be voluntarily withdrawn, stating "There is absolutely no possibility that Ms. Cho made contributions worthy of being first author."

Liberty Korea Party lawmaker Joo Gwang-deok has also questioned nominee Cho's explanation, saying that his daughter's English grades during high school were only 4th to 8th grade out of 9 total grades.

Nominee Cho explained, "I thought it was somewhat strange that my daughter was listed as first author," while adding, "At that time, the criteria for determining first and second authors seemed loose or ambiguous, or largely dependent on the supervising professor's discretion."

It was also confirmed that Ms. Cho and the son of Professor Jang, who was the corresponding author of this paper, were alumni of Hanyoung Foreign Language High School.

Claims have also been raised that Professor Jang's son worked as a high school intern at Seoul National University Law School where nominee Cho was a professor, raising suspicions that nominee Cho was involved in an 'internship exchange' for the children.

However, nominee Cho's position is that "the parent-participation internship was created by the teacher in charge at the high school where she was enrolled, and my child (daughter) participated in that program."

The fact that Ms. Cho was listed as third author of an abstract presented at an international ornithology conference after interning at Kongju National University's Biotechnology Research Institute is also controversial, as the professor in charge of the internship at that time was known to be acquainted with nominee Cho's spouse, Chung Kyung-sim, from her Seoul National University undergraduate days.

Above all, as suspicions have been raised that such internships and paper authorship listings may have influenced nominee Cho's daughter's admission to Korea University in 2010, this controversy has expanded to 'university admission fraud suspicions.'

However, nominee Cho drew a line, saying "There are no facts of improper solicitation related to university admissions."

Additionally, it became known that Ms. Cho received a commendation letter from the president of Dongyang University, where her mother Chung works, and used it for medical school admissions, but suspicions of document forgery have emerged as the school recently stated that it 'never approved the commendation letter.'

In addition, claims that Chung requested the school to 'issue a press release stating that the commendation letter was properly issued' but was refused are also expected to be controversial.

(Yangsan=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Jung-heon = On the afternoon of August 27, prosecutors who completed a search and seizure at the College of Nursing, Graduate School of Medicine at Pusan National University Hospital in Yangsan, Gyeongnam Province, are moving boxes. [Yonhap News file photo]

◇ Controversy over daughter's scholarships at Pusan National University and Seoul National University

The controversy over Ms. Cho's scholarship receipts at Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine continues. Despite failing twice, Ms. Cho received scholarships totaling 12 million won [approximately $9,000 USD] for 6 consecutive semesters from 2016 to 2018.

The scholarship was provided by the 'Socheon Scholarship Foundation,' privately established by Noh Hwan-jung, director of Busan Medical Center, who was her supervising professor. While this scholarship was given to at least 2 people each semester, Ms. Cho alone received it for 6 semesters.

The fact that nominee Cho met and dined with Director Noh and hospital officials just before the scholarship was received, that Director Noh was selected as director of Busan Medical Center when nominee Cho was senior presidential secretary for civil affairs, and that documents stating he 'was deeply involved in selecting the president's personal physician' were reportedly found on Director Noh's office computer during the prosecution's search and seizure, are expected to become material for opposition attacks.

However, nominee Cho refuted, saying "As announced by Pusan National University Graduate School of Medicine, there was nothing illegal about the payment" and "The selection of the Busan Medical Center director and personal physician is not within the authority of the senior secretary for civil affairs."

The fact that Ms. Cho received scholarships totaling 8.04 million won [approximately $6,000 USD] for 2 semesters after entering Seoul National University Graduate School of Environmental Studies in 2014 also became problematic, with questions of whether it was 'eating and running' since she took a leave of absence immediately after being accepted to medical school in October of that year.

Moreover, this scholarship from the 'Gwanak Association,' a scholarship foundation under the Seoul National University Alumni Association, was reportedly given even though Ms. Cho had not applied for it, causing fierce controversy over the circumstances.

Nominee Cho said, "No one in our family has ever applied for or contacted by phone about Seoul National University alumni scholarships" and "We tried to return the scholarship when taking a leave of absence, but the scholarship foundation said it was impossible."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jung-hoon = Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk arrives at the confirmation hearing preparation team office at Jeokseon Hyundai Building in Jongro-gu, Seoul, on the morning of the 4th. uwg806@yna.co.kr

◇ Private equity fund suspicions...Family fund and government contract allegations

The private equity fund 'Blue Core Value-up No. 1' by Kolink Private Equity (PE), which nominee Cho's spouse and children invested in in July 2017, is also a core issue of the hearing.

This private equity fund had a total of 6 investors, with nominee Cho's spouse and two children investing 1.05 billion won [approximately $788,000 USD], and his spouse's brother (nominee Cho's brother-in-law) and two sons investing 350 million won [approximately $263,000 USD].

Additionally, circumstances became known that in March 2017, his spouse lent 300 million won [approximately $225,000 USD] to her brother, and the brother purchased Kolink PE shares at 200 times the price, raising suspicions that the private equity fund was essentially a 'family fund' and a means to avoid gift taxes.

Suspicions have also been raised that the actual owner of Kolink PE is nominee Cho's second cousin. Nominee Cho has explained that he was introduced to the fund by his second cousin.

Regarding this, nominee Cho said, "I didn't know well what a private equity fund was" and "I hope my second cousin returns to the country as soon as possible to reveal the truth."

This private equity fund invested in streetlight flasher company 'Wells C&T' in August 2017, and it was pointed out as suspicious that Wells C&T subsequently won 177 projects from 47 local governments and public institutions, with sales nearly doubling.

As the private equity fund investment was made after nominee Cho was appointed as senior presidential secretary for civil affairs, the Liberty Korea Party claims this company received preferential treatment.

The fact that 2 months after nominee Cho's family invested in Kolink PE, related company Consortium A was selected as the 'preferred bidder' for Seoul's 150 billion won [approximately $113 million USD] subway Wi-Fi project is also a point where the opposition raises suspicions.

The Liberty Korea Party suspects that Consortium A won the public bid through the influence or inside information of nominee Cho and other ruling party members, given that two former aides to former and current Democratic Party lawmakers are listed as major shareholders of Consortium A.

Additionally, suspicions arose that Kolink PE's acquisition of shares in KOSDAQ-listed secondary battery company WFM in October 2017, becoming the largest shareholder, was an attempt at backdoor listing for Wells C&T. If this were the case, Blue Core Value-up No. 1, which invested in Wells C&T—that is, nominee Cho's fund—would gain considerable profit.

However, nominee Cho refuted, "I didn't know about Kolink PE itself until recently." He added, "I have never been involved in winning government contracts at all."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Ju-hyung = Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk answers reporters' questions at a press conference that resumed after finishing dinner at the National Assembly on the afternoon of the 2nd. kjhpress@yna.co.kr

◇ Ungdong hagwon suspicions...'Sham lawsuit and property seizure' controversy

Suspicions surrounding the school corporation Ungdong hagwon, which has been operated by nominee Cho's family, are also receiving considerable attention as they are directly related to nominee Cho's family's current property issues.

Nominee Cho's mother and younger brother Cho Kwon previously applied for 'qualified acceptance'—not repaying debts exceeding inherited property—to avoid joint debt obligations when Goryeo General Construction, where their father served as representative director, went bankrupt in 1997, thereby escaping debt.

Later, Cho Kwon established a company called Cova C&D in late 2005, then transferred construction payment claims (approximately 5.2 billion won [approximately $3.9 million USD] at the time) that he couldn't receive from Ungdong hagwon, where his father served as chairman—1 billion won [approximately $750,000 USD] to his spouse and 4.2 billion won [approximately $3.2 million USD] to Cova C&D—then filed a lawsuit against Ungdong hagwon for construction costs.

However, Ungdong hagwon gave up on defense, and Cho Kwon's side won the case, raising suspicions of a 'sham lawsuit.'

The same lawsuit occurred in 2017 as well. When the statute of limitations for the case was about to expire, 'Cafe Hugo,' represented by Ms. Cho, the ex-wife of Cho Kwon, filed a lawsuit against Ungdong hagwon and again won without defense. This was after they had divorced.

Criticism arose that nominee Cho's family did not repay their father's 4.2 billion won [approximately $3.2 million USD] debt but acquired 5.1 billion won [approximately $3.8 million USD] in claims.

The Liberty Korea Party claims, "The original construction cost was 1.6 billion won [approximately $1.2 million USD], but now it has grown to 10.084 billion won [approximately $7.6 million USD] (including delay interest)" and "The lawsuit was filed with the purpose of seizing school property if Ungdong hagwon closes."

However, nominee Cho explained, "My brother came to have construction payment claims for the school, but nothing remained. We never took measures such as provisional seizure against the school, and (the lawsuit) was a measure to confirm claims."

Nominee Cho himself also caused controversy by reportedly avoiding his father's 1.2 billion won [approximately $900,000 USD] debt to Korea Asset Management Corporation (KAMCO) for just 6 won [approximately $0.005 USD] through qualified acceptance along with his brother.

The Liberty Korea Party believes that the funds nominee Cho used to purchase Daelim Apartment in Garak-dong, Songpa-gu in 1998 and Kyungnam Sunkyung Apartment in Haeundae-gu, Busan in 1999 also flowed from Ungdong hagwon.

{
  "translated_title": "[Jeju News] Provincial Education Office Implements 'Phone Complaint Reservation Call Service'",
  "translated_text": "(Jeju=Yonhap News) The Jeju Provincial Education Office will implement a 'phone complaint reservation call service' starting from the 5th.
[Yonhap News file photo]

The phone complaint reservation call service is a service that makes it possible to make advance reservations for certificate issuance complaints with just one phone call, which previously could only be done through the internet homepage.
Even complainants who have difficulty using the internet can easily use it, and complainants can visit on their desired date and receive civil complaint documents immediately without waiting time after only going through identity verification procedures.
The certificates and documents that can be issued through advance reservation include a total of 19 types: 5 student-related types (graduation certificate, enrollment certificate, expulsion certificate, transcript, school life record), 3 personnel-related types (employment certificate, career certificate, retirement certificate), 9 lifelong education-related types (hagwon operator fact confirmation document, hagwon closure/suspension fact confirmation document, hagwon instructor fact confirmation document, etc.), and 2 qualification exam-related types (pass certificate, transcript).
Advance reservation phone reception can be made on weekdays from 9 AM to 6 PM by calling the Provincial Education Office civil complaint office (☎064-1396, 064-710-0114).
Provincial Education Office provides Chuseok [Korean harvest festival] monetary support to 127 student heads of household
(Jeju=Yonhap News) The Jeju Provincial Education Office provided a total of 38.1 million won [approximately $28,600 USD] in monetary support to 127 student heads of household in the province on the 3rd ahead of Chuseok.
The Provincial Education Office regularly provides 'Small Seeds of Love' monetary support to student heads of household, which is formed from small change donations of less than 1,000 won [approximately $0.75 USD] from employee salaries and donations voluntarily contributed by companies and benefactors in the province.
This Chuseok monetary support was provided to 36 elementary school students, 35 middle school students, 55 high school students, and 1 special school student, with 300,000 won [approximately $225 USD] per person.
Superintendent Lee Seok-moon conveyed through a letter, "I hope you will love yourself more with the power of love that many people have sent. I hope you have a peaceful and joyful Chuseok."

{
  "translated_title": "17.7% of Jeonnam Arts High School practical instruction teachers are hagwon directors… 'Concerns over profit-seeking activities'",
  "translated_text": "[Yonhap News file photo]

(Muan=Yonhap News) Reporter Son Sang-won = It has been confirmed that a significant number of practical instruction teachers at Jeonnam Arts High School are hagwon directors, leading to criticism that this violates teacher operation guidelines.

According to instructor status data that the Citizens' Coalition for Educational Equality received from Jeonnam Arts High School on the 30th, 23 out of 130 music, art, and dance instructors (17.7%) were hagwon directors or tutoring center operators.

The Jeonnam Provincial Office of Education's contract teacher operation guidelines prohibit those engaged in occupations that selectively influence students, such as hagwon instructors, from engaging in profit-making activities or holding concurrent positions.

The citizens' coalition expressed concern that having hagwon directors—not just hagwon instructors—teach at schools could, contrary to the positive function of managing practical instruction, indirectly promote their hagwons or encourage the sale of portfolios such as choreography and compositions.

The citizens' coalition reported that the Daegu Metropolitan Office of Education imposed administrative sanctions on an arts high school that hired hagwon instructors to conduct regular classes, and the Gwangju Metropolitan Office of Education also recently decided to review the guideline content following an audit request.

A citizens' coalition official urged, "The Jeonnam Provincial Office of Education should correct the violation of operation guidelines and secure a talent pool of major practical instruction teachers based on public interest to provide balanced educational support for career and college guidance."

{
  "translated_title": "70% of Elementary, Middle, and High School Students Ages 9-17 'Suffer from Time Shortage Due to Studying'",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Seo Han-ki = A survey found that 7 out of 10 Korean elementary, middle, and high school students suffer from time shortage in their daily lives due to studying.

According to the '2018 Comprehensive Survey on Children' report commissioned by the Ministry of Health and Welfare to the Korea Institute for Health and Social Affairs on the 30th, this result emerged from a time poverty survey of 2,219 students ages 9-17 (743 students ages 9-11, 1,476 students ages 12-17).

[Provided by Korea Institute for Health and Social Affairs]

More than 70% of children ages 9-17 responded that they usually lack time (always lack time, sometimes lack time). The higher the age group (12-17 years old), the more cases there were of struggling with time pressure.

Reasons for suffering from time shortage were, in order: school (27.5%), friend relationships and out-of-school activities (27.0%), hagwon or private tutoring classes (23.3%), and self-study (19.6%). Responses related to learning—that is, struggling with time shortage due to studying—accounted for 70.4% of the total.

Youth felt a significant gap between 'desired after-school activities' and 'actual activities' due to time shortage issues. Particularly, responses saying they 'want to' 'play with friends (playgrounds, PC rooms [internet cafes], etc.)' were 18.9% higher than responses saying they 'actually play.'

In contrast, responses saying they are actually doing 'attending hagwon or private tutoring' and 'doing homework at home' were 27.9% and 11.1% higher, respectively, than what they hoped for.

This shows that children's right to play is not being guaranteed, reflecting a situation where an college entrance exam-centered education system dominates our society.

The report emphasized that "in order for children's right to play to establish itself as children's culture in living spaces, the state needs to continuously provide strong support, and various private entities in local communities need to actively develop diverse play programs."

[Provided by Korea Institute for Health and Social Affairs]

{
  "translated_title": "[New Year Interview] Gyeongbuk Education Superintendent Lim Jong-sik: "Self-evaluation through Academic Achievement Certification System"",
  "translated_text": "(Andong=Yonhap News) Reporter Han Mu-seon = Gyeongbuk Provincial Education Superintendent Lim Jong-sik said, "We plan to support individualized, customized learning by introducing a system through the Academic Achievement Certification System where students can evaluate themselves online."
[Provided by Gyeongbuk Provincial Office of Education. Resale and DB prohibited]

Superintendent Lim said in an interview with Yonhap News on the 26th, "Next year, we will increase the number of elementary schools subject to the free school district system and pilot it in middle schools to strengthen the educational competitiveness of small schools and create schools that students seek out on their own."

Regarding government education policies, he also said, "The expansion ratio of regular admissions [university admissions based solely on CSAT scores] should be minimized, and the abolition of autonomous private high schools should be approached carefully considering regional educational conditions."

The following is a Q&A with Superintendent Lim.

-- What was the best project this year and what project left the most regret?

▲ I viewed normalizing school operations as the core driving force to change the future of Gyeongbuk education, and focused on it immediately after taking office. We improved 452 unnecessary or duplicative projects so that school teachers could concentrate on classes and student guidance while staying close to students.

Last July, commemorating the 100th anniversary of the March 1st Movement and the establishment of the Provisional Government, I traveled the independence movement route from Imcheong-gak to Harbin with 55 teachers and high school students. Through this independence movement pilgrimage, we sought to learn the spirit of patriotism and inherit the noble spirit of the March 1st Movement, but I have much regret that many students could not participate due to circumstances.

-- What are the educational measures for students in small rural and fishing village schools?

▲ In preparation for the decline in school-age population, we implemented various policies such as joint educational curricula for small rural and fishing village schools, distinctive educational curricula by school, free school district system for small schools, and certification system for reviving small schools.

In particular, we piloted the 'free school district system for small schools' in 29 elementary schools this year, adjusting school districts so that students from large schools can transfer to small schools without relocating their addresses. As a result, 113 students flowed into small schools—76 new students and 37 transfer students—increasing 9 classes and resolving 9 combined classes.

Next year, we plan to additionally designate 68 elementary schools and pilot the program in middle schools including 2 private and 9 public schools.

-- Parents are very worried about safety due to a recent fire at an elementary school in Andong.

▲ When conducting school construction, we require construction to proceed only after supervision and oversight officials are present. For welding work and other operations with high fire risk, we require teams of two and deploy fire monitors. We thoroughly implement a permit system for fire-handling work and seek to eliminate dryvit exterior finishing materials that pose high fire spread risks.

We conducted comprehensive inspections of fire safety plans at each school and took measures to immediately supplement and correct deficiencies. We designated three or more evacuation sites inside and outside schools, allowing evacuation to optimal locations considering fire size, wind direction, and other factors.

We conduct disaster safety education, including fire safety education through curriculum and creative experiential activities, at least 6 hours twice per semester.
[Provided by Gyeongbuk Provincial Office of Education. Resale and DB prohibited]

-- What are your thoughts on expanding regular admissions and abolishing autonomous private high schools?

▲ Expanding regular admissions is a policy that emerged to ensure fairness in college entrance exams, but expanding regular admissions could create unfairness favoring students in urban areas with good hagwon education infrastructure. Since it conflicts with the direction of future education that must cultivate creative, convergent talent, it would be desirable to minimize the expansion ratio of regular admissions.

Autonomous private high schools have had cases of aberrant operation contrary to their original purpose in some regions like the metropolitan area. Autonomous private high schools in the Gyeongbuk region operate distinctive educational curricula and are contributing to nurturing regional talent, achieving perfect scores in constituent satisfaction surveys among this year's re-designation evaluation items. I judge that rather than wholesale abolition due to policy changes, there is a need to carefully consider educational consumer opinions and regional educational conditions from an educational perspective.

-- What are your plans for free meals and free education?

▲ This year we implemented free meals for all elementary, middle, and special schools, so the current free meal support ratio reaches about 85% of all elementary, middle, and high school students. Next year we plan to provide free meals to high school seniors, in 2021 to high school sophomores and seniors, and in 2022 to all high school students.

Regarding free education, starting from the second semester this year, we supported 9 billion won [approximately $6.8 million USD] in tuition and school operation support fees for high school seniors. Next year we will expand the target to high school sophomores and seniors, supporting a total of 51.5 billion won [approximately $39 million USD]. In 2021, we plan to provide free education to all high school students, supporting 74.6 billion won [approximately $56 million USD].
[Yonhap News file photo]

-- What are next year's main projects?

▲ Next year, we plan to support individualized, customized achievement by introducing an online evaluation system where students challenge themselves through operating the 'Challenge! Academic Achievement Certification System.' We seek to nurture Gyeongbuk people who grow with warm hearts and healthy bodies through operating schools with poetic resonance, proper walking, and other programs.

We will strengthen educational public nature by expanding free education and free meals, and achieve early completion of earthquake-resistant reinforcement construction and asbestos removal construction. We seek to actively promote the free school district system for small schools to create safe school environments and realize educational welfare.

We will continue school operation normalization projects to create schools where teachers can concentrate on classes and student guidance, and seek to create a school self-governance culture where autonomy and responsibility go together.

(Busan=Yonhap News) Reporter Cho Jung-ho = At the opening ceremony of the AI-based Future Education Center held at Tongmyong University in Busan on the 12th, Tongmyong University President Jeong Hong-seop and Busan Metropolitan Office of Education Superintendent Kim Seok-jun examine the AI education system. {
  "translated_title": "[Yonhap Editorial] University Admission Regular Track Expansion Must Not Shake the Foundation of Public Education Normalization",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) The government has announced a 'plan to strengthen fairness in university admissions' centered on expanding the regular track [jeongsi] based on CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) and reforming the comprehensive student record evaluation system [hakjong]. The Ministry of Education announced on the 28th that it will have 16 Seoul universities increase the number of students selected through CSAT-based regular track to 40% or more by the 2023 academic year. The universities subject to regular track expansion are Konkuk University, Kyung Hee University, Korea University, Kwangwoon University, Dongguk University, Sogang University, University of Seoul, Seoul National University, Seoul Women's University, Sungkyunkwan University, Sookmyung Women's University, Soongsil University, Yonsei University, Chung-Ang University, Hankuk University of Foreign Studies, and Hanyang University. Among these 16 universities, the 2021 academic year regular track selection comprises 14,787 students, which is 29% of the total 51,013 recruitment slots. If this proportion is raised to 40%, regular track selection will increase by 5,625 students to a total of 24,012.

While the universities targeted for regular track expansion are 16 Seoul-based institutions, the ripple effect is expected to spread to other universities as well. This is because the Ministry of Education plans to link regular track expansion with the 'High School Education Contribution University Support Project.' This essentially means forcing regular track expansion by using financial support for universities as leverage. Nominally, this support project aims to provide financial assistance to universities that simplify admission processes and enhance fairness and transparency. However, universities designated for regular track expansion must submit plans to the Ministry of Education to achieve a 40% regular track ratio by the 2023 academic year in order to participate in this project. Universities that depend on government financial support have no choice but to accept this 'coercive measure.' Even universities not designated as targets will inevitably have to consider regular track expansion while watching others' moves. This is why the education sector is voicing concerns that if regular track expansion spreads in this manner, problem-solving-oriented classes will revive in school settings, damaging public education normalization.

The measures to strengthen fairness in the comprehensive evaluation system [hakjong] also seem to fall short of resonating with parents and students. The core of this plan is to gradually reduce the reflection of non-curricular areas of school records and personal statements in university admissions, completely abolishing them by the 2024 academic year. However, there is strong criticism that no effective measures are visible to address the fundamental reason for distrust in the comprehensive evaluation system—that the quality of student record writing varies from teacher to teacher. The measures presented by the Ministry of Education to resolve gaps between teachers, such as distributing standard guidelines for student record entries, are said to be insufficient to wash away public distrust that 'you're doomed if you get the wrong teacher.'

The Ministry of Education announced this fairness enhancement plan exactly 100 days after allegations surfaced regarding the university admission of former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's daughter. However, it appears insufficient to gain the sympathy of the majority of citizens. The biggest dysfunction of regular track expansion is the high possibility that side effects of exam-oriented education, such as public education disruption and hagwon education [private tutoring industry] promotion, will be repeated. This is why some in the education sector criticize that 'regular track expansion is an anti-educational declaration of abandoning public education that foreshadows classroom collapse.' The comprehensive evaluation system reform is also facing harsh criticism as being intended to quell public opinion over the 'Cho Kuk incident.' The Ministry of Education should heed these criticisms and not blindly push forward with regular track expansion in a way that would harm the foundation of public education normalization. We also hope for additional supplementary measures for the comprehensive evaluation system reform. In particular, if the Ministry of Education has been focused on short-term measures to ensure fairness until the 2024 university admissions, it should now present substantial measures for high school education normalization from a long-term perspective. The blueprint consists of the 'high school system reorganization' and 'high school credit system' that were announced in the early days of the Moon Jae-in administration with a target of 2025. We hope the Ministry of Education will revise and supplement these two pillars to present a long-term vision for 'future education' aimed at fostering creative talent.

Tips: KakaoTalk okjebo <Copyright holder (c) Yonhap News, unauthorized reproduction-redistribution, AI learning and utilization prohibited> November 28, 2019 1:50 PM transmission November 28, 2019 1:50 PM transmission"

{
  "translated_title": "Ministry of Education: "To Substantiate Education, Academic Credential-Centered Society Must Be Improved" (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education Yoo Eun-hye speaks at the '2019 Education Sector National Agenda Mid-term Review Meeting' held at the Government Complex Sejong on the 11th. 2019.11.11 [Provided by Ministry of Education. Resale and DB prohibited] photo@yna.co.kr

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = An official government public opinion survey found that to substantiate elementary, middle, and high school education, not only should the education system be overhauled, but the academic credential-centered social system must also be improved.

The Ministry of Education announced these survey results at the Moon Jae-in administration's first-half education sector national agenda mid-term review meeting held at the Government Complex Sejong on the afternoon of the 11th. The survey was conducted by the Korean Educational Development Institute targeting over 4,000 adult men and women nationwide from August to September this year.

When asked 'What policies should be prioritized to restore trust in education?' in the survey, the most common response was "ensuring fairness in admissions, academic affairs, and hiring" (49.5%).

When asked 'What are the tasks for substantiating elementary and secondary education?', 27.0% of respondents answered "improving the academic credential-centered social system." 19.5% of respondents suggested "diversifying teaching methods."

In other words, the Ministry of Education explained that ensuring fairness in admissions and other areas is a policy that must naturally be pursued for trust recovery, and to substantiate public education, ultimately academic credentialism and other aspects of society as a whole must be improved - this is the meaning of these survey results.

45.2% of survey respondents answered 'average' regarding the introduction of the high school credit system. Regarding high school system restructuring such as abolishing autonomous private high schools and foreign language high schools, 50.9% chose 'support.'

When asked 'Is university education fulfilling its function of nurturing talent that society needs?', 55.4% answered 'generally not.'

The most common response for university education policies the government should prioritize was "reducing tuition burden" (33.0%).

Kim Cheon-hong, Ministry of Education Policy Planning Officer, who announced the survey results, said, "Ultimately, to solve education problems, it appears we must advance to social system reforms such as resolving labor and wage gaps," adding "There is a need to strengthen inter-ministry collaboration through social affairs ministerial meetings."

At the performance report meeting that day, the Ministry of Education evaluated itself as having achieved results in strengthening public nature from early childhood education to university education during the first half of the Moon administration's term.

Full national support for daycare center free childcare (Nuri Course) costs, expansion of 1,788 national and public kindergarten classes, introduction of the national accounting management system (EduFine) for private kindergartens, and raising qualification standards for private kindergarten principals were among the achievements the Ministry of Education cited for itself.

The Ministry of Education also explained that it has legislated an advance notice system requiring university admission systems to be announced four years in advance, and is pursuing strengthening university admission fairness by establishing new regulations for admissions officers to avoid and exclude relatives.

The Ministry of Education added that it is also pursuing school space innovation projects in preparation for future education, asbestos removal from schools and air purification device installation, and educational governance reorganization such as establishing a National Education Committee.

Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education Yoo Eun-hye said, "Countless challenges remain for which policy alternatives are not easy to find, such as hagwon education costs, school violence, student suicide, and guaranteeing basic academic ability," adding "I will work with the attitude of 우공이산 [yugong-isan: a person who does one thing consistently can move mountains]."
