```json
{
  "translated_title": "Foreign language high schools after 33 years, autonomous private high schools after 24 years to disappear... "Second high school equalization"",
  "translated_text": "[Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = The government has decided to completely eliminate three types of high schools: foreign language high schools, international high schools, and autonomous private high schools.

The Ministry of Education announced on the 7th a "plan to resolve high school hierarchization" that includes deleting the operational basis for foreign language high schools, international high schools, and autonomous private high schools from the Elementary and Secondary Education Act enforcement ordinance, converting them all to regular high schools in 2025.

If this plan is implemented, foreign language high schools introduced in 1992 will disappear after 33 years, international high schools will disappear after 27 years since their 1998 introduction, and autonomous private high schools will disappear after 24 years since their 2001 introduction.

◇ Sharp turn from 'selective, gradual abolition' to 'complete abolition'

The conversion of foreign language high schools, international high schools, and autonomous private high schools to regular high schools was included in the Moon Jae-in administration's national agenda.

The government's original plan was not the complete abolition of foreign language high schools, autonomous private high schools, and international high schools announced this time, but rather to selectively convert only schools operating contrary to their founding purposes to regular high schools in stages.

In November 2017, the government announced a "3-stage roadmap for high school system restructuring" that would significantly restrict the student selection rights of foreign language high schools, autonomous private high schools, and international high schools through high school admission system improvements, then convert schools operating contrary to their founding purposes to regular high schools through operational performance evaluations (re-designation evaluations), and subsequently discuss high school system restructuring plans at the National Education Council.

However, this year's autonomous private high school operational evaluations caused extreme confusion due to pros and cons debates plus different evaluation standards by region, leading to growing support for the argument that if autonomous private high schools were to be converted to regular high schools, it would be better for the Ministry of Education to take responsibility and revise laws to proceed all at once.

The recent 'Cho Kuk incident' added fuel to this fire.

Former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's daughter was able to participate in writing a medical paper while attending a foreign language high school with help from a medical professor parent from the same school.

Public outrage erupted as it became apparent that children from families with social status and economic means like former Minister Cho's family have relatively high rates of advancing to foreign language high schools or autonomous private high schools, and these students easily enjoy 'resume-building' experiences compared to regular high school students through help from their own parents or friends' parents.

Education authorities cite as the main reason for deciding to completely abolish foreign language high schools, international high schools, and autonomous private high schools the full implementation of the high school credit system in 2025, where high school students will choose classes they want to take like university students.

Once the credit system is implemented, students will take different classes from each other, making current relative evaluation of school records [GPA] virtually impossible, necessitating a shift to absolute evaluation methods.

The transition to absolute evaluation of school records [GPA] could be 'favorable' to foreign language high schools, international high schools, and autonomous private high schools, which are evaluated as having difficulty achieving good school records [GPA] under relative evaluation because excellent students are concentrated there. If only the disadvantage in school records [GPA] is resolved, foreign language high schools, international high schools, and autonomous private high schools would become absolutely advantageous in university admissions. This point led to arguments that these schools should be abolished before implementing the high school credit system.

[Photo caption: In 2017, members of the civic education group No More Worry About Private Education hold a rally in front of the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education in Jongno-gu, Seoul, advocating for the abolition of autonomous private high schools. [Yonhap News file photo]]

◇ Specialized high schools and autonomous private high schools that started as 'supplements' to high school equalization... creating cracks in the spirit of equalization

Foreign language high schools, international high schools, and autonomous private high schools all emerged as 'supplements' to high school equalization.

Around the implementation of high school equalization in 1974, concerns poured out from inside and outside the education community that students' academic abilities would undergo 'downward leveling.' Criticism was also raised that the government had abandoned excellence education, namely 'elite education.'

Against this backdrop of concerns and criticism, science high schools were established in 1983 and foreign language high schools (then called foreign language schools) in 1984. Science high schools were designated as specialized high schools in 1986, and foreign language high schools in 1992. International high schools were established as specialized high schools in 1998.

Autonomous private high schools were first introduced in 2001 under the name 'independent private high schools' during the Kim Dae-jung administration.

The plan to create private high schools that would receive broad autonomy in curriculum organization and operation in exchange for not receiving financial support to expand students' school choice was already presented in the 'Education Reform Plan for Establishing a New Education System' (May 31 Education Reform Plan) announced in 1995 during the Kim Young-sam administration. The May 31 Education Reform Plan is evaluated as the blueprint for the current education system.

Specialized high schools and autonomous private high schools were heated topics of controversy from their inception. These schools are paradoxical entities that serve as supplements to resolve the side effects of high school equalization while simultaneously creating cracks in the spirit of high school equalization, which aimed to ease entrance exam competition and realize holistic education.

Specialized high schools and autonomous private high schools are also cited as main culprits in fueling early hagwon education [hagwon education] fever. They also face criticism for becoming channels through which certain classes who can afford expensive tuition and have the leisure to focus on their children's education pass down their social and economic status.

Seoul Metropolitan Superintendent of Education Cho Hee-yeon has even defined the abolition of autonomous private high schools as 'second high school equalization.' This means autonomous private high schools function like the 'prestigious high schools' that required passing difficult exams for admission until the 1970s.

According to hagwon education [hagwon education] cost statistics released by Statistics Korea last March, as of last year, the hagwon education [hagwon education] participation rates of middle school students seeking to advance to specialized high schools and autonomous high schools including autonomous private high schools were 82.4% and 78.8% respectively, higher than those hoping to advance to regular high schools (69.5%). Average monthly hagwon education [hagwon education] costs were also higher for those hoping to advance to specialized high schools (493,000 won [approximately $370 USD]) and autonomous high schools (425,000 won [approximately $320 USD]) than for regular high school aspirants (296,000 won [approximately $220 USD]).

Those advocating for the abolition of specialized high schools and autonomous private high schools also argue that these schools have caused 'devastation' of regular high schools by using their student selection rights to sweep up 'excellent students.'

Indeed, comparing Seoul area high schools by type, the ratio of new students whose middle school records [GPA] ranked in the top 10% is 44.4% for 7 foreign language and international high schools, 18.5% for 23 autonomous private high schools, and 8.5% for regular high schools. This confirms the hierarchy of 'foreign language·international high schools > autonomous private high schools > regular high schools.'

[Photo caption: Parents of 8 Seoul autonomous private high schools that received scores below re-designation standards in this year's autonomous private high school operational performance evaluation (re-designation evaluation) and face designation cancellation crisis hold a protest rally. [Yonhap News file photo]]
```

```json
{
  "translated_title": "Government: "Foreign Language High Schools and Autonomous Private High Schools to Convert to Regular High Schools in 2025"...Dismantling High School Hierarchy",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Kim Seung-du = Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yu Eun-hye (center) announces the 'Plan to Eliminate High School Hierarchy and Strengthen Regular High School Educational Capacity' at the Government Complex Seoul on the afternoon of the 7th, which includes converting autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to regular high schools all at once in 2025. From right: Gyeonggi Provincial Education Superintendent Lee Jae-jeong, Deputy Prime Minister Yu, and Sejong City Education Superintendent Choi Kyo-jin. kimsdoo@yna.co.kr

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Park Seong-jin, Lee Jae-young, Lee Hyo-seok = Starting in 2025, when current fourth-grade elementary school students enter high school, autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools will all disappear and convert to regular high schools all at once.

Among gifted schools and special purpose high schools, science high schools, arts high schools, and sports high schools will not convert to regular high schools after 2025 and will be maintained.

Following the 'Cho Kuk scandal' [referring to the 2019 corruption scandal involving former Justice Minister Cho Kuk's family's college admissions irregularities], a decision has been made to abolish foreign language high schools and autonomous private high schools after 20-30 years in order to strengthen fairness in high school education, but criticism is also being raised that this overlooks the necessity of elite education.

Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yu Eun-hye announced the 'Plan to Eliminate High School Hierarchy' containing these details at the Government Complex Seoul in Jongno-gu, Seoul on the 7th.

The Ministry of Education will revise the enforcement decree of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act by the end of this year to convert autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools to regular high schools starting March 2025, when the high school credit system is introduced.

Special admission privileges for regular high schools (49 schools) that select students nationwide will also be abolished.

The Ministry of Education's investigation results on the student record comprehensive evaluation system at major universities announced on the 5th confirmed hierarchical ranking by high school type among science/gifted schools, foreign language high schools, autonomous private high schools, and regular high schools. Building on these facts, the abolition of foreign language high schools, autonomous private high schools, and international high schools, which have been criticized for promoting high school hierarchy, has been confirmed.

With the conversion of foreign language high schools and autonomous private high schools, which performed elite education after regional prestigious high schools disappeared due to high school equalization in the 1970s, all converting to regular high schools, substantial 'complete high school equalization' is expected to be realized.

On the afternoon of September 20, parents and students listen to lectures at a Seoul Autonomous Private High School Association information session held at Dongsung High School in Jongno-gu, Seoul. [Yonhap News file photo]

After 2025, when autonomous private high schools and foreign language high schools convert to regular high schools, existing foreign language high schools such as Seoul Daewon Foreign Language High School can continue using their school names while operating their specialized foreign language curricula as before.

However, student selection authority will disappear and the system will change to one where students apply and are assigned based on student choice, like other schools in Seoul. Monthly tuition of around 1 million won [approximately $750 USD] will also disappear, and free education will be implemented like other high schools.

Students who enter autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools before the 2025 conversion to regular high schools will maintain their status until graduation.

Regarding the background for the wholesale conversion to regular high schools, the Ministry of Education explained, "Autonomous private high schools, foreign language high schools, and international high schools are intensifying hagwon education and causing educational opportunity inequality based on parents' income," adding "We decided on conversion to regular high schools to secure admission fairness and prepare for future high school education."

According to Ministry of Education survey results, based on last year's data, the average hagwon education costs by desired high school type showed foreign language and international high schools at 1.7 times that of regular high schools, and autonomous private high schools at 1.4 times.

However, anxiety has also grown that the next administration could easily reverse this, as the government is drastically reorganizing a high school system that has continued for decades through merely revising enforcement decrees.

A Ministry of Education official said, "Opinion polls showed over 50% support for abolishing autonomous private high schools and foreign language high schools. It would be difficult for (the next government to) reverse this," adding "Young generations in particular are very sensitive to discrimination."

While the government will not convert science high schools and gifted schools to regular high schools, it plans to improve selection methods by abolishing written assessments (problem-solving type exams) at gifted schools.

The government plans to resolve educational inequality by investing approximately 2.2 trillion won [approximately $1.65 billion USD] over five years to strengthen the competitiveness of regular high schools instead of abolishing autonomous private high schools and foreign language high schools.

The Ministry of Education will also expand subject-specialized schools that expand course selection rights according to student levels and aptitudes and provide intensive learning opportunities in specific fields such as science, languages, arts, and software.

The Ministry of Education plans to steadily strengthen the educational capacity of regular high schools to create customized educational conditions for all students before implementing the high school credit system.

Following partial revision of elementary and secondary school curricula in 2020, comprehensive revision in 2022 will operate a credit system-type curriculum starting from the 2025 school year where high school students choose classes like university students.

Deputy Prime Minister Yu Eun-hye stated, "The hierarchical high school system not only creates unfairness throughout high school education but is also not a form that matches future education, so we decided to boldly improve it this time," adding "We will push forward with institutional improvements without setbacks."

Deputy Prime Minister Yu said, "We plan to support over 2 trillion won [approximately $1.5 billion USD] over five years to revitalize regular high schools," adding "We will operate a tentatively named 'High School Education Innovation Task Force' headed by the Deputy Prime Minister to take responsible care of this."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Young-seok = The fact that admission rates for the student record comprehensive evaluation system, which has raised fairness controversies in university admissions, are hierarchically ranked in the order of special purpose high schools, autonomous private high schools, and regular high schools has been confirmed through Ministry of Education investigation results. Ministry of Education Vice Minister Park Baek-beom announced the results of a student record comprehensive evaluation system survey of 13 major universities including Seoul National University, Yonsei University, and Korea University over four years from 2016-2019 school years at the Government Complex Seoul on the 5th. zeroground@yna.co.kr
```

{
  "translated_title": "[Yonhap Editorial] Problems with 'Comprehensive Student Record Admissions' Don't Justify Pushing Through Expanded Regular Admissions",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) On the 5th, the Ministry of Education announced the results of a fact-finding survey that starkly revealed various problems with the Comprehensive Student Record Admissions (Hakjong) system among university admission methods. This was the first survey conducted since the admission officer system was introduced in 2007 and developed into Hakjong, 12 years later. The Ministry of Education formed an investigation team to analyze university admission data from 13 universities including Seoul National University, Yonsei University, and Korea University for the 2016-2019 academic years - universities with high Hakjong selection ratios or many admissions from specific high schools. This survey has drawn extraordinary attention as it emerged during the government's process of promoting expanded regular admissions plans.

The most notable finding in the fact-finding survey is the entrenchment of hierarchical structures by high school type. Looking at acceptance rates by high school type, science and gifted high schools had the highest rate at 26.1%, followed by foreign language and international high schools at 13.9%, private high schools at 10.2%, and general high schools at 9.1%. The Hakjong acceptance rate for science and gifted high schools was nearly three times higher than that of general high schools. By high school location, Seoul students had much higher Hakjong selection ratios than provincial students. It was also revealed that some high schools improperly provided universities with past graduates' university admission records or students' language test scores. However, the so-called high school ranking system - where schools are graded to evaluate students - was not confirmed in this survey, leading to suggestions that additional investigation is needed. There were also 366 violations involving content in personal statements and recommendation letters that revealed parents' socioeconomic status, and 228 personal statements suspected of plagiarism. In special talent admissions, cases were confirmed where language abilities were set as qualification and evaluation criteria, resulting in students from specific high schools comprising 70% of successful candidates in some departments.

While the fact-finding survey revealed various problems with Hakjong, this is not grounds for blindly pushing through expanded regular admissions. If regular admissions are rashly expanded under the pretext of university admission fairness, it will drive high school curricula into dysfunction and undermine the normalization of public education. There is a high possibility that the side effects of exam-focused education that we painfully experienced in the past will be repeated. The biggest dysfunction of expanding regular admissions is that it promotes hagwon education, leading to educational inequality. It is widely known that regular admissions is a system favorable to children from high-income families. There are survey results from various education-related institutions showing that income and scores are proportional when comparing monthly average household income with test-takers' CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] average scores. This is why the Korea Educational Development Institute's '2018 Education Public Opinion Survey' showed that high-income earners with monthly incomes of 6 million won [approximately $4,500 USD] or more overwhelmingly prefer CSAT-focused regular admissions. There are great concerns in school settings that problem-solving classes will increase instead of presentation and discussion. Future education aimed at nurturing creative talent will be pushed to the back burner.

University admission systems involve different perspectives and complexly intertwined interests among students, parents, teachers, as well as various education-related organizations and institutions. It is not something to be handled rashly. In particular, frequent changes could shake education from its very foundation. Recently, over 1,400 people from various sectors issued a declaration stating, 'It is deeply regrettable and concerning to attempt to solve Korea's educational problems that unexpectedly emerged from the Cho Kuk incident through CSAT-focused regular admission expansion.' The Council of Superintendents of Education also issued a statement calling for the immediate cessation of regular admission expansion. The Ministry of Education should listen to these critical voices. We hope that the 'University Admission Fairness Enhancement Plan' to be announced this month will present regular admission expansion ratios and Hakjong improvement measures that the majority of citizens can support.

{
  "translated_title": "Progressive education groups: "Must withdraw expansion of regular admissions... concerns over rote learning"",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = Progressive education groups including KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) have once again urged the government to withdraw its policy of expanding regular university admissions.

KTU, Good Teacher Movement, World Without Worry About Hagwon Education, and 67 other education groups held a press conference on the 28th in front of Cheong Wa Dae's Sarangchae and demanded that the government "withdraw the regular admissions expansion policy that goes against the normalization of public education," stating that "expanding regular admissions centered on CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) would return us to the past of rote learning and problem-solving focused classes."

They argued that "regular admissions is a selection method where hagwon education or parents' socioeconomic status has more influence than other admission types" and "the government should not be obsessed with reforming the university entrance system, but should pursue genuine educational reform that resolves the phenomenon of privilege being passed down through generations via education."

Progressive education groups immediately expressed opposition when President Moon Jae-in announced in his parliamentary policy speech on the 22nd that he would pursue "university entrance reform including increasing the proportion of regular admissions."

The Ministry of Education plans to announce measures to strengthen university admission fairness, including increasing the proportion of regular admissions, next month.

{
  "translated_title": "National Education Council Chairman: "Essay-type CSAT should be considered for educational fairness" (Comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "(Goyang=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = Kim Jin-kyung, chairman of the presidential National Education Council, delivers a speech on 'Directions and Key Agendas for Establishing the 2030 Future Education System' at the Korea-OECD International Education Conference held at KINTEX in Goyang, Gyeonggi Province on the 23rd. 2019.10.23

(Sejong·Goyang=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Hyo-seok and Lee Jae-young = Kim Jin-kyung, chairman of the National Education Council, a presidential advisory body, argued that essay and descriptive questions should be introduced to the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) and school autonomy should be strengthened to secure 'future education' and educational fairness.

Chairman Kim made this argument in a keynote speech at the 'Korea-OECD International Education Conference' jointly hosted by 11 organizations including the National Education Council, Ministry of Education, and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) on the 23rd.

In his speech titled 'Directions and Key Agendas for Establishing the 2030 Future Education System,' Chairman Kim emphasized that academic ability should be redefined as 'ability to live' in accordance with the future intelligent information society, and the education system should be redesigned accordingly.

He said, "'Internal fairness' in education means providing equal opportunities to develop capabilities to prepare for the future and ensuring that the state takes responsibility for guaranteeing the minimum capabilities needed to maintain a human-like life," adding, "We must strengthen this fairness to alleviate and resolve conflicts surrounding education."

He continued, "Educational problems in our society, particularly controversies over university admissions processes, are close to interest disputes that judge whether the rules of the game for status acquisition are advantageous or disadvantageous, and this is an issue of 'external fairness' in education," pointing out that "fairness disputes related to mobilizing 'forces outside school' such as parents or hagwon education are matters of interest coordination, so there are no short-term solutions."

As a mid- to long-term solution to resolve interest disputes over external fairness in education, Chairman Kim proposed introducing essay and descriptive questions that measure future capabilities to the CSAT and strengthening school community autonomy.

He explained, "If essay and descriptive questions that can gauge students' future capabilities are introduced and the reliability of the CSAT increases, a natural balance will be formed in the selection methods chosen by some universities," adding, "If parents and residents can look into schools, controversies over fairness regarding the comprehensive school record admission system will also be alleviated."

Chairman Kim also proposed adjusting the educational period for elementary, middle, and high schools, establishing a 'career exploration year' at ages 14-15, and creating new teacher training systems such as teacher professional graduate schools.

Andreas Schleicher, OECD Education Director, followed Chairman Kim with a speech titled 'Analysis of Korean Education from the OECD Education 2030 Learning Framework.'

Director Schleicher noted that Korean students have low life satisfaction compared to their academic achievement and suggested, "The criteria for student success should be redefined from academic achievement to improving 'quality of life.'"

He first revealed the contents of the 'OECD Physical Education International Comparative Analysis Report' on this day.

According to this report, Korea has the third-highest school physical education class hours among 18 countries and regions worldwide, after Turkey and Chile, but relatively many students reported having no physical activity outside school, with large gender gaps.

Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye said in her opening remarks before the keynote speech, "While there are certainly points to overcome, such as excessive entrance exam competition, no one can deny that education has been the driving force of national development," adding, "As the flow of change such as the Fourth Industrial Revolution has brought challenges and crises to the education system, we must gather wisdom to turn these into opportunities."

The Korea-OECD International Education Conference continues for three days from this day until the 25th.

This conference will feature the '2030 Future Education Citizens' Roundtable Discussion' where about 400 citizens propose future education agendas, and the 'Declaration of Educational and Cultural Rights for Children and Youth that Should be Guaranteed as Democratic Citizens' created by about 100 children and youth over five months.

OECD officials plan to visit Changdeok Girls' Middle School, Yongsan Technical High School, and Doseon High School in Seoul on the 25th with Chairman Kim Jin-kyung to examine Korea's educational innovation cases.

{
  "translated_title": "[Presidential State of the Union Address] Education sector expresses 'concerns' over mention of expanding regular admissions...Parents divided in support and opposition (Comprehensive Report 2)",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Ha Sa-heon = President Moon Jae-in delivers a state of the union address on next year's budget proposal at the National Assembly on the morning of the 22nd. 2019.10.22 toadboy@yna.co.kr

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = Regarding President Moon Jae-in's statement in his National Assembly state of the union address on the 22nd that he would expand regular admissions centered on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) in university admissions, teacher organizations and universities expressed significant concerns.

Teacher organizations generally opposed expanding regular admissions, emphasizing that education reform should focus on 'normalizing public education.'

KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) stated in a commentary that day: "Following the mention of university admissions system reform in September, we must not repeat situations where the foundation of admissions policy is shaken by a single presidential statement. Discussing university admissions system reform that is impossible within the current Moon Jae-in administration's term is neither desirable nor effective. The focus of discussion should be on normalizing public education."

A KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) official also expressed concern, saying: "If regular admissions are expanded, schools will return to CSAT-focused, EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) problem-solving-focused education."

The Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations also criticized: "Admissions system reform cannot be solved by adjusting the ratio of regular and rolling admissions, but should be adjusted in the process of preparing measures to resolve 'educational inequality' and secure 'fairness' that our society faces. However, the president's statement today will again plunge the education sector into confusion through regular-rolling admissions ratio debates."

The teachers' union argued: "Expanding regular admissions not only makes it difficult to realize the value of 'fairness,' but also brings about hagwon education fever, forced autonomous study, and problem-solving education, which does not align with the direction of innovative education being pursued nationwide."

The Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations (KFTA) stated in a position paper: "We sympathize to some extent with expanding regular admissions in terms of resolving the problem of the regular-rolling admissions ratio being excessively skewed to one side and achieving balance."

However, KFTA pointed out: "The president's official mention of admissions reform including regular admissions expansion through his National Assembly state of the union address is concerning as it reveals discord between the party, government, and Blue House and only causes confusion and disruption in educational settings including students and parents."

KFTA demanded that the Ministry of Education "clearly reveal the true intention behind the president's statement on expanding regular admissions to prevent unnecessary confusion and controversy," emphasizing that admissions reform should not be swayed by political rhetoric or dominated by the loud claims of a vocal minority.

Universities showed largely negative reactions.

An official from the Korean Council for University Education (KCUE), a university association, criticized: "Expanding regular admissions without any consultation with universities, which are the main agents of student selection, amounts to making policy based on public opinion. University admissions should be left to university autonomy."

One university official worried: "As the school-age population decreases, regional universities have been competing to secure students first in rolling admissions, but regional universities will face another crisis."

Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education Superintendent Cho Hee-yeon also expressed a negative stance on expanding regular admissions, saying: "Our (education office) position is that student record comprehensive evaluation should be improved as student record comprehensive evaluation itself, and there is no need to connect it with CSAT expansion."

Superintendent Cho explained: "While complementary measures are necessary regarding individual universities secretly applying high school ranking systems and misusing student record comprehensive evaluation as a tool for selecting students from special purpose high schools, we oppose taking this to a general CSAT expansion argument."

Parents generally showed welcoming reactions, saying it was "justice prevailing."

Park So-young, representative of the Movement Headquarters for Correcting Education, said: "Parents have been demanding regular admissions expansion for two years, but the current government ignored it and finally listened. While it's welcome news, I hope it becomes an opportunity to correct actual field suffering rather than being for 'general election purposes' or a 'political show.'"

A high school student parent, Mr. Jeong (48), living in Songpa-gu, Seoul, raised his voice saying: "Yesterday when Seoul National University said it would strengthen interviews instead of expanding regular admissions (if extracurricular areas are abolished in student record comprehensive evaluation), I was angry thinking they still haven't come to their senses even after seeing the 'Cho Kuk incident.' Regular admissions must be expanded starting immediately next year."

However, even among parents, there were opposing opinions on expanding regular admissions depending on their children's school records [GPA].

[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

hyo@yna.co.kr

{
  "translated_title": "KAIST, Dongguk University and 3 Other Universities Violate Advanced Learning Prohibition Law in Essay and Oral Exams",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by KAIST]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = Five universities including Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) and Dongguk University were found to have violated the advanced learning prohibition law in university-specific tests for the 2019 academic year admissions conducted at the end of last year.

The Ministry of Education announced on the morning of the 16th that it held a Curriculum Normalization Review Committee meeting and confirmed corrective orders for five universities: Daejeon University, Dongguk University (Seoul), Jungwon University, KAIST, and Korea Polytechnic University.

The Ministry of Education establishes investigation, research, and improvement measures related to advanced education through the Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation's Advanced Education Prevention Research Center, based on the Act on the Promotion of Normalization of Public Education and Regulation of Preliminary Education (Public Education Normalization Act, commonly known as the Advanced Learning Prohibition Law).

The Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation's Advanced Education Prevention Research Center has been conducting advanced learning impact assessments targeting universities with university-specific tests such as essay-writing exam and oral examination admissions since the 2016 academic year.

This year, 53 universities underwent evaluation. A total of 107 people participated in the evaluation, including institute researchers and teachers and professors with experience in CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) and mock exam question writing.

The final results went through a clarification procedure and were then reviewed and decided by the Curriculum Normalization Review Committee established under the Public Education Normalization Act. The committee is chaired by the Vice Minister of Education and consists of about 15 members including Ministry of Education officials and other experts, as well as parent organization representatives.

Looking at the violation details of the five universities caught this year, KAIST violated the Public Education Normalization Act in essay-writing exam admissions, while the other four universities violated it in oral interview admissions.

Daejeon University in science (life sciences), Dongguk University in mathematics, Jungwon University in science (physics), KAIST in science (life sciences), and Korea Polytechnic University in mathematics each posed one question that exceeded the scope of the high school curriculum.

The specific content of how each university violated the curriculum scope was not disclosed.

The Ministry of Education ordered the five universities to take corrective measures to prevent recurrence of violations and required them to submit result reports on their implementation plans for recurrence prevention measures, including strengthened question verification measures, by March next year.

If violations are detected for two consecutive years in advanced learning impact assessments, administrative and financial penalties are imposed, including partial suspension of admission quotas and point deductions in evaluations for university support projects contributing to high school education.

This year, no universities were caught for two consecutive years. Last year, three universities were caught: Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST), Dongguk University (Gyeongju), and Korea University of Technology and Education.

Kim Seong-geun, Director of the Ministry of Education's School Innovation Support Office, said, "We plan to strengthen training for university admissions officials to ensure that university-specific tests do not induce excessive advanced learning and hagwon education."

{
  "translated_title": "Education community divided over '2025 mass conversion of autonomous private high schools to regular high schools'",
  "translated_text": "On the 6th of last month, at a restaurant in Yeouido, Seoul, a closed-door ruling party-government-Blue House meeting on 'directions for university admissions system improvement' was held, where participants including Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye discussed university admissions system improvement measures including enhancing transparency in the comprehensive student record evaluation system (hakjong). [Yonhap News file photo]

(Sejong·Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Hyo-seok and Lee Jae-young = The education community has responded to the government's plan to convert autonomous private high schools (jasago), foreign language high schools, and international high schools all at once into regular high schools in March 2025, calling it "an expected course of action." However, opinions were divided by organization.

According to the Democratic Party of Korea on the 14th, the Ministry of Education discussed plans to collectively convert jasago, foreign language high schools, and international high schools into regular high schools in 2025 at a ruling party-government-Blue House consultation meeting on the 18th of last month. The Ministry of Education said it would revise the Elementary and Secondary Education Act enforcement decree at the end of this year or early next year for the mass conversion.

The government is citing the full introduction of the high school credit system in the 2025 school year as justification for the need for mass conversion. The high school credit system, where students choose classes they want to take, must be implemented together with 'absolute evaluation of high school records' (achievement evaluation), and if absolute evaluation of school records is implemented, jasago and similar schools are likely to gain a very advantageous position over regular high schools in university admissions.

Lee Man-gi, director of the Uway Education Evaluation Research Institute and university admissions expert, explained, "To introduce the high school credit system, absolute evaluation of high school records must be implemented," adding "With absolute evaluation of school records, jasago and similar schools would become greatly advantageous, so the credit system cannot be introduced without eliminating jasago and similar schools."

Progressive-leaning superintendents and education organizations have consistently argued for revising laws to convert jasago and similar schools to regular high schools all at once.

Especially as major confusion arose during this year's re-designation evaluation (operational performance evaluation), voices calling for mass conversion have grown louder to prevent such confusion from recurring.

Jeon Kyung-won, director of the Chamgyoyuk [True Education] Research Institute at KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization), said, "The government has set the right direction for now," explaining "If jasago and similar schools are not converted to regular high schools before the full introduction of the credit system, the situation would become unmanageable later."

He analyzed, "I understand that as applicants decrease, voices saying it's difficult are emerging from within jasago as well," adding "(The government plan) aligns with the current trend of jasago wanting to convert to regular high schools due to financial problems and other issues."

Koo Bon-chang, policy director at Saegyoyukgeokjeongeomneunsegsang [World Without Worry About Private Education], said, "The government plan is reasonable in that it set a 'grace period' to convert to regular high schools in 2025 after revising laws at the end of this year or early next year," adding "I evaluate this as a plan moving toward 'upward equalization' where each regular high school operates diverse curricula through the credit system, rather than 'educational diversification' through the high school system."

On the other hand, Cho Seong-cheol, spokesperson for the Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations (KFTA), pointed out, "Before converting jasago and similar schools to regular high schools, there needs to be proof that regular high schools can also provide diverse education suited to students' talents and aptitudes," adding "If they had said they would convert jasago and similar schools to regular high schools after gaining trust that regular high schools can also provide diverse education, no one would have opposed it."

He argued, "There are concerns from the education field that even if the credit system is implemented, it will remain at the level of slightly increasing elective subjects because it's difficult to realize a credit system at the high school level where students choose all classes like at universities," adding "It's unreasonable to eliminate schools that already operate diverse curricula when it's unclear at what level the credit system will operate (just because the credit system is being implemented)."

Spokesperson Cho added, "The high school system shouldn't change just because the administration changes," saying "The high school system should be designed in a direction that can provide diverse curricula to students and cultivate talent suitable for the Fourth Industrial Revolution, and this should be specified in law."

The government's plan for mass conversion of jasago, foreign language high schools, and international high schools is expected to affect the popularity of jasago and similar schools starting from this year's high school admissions.

Director Lee Man-gi said, "Would students apply to schools that are obviously going to close?" adding "As the Ministry of Education is also considering abolishing extracurricular areas in the comprehensive student record evaluation system for university early admissions, if even the curricular areas disappear, jasago would have no advantages in university admissions, so popularity will decline, though not by a large margin."

On the other hand, there's also a forecast that popularity will be maintained based on the high possibility that students who enroll before jasago and similar schools convert to regular high schools in 2025 as planned by the Ministry of Education will maintain their jasago student status until graduation."
}

{
  "translated_title": ""Should improve school records instead of expanding CSAT"... Progressive education groups reach consensus (comprehensive)",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = Progressive school teachers and education groups agreed that to enhance fairness in university admissions, improvements should be made to extracurricular items in school records and high school hierarchies should be eliminated by abolishing autonomous private high schools and foreign language high schools.

Six education groups - Education Hope Network, New School Network, Practical Education Teachers' Association, KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization), Good Teachers Movement, and National Association of Parents for True Education - held a 'Public Hearing for Normalizing Public Education and Strengthening Admissions Fairness' at the National Assembly on the 25th and announced a consensus statement containing these points.

In their consensus statement, they argued that "to strengthen admissions fairness, the following are necessary: ▲ opposing expansion of CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) ▲ improving extracurricular items in school records such as volunteer activities, awards, and autonomous clubs ▲ eliminating high school hierarchies through enforcement decree amendments ▲ transitioning CSAT and school records to absolute evaluation ▲ seeking measures to ease university hierarchies."

These groups plan to deliver the consensus statement to Democratic Party members of the National Assembly Education Committee, the Ministry of Education, and the National Association of Superintendents of Education.

Specific arguments for the consensus items were presented at the public hearing.

Shin Dong-ha, a policy committee member of the Practical Education Teachers' Association and current school teacher, said "School records are being doubted for their reliability due to some unfair elements that allow room for hagwon education or parental intervention," adding "Much was reorganized through last year's school record reform deliberation system, but parts that weren't addressed need to be organized."

Committee member Shin said "First, individual volunteer activity records should be deleted," pointing out that "since they are not school life records, they don't align with the purpose of school records, and while other external activities like outside awards and clubs have been blocked, volunteer work hasn't been blocked, making it dependent on parental connections with large gaps between urban and rural areas."

He also suggested that 'in-school award records' and 'autonomous club' items should be deleted as their side effects have grown contrary to their original purpose.

In-school award records were considered for deletion during last year's deliberation system but were changed to allow only one per semester for reasons like student encouragement. However, side effects emerged where students secure multiple awards and then choose which to include in school records. Autonomous clubs were also decided to be limited to one last year, but criticism continues about parental connections intervening.

Committee member Shin suggested "By sequentially deleting extracurricular elements like this, parental influence should be excluded and reliability and validity of admissions should be increased through subject-centered records," adding "The timing for absolute evaluation of school records and CSAT should also be reviewed in connection with declining school-age population trends and the completion timeline of the high school credit system."

[Yonhap News TV capture]

Kim Young-sik, co-representative of Good Teachers Movement, proposed "To increase transparency of the comprehensive student record admission system, a public admissions officer system should be implemented, and universities should be required to disclose comprehensive admission results data at a level that doesn't cause side effects of hagwon education expansion."

He argued "Parents' social status and economic power lead to hierarchical school systems like foreign language high schools, autonomous private high schools, science high schools, and gifted schools, forming privileged classes," adding "Through enforcement decree sunset clauses, foreign language high schools, autonomous private high schools, and international high schools should be gradually converted to general high schools, and science gifted education should be changed to a form where general high schools are commissioned with reduced science high schools."

Jeon Gyeong-won, director of KTU's True Education Research Institute, analyzed "University admission systems reflect parents' socioeconomic status more in the order of essay exams, CSAT, comprehensive student records, and student record subject-based admissions," noting "During the CSAT system, fewer than 500 high schools nationwide produced Seoul National University students, but after changing to the comprehensive student record system, about 900 schools are producing Seoul National University students."

Director Jeon added "The Moon Jae-in administration should convert school records and CSAT to absolute evaluation as promised," stating "Evaluation and selection should be conducted in a direction that eases competition among students, parents, and school teachers."

Na Myeong-ju, president of the National Association of Parents for True Education, said "Discrimination in the labor market based on educational background must be eliminated, and blind hiring should be mandated," adding "If social discrimination based on educational background doesn't exist, (public education) won't be subordinated to university admissions."

```json
{
  "translated_title": ""Score-based evaluation is not 'educational fairness'... Must consider disadvantaged groups"",
  "translated_text": "A memorial altar set up on September 6th at Korea University's Democracy Plaza in Seoul's Seongbuk District, related to allegations of admission privileges for Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk's daughter. Korea University students declared that 'equality of opportunity, fairness of process, and justice of results' had died from chronic ailments (hypocrisy and expedience). [Yonhap News file photo]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = As President Moon Jae-in identified high school hierarchies and university admission fairness issues as 'systems that harm equal opportunity,' 'fairness' has been thrown to the Ministry of Education as a hot topic.

As the Ministry of Education begins full-scale reform of the university admission system, voices in the education sector argue that rather than focusing only on formal fairness in university admissions, fairness should be granted from an educational perspective.

On the 12th, Professor Kim Jae-woong of Sogang University's Education Department, Professor Kang Tae-jung of Chung-Ang University's Education Department, and Professor Park Sang-wan of Busan National University of Education's Education Department pointed out in their paper 'Discussion on the Meaning of University Admission Fairness from an Educational Perspective' published in the quarterly journal 'Korean Education' Issue 46 by the Korean Educational Development Institute that "university admission system discussions so far have only focused on competitors for major universities, while not considering students who cannot attend university for various reasons or students whose grades are 'lowered' for higher rankings."

The research team presented the problem awareness that "university admission fairness discourse has been biased toward political and social perspectives, with insufficient discussion from an 'educational perspective,'" and that admission fairness should be examined from the perspective of 'how to distribute university education opportunities justly' considering 'all students' right to education and right not to be discriminated against or excluded from provided education.'

A scene from the 'Jongno Academy 2020 University Admission Rolling Admissions Strategy Briefing' held on July 21st at Seoul Jinseon Girls' High School auditorium [Yonhap News file photo]

In this regard, the research team surveyed a total of 240 people including 178 high school teachers and 62 admissions officers, and conducted Focus Group Interviews (FGI) with 13 experts including 5 high school teachers, 3 admissions directors, 2 faculty admissions officers, 2 professors, and 1 admissions officer.

The survey results showed that both teachers and admissions officers answered that considering both 'CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) scores' and 'applicants' background factors' together would create a fairer admission process.

Responses such as 'it is fair to use CSAT scores as a standard within each category by distinguishing region, gender, school type, etc.' and 'score standards should be lowered for applicants with disadvantageous home and school environments' were more prevalent than responses saying 'only CSAT scores should be used.'

Regarding the survey results, the research team emphasized that "there are more positions that find fairness in progressive consideration to check structural opportunity inequality rather than in score-based uniformity (equity)," and "this means that distribution based on 'ability' is not the golden rule of fairness, and educational opportunity distribution should maximally consider disadvantaged groups."

Students at Daegu Gyeongbuk High School taking the June mock exam for the 2020 College Scholastic Ability Test [Yonhap News file photo]

However, both teachers and admissions officers criticized that there are fairness problems with the current CSAT and comprehensive school record admissions (student record comprehensive evaluation).

For CSAT, problems cited were 'significant influence of hagwon education' (36.2%), 'insufficient consideration of non-academic characteristics such as character and special talents' (30.2%), and 'high possibility of luck playing a role in a one-time test' (25.4%).

For comprehensive school record admissions, problems pointed out included 'differences in school record documentation by school and teacher' (45.2%), 'reliability issues with school record documentation' (20.4%), and 'lack of transparency in the admission process' (17.8%).

Regarding which admission type is fairer between CSAT-focused and school record-focused admissions, teachers favored CSAT-focused admissions (52.9%) while admissions officers favored school record-focused admissions (54.8%).

However, both teachers and admissions officers drew the line that "evaluation methods that apply the same standards to all applicants are not desirable."

As measures to improve university admission fairness, opinions that gained significant support included "restrictions should be placed to prevent frequent changes to the admission system," "entrance exam-focused education should be resolved," "diverse admission types should be utilized," and "admission quotas should be allocated for applicants with disadvantaged backgrounds."

Parents praying for 100 days for CSAT success on August 7th at Seoul Doseonsa Temple's main hall, 99 days before the 2020 College Scholastic Ability Test [Yonhap News file photo]

The research team pointed out that "looking at the controversies that arose during the recent university admission system reform process, there is a confrontational pattern between positions that define ability as 'CSAT-focused' and positions that define it as 'school record-focused,'" and "the former argues that viewing ability as 'scores' is just, while the latter criticizes that regional and family factors also influence scores."

They expressed concern that "if fairness is narrowly perceived by focusing on the formal aspects of the system, it will only obscure deeper injustices and overlook the influence that the university admission system has on Korean society as a whole."

The research team suggested that securing university admission fairness requires expanding active measures such as regional balanced selection and equal opportunity admissions, strengthening admissions officer expertise and ethics, disclosing information about admitted students including their high school backgrounds, regions, and social classes by university admission type, and reducing income gaps between education levels.
```

{

  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Jin Yeon-su = On the afternoon of July 29, participants discuss at a forum titled 'Policy Assessment of Converting Autonomous Private High Schools to Regular High Schools and Examination of Future Tasks' held at NAEYC (No More Worry about Private Education), a civic organization, in Yongsan-gu, Seoul. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = A claim has emerged that non-curricular areas should be reflected less than currently in the comprehensive student record evaluation system for early admissions [university admissions conducted before regular admissions] in order to create a fair university entrance examination system.

The civic organization NAEYC (No More Worry about Private Education) held a press conference at their office in Yongsan-gu, Seoul on the 4th, arguing that "the President's directive to 'review the college entrance system' should not be understood as meaning to expand regular admissions, nor should one argue that there is nothing to fix in the current comprehensive evaluation system."

NAEYC stated that to ensure fairness in college admissions, award records and autonomous club activities listed in school life records, as well as personal statements, should be excluded from comprehensive evaluation factors. This is because these evaluation elements can vary in quantity and quality depending on the abilities of parents or school teachers, not the students themselves.

In particular, NAEYC pointed out regarding club activities that "after small thesis (R&E) activities were banned from being recorded in student records last year, hagwon education [Korea's private tutoring industry] emerged trying to replace this with 'club activity reports.'"

NAEYC also proposed introducing a 'public admissions officer system' that mandates participation of state-dispatched admissions officers in the student selection process, and establishing a 'University Admissions Fair Management Committee.'

They also emphasized that "because there is discrimination in the job market based on school background, competition to obtain good academic credentials becomes fierce," stressing the urgent need to enact an 'Educational Background Discrimination Prohibition Act.'

NAEYC argued that "in the medium to long term, specialized high schools and autonomous private high schools, which are perceived as 'advantageous positions' for getting into prestigious universities, should be converted to regular high schools, and university hierarchies should be alleviated," and "the government should not superficially accept the 'demands for fairness improvement' from young people in their 20s but should come up with fundamental solutions."

NAEYC decided to launch a signature campaign starting that day for the 'abolition of the three major toxic elements in comprehensive evaluations,' including award records.

KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) also issued a statement that day regarding President Moon's directive to review the college entrance system, stating that "we oppose the trend to expand the proportion of regular admissions in college entrance exams following the controversy over Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk's daughter's college admission."

Regarding comprehensive evaluations, KTU demanded the abolition of personal statements and teacher recommendation letters, disclosure of evaluation criteria and results, and establishment of objection procedures.

Regarding the overall college entrance and education system, they urged exploration of ways to simplify the college entrance system, absolute evaluation for CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) and high school GPA [school records] exams, and revision of elementary and secondary education laws to eliminate high school hierarchies.

According to related laws, to overhaul the entire college admissions system, it must be announced four years before implementation, so even if a new system is introduced in the second half of this year, it can only be implemented for the 2024 academic year. Both high school system reform and the high school credit system are for public education normalization and innovation. {
  "translated_title": "Education Community Says 'No to Hasty Decisions' in Unison Over President's 'College Admissions Review' Order",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul·Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporters Lee Jae-young and Lee Hyo-seok = President Moon Jae-in's order to 'review the university admissions system to strengthen fairness' has reignited debate over college entrance reform.

On the 3rd, educational organizations and figures expressed sympathy with the president's directive to strengthen college admission fairness, but voiced concerns about hasty reforms being implemented to fulfill so-called 'VIP instructions.'

Progressive teacher organizations directly criticized the president's remarks.

Kwon Jeong-oh, chairman of KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization), mentioned that the president's directive came in connection with the controversy over Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk's daughter's college admission issues, pointing out that "it was reckless to order a review of the current admissions system based on problems from 10 years ago."

Chairman Kwon emphasized, "The college admissions system is not something to be reviewed based on presidential orders," adding, "Policies that became presidential campaign promises after extensive discussions among educational organizations, such as implementing absolute grading for CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) and converting autonomous private high schools to regular high schools, are not being properly implemented. Fulfilling these promises should be the first step toward normalizing the admissions system."

The Progressive Educators' Practice Group criticized in a statement, "We hope this is not an attempt to use admissions to avoid a political crisis," adding, "It is regrettable that school education faces the crisis of returning to the old problem-solving approach as expectations for expanding regular admissions [test-score based admissions] grow due to the president's directive."

Conversely, voices emerged calling for a comprehensive review and improvement of not only the admissions system but the entire educational system, given the repeated controversies over college admissions.

Cho Seong-cheol, spokesperson for the Korean Federation of Teachers' Associations, said, "Given the recent controversies over college admission fairness, this was a directive the supreme leader of state affairs could reasonably make," adding, "What's important is how the Ministry of Education, as the responsible department, will respond to the president's directive."

Spokesperson Cho emphasized, "If the admissions system changes hastily and becomes a patchwork, it will actually benefit the upper classes who have information and strong adaptability," stressing, "We should first ensure the 2022 academic year admissions reform plan announced last year is well-established in schools while finding areas for improvement."

Koo Bon-chang, policy director at Citizens' Coalition for Economic Justice in Education, argued, "College admission fairness can only be secured when fairness in corporate recruitment markets is secured," adding, "We should alleviate the burden of preparing for extracurricular activities related to the comprehensive student record evaluation system [which faces many criticisms for unfairness], while enacting a law prohibiting discrimination based on school background to improve recruitment market unfairness."

Professor Kim Kyung-hoe of Sungshin Women's University's Education Department advised, "The admissions system should not be drastically changed based on one presidential remark," emphasizing, "Since 'institutional stability' is most important for college admissions, we should meticulously adjust details rather than make major changes."

There are also predictions that the admissions system review following the presidential directive will fizzle out without producing significant results.

Considering that last year's public deliberation on admissions reform essentially failed and the president's remaining term, the view is that additional admissions reform within the current administration would be difficult.

Education commentator Lee Beom said, "We reached a 'conclusion' on the admissions system through last year's public deliberation, so modifying it again would be nearly impossible," adding, "Even if the president issued the directive with the will to change the admissions system, bureaucrats would have no will to implement it."

Lee added, "The comprehensive evaluation system particularly combines the interests of elementary and secondary education, which emphasizes school records [GPA], and universities that want to evaluate extracurricular areas," noting, "We must keep in mind that there are no education bureaucrats free from such interests."

```json
{
  "translated_title": "Voices calling for 'abolition of comprehensive admissions, expansion of standardized testing' grow louder, but... prospects for realization are 'slim'",
  "translated_text": "Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye looks on as ruling and opposition party lawmakers argue over Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk at a National Assembly Education Committee plenary session held on August 26. [Yonhap News file photo]

(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hyo-seok = As controversy continues over Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk's daughter's university admission process, the issue of fairness in rolling admissions is once again under scrutiny.

Voices expressing distrust in the fairness of the comprehensive school record evaluation system (hakjongjonghap), which occupies a large proportion of current university admissions, are emerging alongside arguments to unify admissions based solely on CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) scores as in the past.

As of the 31st, a petition on the Blue House National Petition Board demanding "a comprehensive investigation of all those who entered university through admissions officer and comprehensive evaluation systems" has gained the consent of approximately 40,000 people in just one week.

The petitioner stated, "There are many cases more serious than underage research papers, such as false entries in school records regarding extracurricular awards and overseas experiences," and demanded, "If a comprehensive investigation is difficult, at least investigate top universities like Seoul National University, Korea University, and Yonsei University to raise awareness."

Another petition argued to "abolish rolling admissions, which are a hotbed of admission corruption," claiming "During the CSAT era, regardless of wealth or family background, students entered prestigious universities based solely on ability, but corruption has run rampant since the introduction of rolling admissions and comprehensive evaluations." This petition gained the consent of approximately 15,000 people.

Such Blue House petitions demonstrate the climate of distrust toward comprehensive evaluations and rolling admissions.

Mr. Jeong (52), who sent his eldest daughter to university and whose second son is in his second year of high school, raised his voice saying, "If we unified with CSAT, it would be easier to prepare and more convenient for teachers and universities too, so I don't understand why they increased rolling admissions," adding "Watching my child prepare for comprehensive evaluations through school and extracurricular activities looks so difficult."

Members of the 'Parents' Group Promoting Standardized Test Expansion' and 'Education Reform Movement Headquarters' call for the abolition of rolling admissions and an audit of Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk's children's admissions in front of Korea University's main gate in Seoul on the 23rd. [Yonhap News file photo]

However, the abolition of rolling admissions or comprehensive evaluations has slim prospects for realization at present.

Most experts, including education bureaucrats and academics, shake their heads at the question 'Isn't standardized testing fairer than rolling admissions?'

While CSAT appears more fair at first glance because everyone takes the same test at the same time, there are many research findings that standardized tests like CSAT are actually more unfair in terms of equal opportunity because they favor those with higher parental income and more hagwon education.

This trend is clearly visible in the 2015 research results 'The Impact of Parents' Education and Income Levels on Intergenerational Mobility and Opportunity Inequality' published by Professor Choi Pil-seon of Konkuk University, an expert in economic statistics, and Professor Min In-sik of Kyung Hee University.

This research examined how parents' education and income levels in 2007, when university admissions were centered on standardized testing and CSAT, affected their children's university enrollment and CSAT scores.

The results confirmed a tendency for higher parental income to correlate with higher children's CSAT scores.

When parents were in the 5th income quintile, the rate of their children achieving CSAT grades 1-2 reached 11.0%, but when parental income dropped to the 1st quintile, the rate of children achieving CSAT grades 1-2 was only 2.3%, showing nearly a five-fold difference.

There are also public opinion survey results showing that higher income levels correlate with support for 'standardized test expansion.'

In a Korean Educational Development Institute survey of 2,000 men and women last year, higher-income groups were more likely to choose CSAT scores as 'the item that should be most reflected in university admission processes.'

38.2% of respondents with monthly income of 6 million won [approximately $4,500 USD] or more chose CSAT, while 29.7% of those with income of 4-6 million won [approximately $3,000-4,500 USD] selected CSAT.

In contrast, respondents with income of 2-4 million won [approximately $1,500-3,000 USD] answered that 'special talents/aptitudes (30.4%)' should be most reflected in university admissions. 28.6% of respondents with income below 2 million won [approximately $1,500 USD] also chose special talents/aptitudes.

Regarding this, one education statistics expert analyzed, "Like other fields, but especially in education, public opinion tends to be formed centered on Seoul metropolitan area residents, highly educated, high-income parents," adding "Parents who can afford hagwon education believe that CSAT has clearer hagwon education effects than comprehensive evaluations."

From the Ministry of Education's perspective, the fact that last year's public deliberation process on university admission systems resulted in a '30% standardized testing' conclusion also serves as grounds for viewing calls to abolish rolling admissions as partial and temporary.

The comprehensive investigation of rolling admissions and comprehensive evaluations demanded by some is also practically impossible.

A Ministry of Education official stated, "If we broadly divide comprehensive evaluations, it's a two-stage structure where students create application materials through activities inside and outside school, and universities evaluate these," adding "Conducting a comprehensive investigation of this would mean investigating all universities, high schools, teachers, and volunteer organizations as potential criminals, which is absolutely impossible."

While investigations based on specific case reports are possible—like the case of a student who fabricated research achievements with help from their mother, a pharmacy professor, to enter Seoul National University graduate school but had their admission canceled—comprehensive investigations are practically difficult.

Parental income level and children's CSAT score correlation [Paper capture / 'The Impact of Parents' Education and Income Levels on Intergenerational Mobility and Opportunity Inequality' (2015)]

The Ministry of Education maintains its position of continuing efforts to enhance the credibility of comprehensive evaluations.

The Ministry of Education stated, "While conducting university audits, we will focus on confirming whether admission processes are unfair, and continue to examine whether there are areas for improvement to make comprehensive evaluations a trustworthy university admission system."
```

Superintendent Cho acknowledged that converting only some autonomous private schools to general high schools through operational evaluation would create conflict and has the limitation of further increasing the popularity of schools that pass the evaluation.

In particular, Superintendent Cho proposed, "If the Ministry of Education has no intention of revising elementary and secondary education laws, let's proceed with public deliberation on whether to abolish autonomous private schools and foreign language schools at the National Education Council (Committee)."

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Choi Jae-gu = Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education Superintendent Cho Hee-yeon announces comprehensive support plans for general high schools, including mutual growth support measures for autonomous private schools transitioning to general high schools, at a press briefing held at the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education on the 17th. jjaeck9@yna.co.kr

Regarding students from recently cancelled autonomous private schools who petitioned for meetings, Superintendent Cho stated he would "sincerely present his position," noting that the timing and method of response are under discussion with working-level staff.

A Ministry of Education official explained, "Even though university freshmen and sophomores have sufficient knowledge and ability to teach as educational hagwon instructors, they have been unable to obtain instructor qualifications," adding, "We intend to revise the enforcement decree to guarantee the freedom of occupational choice for young people in their early twenties."

Additionally, the Ministry of Education decided to supplement the lack of clear standards for refunding tuition fees when hagwon operators implement quarantine measures for students who contract infectious diseases under the Hagwon Act. The standard will be based on the date when grounds for refund occur, such as when quarantine measures are implemented.

For reading rooms, although their operating methods and fee-setting approaches differ somewhat from hagwons, their usage fee refund standards had been identical to hagwon tuition fees. The revision will include content to modify these standards to be appropriate for reading rooms.
