{
  "translated_title": "Japan's Labor Shortage and Side Job Permission Lead to Expansion of Short-Term 'Gig Working'",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Hae-young = "Working at times that are convenient for them, only as much as they like, in ways they prefer"

A work style where people take on short-term tasks through internet sites without making long-term contracts with companies is spreading in Japan, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported on the 5th.

This phenomenon has emerged as digital technology development has made it possible to mediate between various 'workers' and 'workplaces,' from restaurant part-time jobs to specialized accounting work. It is known that over 4 million members are registered with the six major publicly listed intermediary services. Including unlisted emerging intermediary services, there are estimates that registered users reach 7 million annually, representing a 40% increase over the past year.

While simple comparison is difficult since many people register with multiple service companies, this represents a scale equivalent to 10% of Japan's total workforce, estimated at approximately 67 million people.

This work style, also called 'gig working' - combining the English word 'gig' meaning temporary day-to-day employment and 'worker' - is spreading due to Japan's serious labor shortage, plus changes in the work environment from work style reforms that the government and companies are promoting, including encouraging side jobs.

Due to aging and population decline, Japan is expected to face shortages of 290,000 workers in the restaurant industry and 340,000 workers in elderly and patient care sectors within five years.

The government is promoting the recruitment of foreign workers, but complete replacement with foreigners is difficult to expect. Additionally, besides the existing six listed companies, new intermediary services are continuously emerging, including 'Taimee,' which introduces talent to the food and retail industries; 'Sukedachi,' which is strong in construction industry labor intermediation; and 'Hacobell,' which promotes utilizing truck drivers' free time.

In Taimee's case, when you register available time slots and locations on your smartphone, they connect you with suitable candidates when part-time job recruitment companies contact them. With just a few simple mobile phone operations without interviews or other procedures, you can find part-time work and receive payment immediately after finishing the job.

[Taimee homepage capture]

Watanabe Tenma (27), who works five days a week as a hagwon instructor for college entrance exams, did a side job distributing promotional tissues at an eyewear store in Tokyo on Saturday when he wasn't teaching, through Taimee in late last month.

After finishing distributing 600 tissues in 4 hours, he moved to Yokohama and worked at an izakaya [Japanese-style pub] for 4.5 hours starting at 6 PM, then worked part-time at a sushi restaurant in Tokyo for 4 hours the next day, Sunday.

Through such 'side jobs,' he earns about 100,000 yen [approximately $750 USD] per month at most. He said, "I can easily experience various types of work, so it's always fresh."

The government included side job promotion in the growth strategy prepared last month. The policy intention is to diversify work styles and support innovation through talent mobility. A survey conducted by Nihon Keizai in May showed that half of 120 major companies allow their employees to have side jobs.

'Visasq' (Tokyo Meguro), which started a service in 2013 connecting those hoping for side jobs with job seekers, has 90,000 major company employees registered who can provide advice for various businesses. They respond to consultations from individuals and companies seeking advice using their free time on weekday evenings or weekends, receiving compensation of about 15,000 yen [approximately $110 USD] per hour. The number of 'experts' registered with Visasq has increased fivefold in three years.

A housewife (35) living in Kawasaki city works about 60-80 hours per month from home, earning 70,000-90,000 yen [approximately $520-670 USD]. 'Merry Biz' (Tokyo Chuo-ku), an accounting proxy service, processes expense settlement and financial statement preparation tasks commissioned by client companies using such workforce. About 750 housewives nationwide connected online handle the actual work.

Kudo Hiroki, president of Merry Biz, said, "Companies can increase productivity in their main business by outsourcing accounting work externally."

{
  "translated_title": "Wage Employment Jobs Increased by 360,000 in Q4 Last Year...Health & Welfare Up 110,000↑",
  "translated_text": "(Sejong=Yonhap News) Reporters Kim Yeon-jeong and Kim Kyung-yoon = Wage employment jobs increased by approximately 359,000 compared to a year ago in the fourth quarter of last year, showing an expanded growth rate.

Wage employment jobs increased significantly, centered on health and social welfare services due to the effects of government job programs, but construction, business services and leasing, and manufacturing jobs continued their decline, showing mixed situations across industries.

According to the 'Q4 2018 (November basis) Wage Employment Job Trends' data released by Statistics Korea on the 20th, total wage employment jobs (hereafter 'jobs') in Q4 last year were 18.494 million, an increase of 359,000 (2.0%) compared to the same period the previous year.

The job growth rate compared to the same period the previous year had continuously shrunk from 315,000 in Q1 last year (February basis) to 245,000 in Q2 (May basis) and 213,000 in Q3 (August basis), but expanded in Q4.

Among Q4 jobs last year, 'continuing jobs' occupied by the same workers as the previous year numbered 12.408 million (67.1%), while jobs where workers were replaced due to retirement or job changes numbered 3.247 million (17.6%).

New jobs created through business establishment or expansion numbered 2.84 million (15.4%), while eliminated jobs that disappeared due to business closure or downsizing numbered 2.481 million.

Looking at job changes by industry in Q4 last year, health and social welfare increased by 114,000 jobs, wholesale and retail by 92,000, professional, scientific and technical services by 46,000, and education by 44,000.

Public administration, defense and social security administration also increased by 38,000, and accommodation and food services increased by 38,000.

Statistics Korea interpreted that government job-related policies influenced job growth in health and social welfare services and wholesale and retail sectors.

Park Jin-woo, Director of the Administrative Statistics Division at Statistics Korea, said, "In health and social welfare, demand for medical and health personnel increased, leading to significant job growth centered on women in their 50s and 60s, and in wholesale and retail, as production continued to expand, employment insurance subscribers increased, which was captured in job expansion statistics."

Regarding factors in job growth, he explained, "Wholesale and retail production increased due to economic factors, policy-wise employment insurance subscribers increased due to expanded implementation of job stability fund support, and institutionally, the mandatory enrollment conditions for employment insurance were relaxed for ultra-short-time workers classified as those working less than 60 hours per month, expanding employment insurance enrollment regardless of livelihood considerations."

Conversely, construction jobs decreased by 96,000, business services and leasing by 38,000, and manufacturing by 12,000.

Comparing construction jobs to the same period the previous year, they decreased by 35,000 in Q1, 84,000 in Q2, and 113,000 in Q3 last year, with the decline expanding, but the declining trend slowed in Q4.

Business facility management, business support, and leasing services decreased by 4,000 in Q1, 28,000 in Q2, 36,000 in Q3, and 38,000 in Q4 last year, expanding the decline.

The manufacturing job decline expanded from 16,000 in Q2 and 19,000 in Q3 last year, then contracted to 12,000 in Q4.

Director Park Jin-woo explained, "Manufacturing and construction continue to see job decreases due to economic conditions and restructuring aftereffects."

Looking at jobs by age, those 50 and over increased significantly, but those in their 40s decreased.

In Q4 last year, jobs for those in their 50s increased by 166,000 compared to the same period the previous year, those 60 and over by 151,000, those in their 20s and under by 56,000, and those in their 30s by 12,000 respectively.

However, jobs for those in their 40s decreased by 26,000, centered on construction and manufacturing.

By gender, women's jobs increased by 283,000 and men's by 75,000 respectively.

By enterprise type, government and non-corporate organization jobs increased by 128,000, corporate jobs by 118,000, non-corporate legal entities by 96,000, and individual enterprises by 17,000.

Director Park said, "As job growth expanded in Q4 last year, men's jobs, jobs for those in their 30s, and individual enterprise jobs all turned to growth after declining in the previous quarter," adding "However, we need to watch a bit longer to see if this trend continues."

This survey targeted wage employment jobs, which differs from employment trends shown in the Economically Active Population Survey that includes non-wage workers.

The survey results identified jobs of workers engaged in wage labor activities at enterprises based on eight types of administrative data available monthly and quarterly, including social insurance, daily labor income, and business registration data.

Here, 'jobs' refers to employment positions occupied by workers, which has a different meaning from 'employed persons.'

For instance, job numbers are calculated based on working days, so if someone worked only 15 days in a month, the job count is calculated as 0.5.

Also, if someone working at a trading company also works as a hagwon instructor at night, there is one employed person but multiple jobs can be counted.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Seo Myeong-gon = Job seekers examine the job posting board at the 'Job Search Day 19th' event held at Songpa District Office in Seoul on the afternoon of the 19th. 2019.6.19 seephoto@yna.co.kr

(Ulsan=Yonhap News) Reporter Heo Gwangmu = A supplementary hagwon instructor who was charged with physically and mentally abusing hagwon students through corporal punishment received a fine in the appeals court.

The Ulsan District Court Criminal Appeals Division 2 (Chief Judge Kim Gwangu) announced on the 19th that it overturned the original court's suspended sentence and sentenced Mr. A (50), who was brought to trial on charges of violating the Child Welfare Act, to a fine of 3 million won [approximately $2,250 USD]. The court also ordered A to be banned from employment at child-related institutions for one year.

A was indicted on charges of physically and mentally abusing student B (8 years old) under his instruction in December 2017 by repeatedly hitting the child's soles and back with a wooden stick and his hands because the child did poorly on a Chinese character test, and by pulling down B's pants while he was standing in front of the blackboard for being unable to solve math problems alone, exposing his underwear.

The first trial court ruled for a suspended sentence, stating "All criminal facts are recognized as guilty, and he has not received forgiveness from the victim child and parents," but also noting "Just receiving a guilty verdict alone serves as an opportunity for reflection, and there appears to be no risk of reoffending."

A suspended sentence is a ruling for minor crimes where the sentencing is postponed for a certain period, and if two years pass from the suspension date, it is effectively treated as if nothing happened.

In response, A appealed, claiming "I never committed physical abuse, and pulling down the pants was also to teach problem-solving methods, so it was not emotional abuse." The prosecutor also appealed, arguing that the original sentence was too light.

However, the appeals court stated "It is difficult to see that the defendant's actions do not violate social norms or that they are justified acts without illegality," and explained the sentencing reasons by saying "We considered that child abuse crimes are serious offenses that have profound effects on victims, and that they caused physical and emotional harm to the victim."

{
  "translated_title": ""Teacher career certificates should allow removal of criminal records when unrelated to employment restrictions"",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Ui-rae = The National Human Rights Commission of Korea has expressed the opinion that former education public officials who retired after committing sex crimes should be able to remove criminal records and other sensitive information from their career certificates, unless they are seeking employment at child and youth-related institutions where they are restricted from working for a certain period.

According to the Human Rights Commission on the 26th, Mr. A, who was an elementary school teacher, was sentenced to three years of probation for a sex crime in 2013 and was automatically dismissed from his position.

After the periods for both disclosure of sex offender personal information under relevant laws and disqualification from public service appointment had passed, Mr. A applied for a career certificate to seek employment as a hagwon instructor. However, the reason for retirement section still specified 'probation,' and the position suspension section stated 'disciplinary decision request (severe discipline),' making it impossible for him to find employment.

Mr. A filed a complaint with the Human Rights Commission, arguing that it constituted a human rights violation for career certificates to mandatorily include not only career information but also personal information such as criminal records and information he did not wish to disclose.

The Human Rights Commission mentioned that under the current Act on the Protection of Children and Youth against Sex Offenses, those convicted of sex crimes are restricted from employment at child and youth-related institutions such as hagwons or tutoring centers for up to 10 years, stating "recording the reasons for retirement or position suspension in Mr. A's career certificate can hardly be seen as a human rights violation" and dismissed the complaint.

However, the Human Rights Commission determined that except in cases like Mr. A's where criminal records or disciplinary reasons must necessarily be disclosed, sensitive personal information should not have to be recorded in career certificates.

The intent is that when seeking employment at institutions that do not restrict employment based on crime type, individuals should be able to keep information they do not wish to disclose private, ensuring protection of personal information self-determination rights and freedom of occupational choice.

The Human Rights Commission stated to the Minister of Education that "revision of the 'Rules on Personnel Records and Personnel Affairs Processing for Education Public Officials' is necessary to allow issuance of career certificates with sensitive personal information deleted upon the individual's request."

{
  "translated_title": "Hired contract workers, used dual contracts to obtain employment promotion subsidies… Court orders "repayment"",
  "translated_text": "[Provided by Yonhap News TV]

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Song Jin-won = A business owner who hired contract hagwon instructors but used dual contracts to make it appear as if regular employees were hired has been ordered to return employment promotion subsidies received from the government.

According to legal circles on the 19th, the Administrative Court of Seoul's 6th Administrative Division (Presiding Judge Lee Seong-yong) dismissed Mr. A's claim in a lawsuit filed against the competent labor office requesting "cancellation of the employment promotion subsidy return order."

Hagwon instructor Mr. B worked at a language hagwon operated by Mr. A starting from July 20, 2015.

When hiring Mr. B, Mr. A created an 'instructor contract' that included clauses stating that contracts would be renewed at specific times each year, and that no objections would be raised if renewal was not offered.

Mr. A later created a standard employment contract retroactively dating Mr. B's employment as a regular employee.

The following year, claiming that 'Mr. B completed the Job Success Package, an employment support program by the Ministry of Employment and Labor,' Mr. A applied to the labor office for employment promotion subsidies and received 9 million won [approximately $6,800 USD] for one year.

The Job Success Package is a counseling, training, and job placement service for low-income employment-vulnerable groups and unemployed young and middle-aged adults. Business owners who employ job seekers who have completed this program as regular employees for three months or more can receive employment promotion subsidies. However, subsidies cannot be received if the employment contract period is short-term.

The labor office issued Mr. A an order to return the subsidies along with an additional collection penalty of 18 million won [approximately $13,600 USD], stating that he illegally received subsidies despite hiring Mr. B as a contract worker.

Mr. A filed a lawsuit claiming "I hired Mr. B as a regular employee and had no intention of illegally applying for subsidies."

However, the court dismissed Mr. A's claim, stating "Mr. B's actual salary, working hours, and other important working conditions correspond to the instructor contract, not the standard employment contract."

The court pointed out, "Unless there are special circumstances, there is no reason for two employment contracts to be created for one employment relationship," and "The standard employment contract created with a retroactive date after an effective instructor contract had already been established between the parties appears likely to have been created for a separate purpose."

  "translated_text": "[Provided by Gokseong County]

(Gokseong=Yonhap News) Reporter Park Cheol-hong = Three young farmer friends who moved to rural Gokseong County are breathing new life into Gokseong's strawberry farms.

Kim Gwan-tae (34) left his hagwon instructor life in the city and moved to rural Gokseong last summer.

In his first year of farming, he cultivated strawberries in three greenhouse facilities.

Due to labor shortages in rural areas, Kim occasionally asked his friends Kim Won (34) and Kim Min-jun (34) for help.

After visiting Gokseong several times, his friends also naturally settled in Gokseong and moved to rural farming.

The three friends with the surname Kim decided to become young farmers and chose to move to rural Gokseong because they were confident in the success potential of Gokseong strawberries.

The three young farmers have their own farming principles: community-style farm management.

The three friends farm as a team on a joint farm, sell together, and share profits.

They pursue farming with 'joy' rather than difficult farming.

Their dream is to create a world-class agricultural product brand using Gokseong strawberries, like Dole or Zespri.

As their primary goal, they set a target to export fresh Gokseong strawberries to Southeast Asian markets within five years, and this year they began strawberry seedling cultivation on approximately 4,600 square meters of leased farmland.

They also plan to rent an additional 10 greenhouse facilities to cultivate winter strawberries.

Gokseong County also helped the three friends realize their dream of becoming young farmers.

[Provided by Gokseong County]

Gokseong County actively supported the projects they needed.

The county supported rental costs for four greenhouse facilities and reduced the burden of initial investment costs through the Young Startup Farm Support Project.

Through the Young Farmer Settlement Support Project, they are providing up to 1 million won [approximately $750 USD] per month in farming funds for three years.

Behind Gokseong County's active support for young farmers lies the county's agricultural policy goal of fostering 100 new young farmers by 2022.

Gokseong County Mayor Yoo Geun-gi said on the 15th, "Recently, there has been an increase in young successor farmers who want to inherit their parents' farming," and "We will spare no support in fostering the 2030 young farmer generation as successor manpower for rural areas so that agriculture and rural communities can be revitalized through generational change in agriculture."

{
  "translated_title": "[Card News] Memorial Day: The Attitude We Should Have",
  "translated_text": "<<Text for audio information support for the visually impaired>>
Memorial Day: A day designated to commemorate the loyalty of soldiers and patriotic martyrs who died fighting for the country.
Source / Korean Dictionary

Today marks the 63rd Memorial Day. It was designated in 1956 to commemorate the war dead who died during the Korean War. However, not many people accurately understand and commemorate the meaning of this day.

The National Cemetery is a national cemetery where the spirits of those who sacrificed their lives for the country and nation are laid to rest.
Source / Doosan Encyclopedia

Citizens' attitudes toward this place, which should be accompanied by solemnity, are being pointed out as problematic.

The National Cemetery is suffering from household waste.
Source / Daejeon National Cemetery

Daejeon National Cemetery has a problem with the steadily increasing amount of waste generated within the grounds. While 90% of this consists of wreaths within the burial areas, household waste such as food scraps is gradually increasing, raising concerns about environmental pollution.

"The National Cemetery has free access, so we cannot restrict visitors" - Official from Seoul National Cemetery

Seoul National Cemetery sometimes has problems with visitors who come for outings. While most visitors maintain proper etiquette toward the National Cemetery, complaints are sometimes filed due to some citizens who shout or drink alcohol.

Awareness of Memorial Day has not been well established either. 66% of middle and high school students did not know on which national holidays or commemorative days the flag should be displayed.
Source / Elite uniform brand survey of elementary, middle, and high school students

One government office was even criticized for failing to fly the Korean flag at half-mast on Memorial Day.

"People perceive Memorial Day simply as a day off or a day to pray. More education is needed" - Ms. Yeo (23), hagwon teacher

"Especially younger students have no idea at all. For students, it's just a day off" - Mr. Choi (26), elementary school teacher

Teachers say that students, especially, often don't understand the meaning of Memorial Day.

Yu Gwan-sun, a patriot who died while shouting for independence during the March 1st Movement
Park Eun-sik, an independence activist during Japanese colonial rule who served as the second president of the Provisional Government
Major Kang Jae-gu, who died saving his subordinates during Vietnam War deployment training

Approximately 300,000 people who sacrificed themselves for the country rest in the National Cemetery.
Source / Seoul National Cemetery, Daejeon National Cemetery

How about taking a moment of silent prayer today for those who made today's safe Republic of Korea possible.

(Seoul=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Sang-seo, Interns Park Hyo-yeon and Lee Han-na

{
  "translated_title": "'Korean Language Fever' Confirmed in Vietnam… Korean Language Department Students Up 25% in 2 Years",
  "translated_text": "(Ho Chi Minh City=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = On the 5th (local time), students at Truduc High School in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam are learning Korean from teacher Heo Seon, who was dispatched by the National Institute for International Education. 2019.12.5

(Ho Chi Minh City=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = The 'Korean learning fever' experienced in Ho Chi Minh City, the economic center of southern Vietnam, was as hot as the local temperature.
Local officials met before and after the 'Vietnamese University Students Korean Speaking Contest' held at Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology on the 7th (local time) unanimously said, "The Korean language fever will continue for some time."
According to the Ho Chi Minh City Korean Language Education Institute under the Ministry of Education on the 9th, the number of Korean language department students at 12 universities in Ho Chi Minh City is currently 5,920, a 25% increase from 4,724 two years ago.
TOPIK [Korean Language Proficiency Test] test-takers in the Ho Chi Minh City area numbered 15,754 this year, a 26% increase from last year (12,478) and nearly double compared to two years ago (8,495).
Particularly in Da Nang, a tourist destination popular with Koreans where the Vietnamese government is ambitiously developing high-tech industrial complexes and Korean corporate investment is increasing, TOPIK test-takers jumped to 1,095 in October this year, doubling in just six months compared to April (507).
TOPIK test-takers across Vietnam totaled 23,939 last year, an increase of more than 10,000 from 2015 (13,160).
The 'Korean language fever' is spreading to middle and high school students, riding the Korean Wave.
Truduc High School, one of 12 pilot schools adopting Korean language in Vietnam, has 415 students taking Korean language classes as an elective, representing about 19% of the entire student body. The number of students taking Korean language classes at this school has grown significantly each year: 220 in 2017, 285 in 2018.
Vietnamese Korean language learners often start with interest in Korean due to K-pop and other Korean popular culture, then continue learning for employment purposes.
Truduc High School student Hong Ngoc (16) said, "I'm learning Korean because I'm curious about the meaning of Korean idol group song lyrics." Although Ngoc had only been learning Korean for a short time and hesitated several times even when speaking short sentences, she fluently sang 'Energetic' by Wanna One, her favorite idol group, without stopping once.
(Ho Chi Minh City=Yonhap News) Reporter Lee Jae-young = A student at Truduc High School in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam is concentrating on class with Korean language textbooks spread on her desk on the 5th (local time). 2019.12.5

YouTube is also playing a role in spreading Korean among Vietnamese youth. Hong's friend Mai Cham pointed to YouTuber 'Cherry Hyeri' as her Korean 'private tutor.' Cherry Hyeri presents videos comparing the cultures of both countries while mixing Korean and Vietnamese.
Asking Vietnamese university students studying Korean why they learn Korean was like asking Korean university students preparing for employment why they study English.
If they get jobs at Korean companies, they receive 'high wages' of 700,000-800,000 won [approximately $530-600 USD] per month, more than 2.5 times the average salary of Vietnamese university graduates. For this reason, most university students learn Korean with the goal of getting jobs at Korean companies, local officials explain.
Nguyen Thi Phuong Mai, department head of the Korean Studies Department at the University of Social Sciences and Humanities under Ho Chi Minh National University, said, "Students who major in Korean and go to Korea for language study don't need to worry about employment," adding, "Many students get jobs in their third year and delay graduation because they're working."
Thanks to the high employment rate, the Korean Studies Department is a popular department even within the prestigious University of Social Sciences and Humanities. School officials disclosed that students need to score about 5 points higher than other departments on the entrance exam out of 30 points to be in the acceptance range.
Vietnamese Korean language education officials point out that Korea's support needs to be expanded.
They say they cannot accelerate the spread of Korean because it's like having only one oar when the tide is coming in and you need to row.
The most urgent problem is securing Korean language teaching personnel.
The Korean Studies Department at the University of Social Sciences and Humanities in Ho Chi Minh City has about 720 students but currently employs 23 instructors, meaning one instructor handles about 30 students, exceeding the university's own standards (20 students per faculty member). The fact that most instructors are master's level rather than doctoral level is also an area for improvement.
Moreover, the Korean Studies Department at the University of Social Sciences and Humanities plans to establish a 'Korean Studies' major in graduate school next year, the first in Vietnam. For this graduate program to take root, professor-level instructors proficient not only in Korean language but also in Korea's politics, culture, and society overall are needed.
Insufficient Korean learning content is also cited as a problem. The Overseas Education Institution Portal created by the government to help foreigners learn Korean still has low recognition.
Heo Seon, a teacher dispatched by the National Institute for International Education who teaches Korean at Truduc High School, explained, "Korean is still a foreign language in Vietnam that only those who want it need to choose and study," adding, "Young students immediately choose other languages if they find it boring, so interesting content is necessary to consistently teach Korean."
The immediate task is to get Korean language into formal curriculum where Vietnamese middle and high school students can choose it as their first foreign language. Currently, Korean is a 'secondary school second foreign language pilot subject.'
Vietnamese middle and high school students must choose and learn one of five first foreign languages—English, Japanese, Chinese, French, or Russian—according to government policy. These first foreign languages are taught from elementary school (grades 1-5).
Japan implemented Japanese language expansion policies in Vietnam ahead of Korea and included Japanese as a formal first foreign language subject in 2016.
A Ministry of Education official stated, "We will closely cooperate with Vietnamese authorities so that Korean language will be adopted as a formal subject once the pilot subject operation ends."

{
  "translated_title": "'Cho Confirmation Hearing' Allegations and Explanations... "Criminal Acts" vs "Not True"",
  "translated_text": "(Seoul=Yonhap News) Lee Seul-ki, Lee Eun-jung, Lee Dong-hwan reporters = The National Assembly's confirmation hearing on September 6 for Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk resembled a battlefield where spears and shields clashed, with various allegations and explanations surrounding the nominee going back and forth.
(Seoul=Yonhap News) Kim Ju-hyung reporter = Justice Minister nominee Cho Kuk responds to lawmakers' questions at the Judiciary Committee confirmation hearing held at the National Assembly on the morning of September 6. kjhpress@yna.co.kr

The early part of the confirmation hearing that began at 10 a.m. focused intensively on allegations of forging a Dongyang University presidential commendation used by his daughter Ms. Cho (28) for admission to Pusan National University's graduate medical school, Professor Chung Kyung-sim's (57) removal of a PC before the search and seizure, and the contents of nominee Cho's phone conversation with Dongyang University President Choi Sung-hae.

The main opposition Liberty Korea Party presented the original Dongyang University presidential commendation and argued that Professor Chung Kyung-sim was involved in forging the commendation, pressuring that nominee Cho's direct phone conversation with President Choi Sung-hae constituted solicitation of evidence destruction.

Nominee Cho actively denied the opposition lawmakers' allegations with responses to the effect of 'that is not true' and 'I was not involved,' while responding to the ruling party lawmakers' support with 'I agree' and 'that's right,' going on the defensive.

◇ Allegations of Dongyang University Presidential Commendation Forgery

The Korea Party argued that nominee Cho's daughter forged a Dongyang University presidential commendation and submitted it for Pusan National University's graduate medical school admission.

They claimed that the official format of the Dongyang University presidential commendation has a serial number written in the upper left corner, and at the bottom it states 'Dongyang University President, Doctor of Education Choi Sung-hae.'

In contrast, the Korea Party pressed that the commendation submitted by Mr. Cho's daughter had 'Language Education Center' written in the upper left corner and at the bottom only stated 'Dongyang University President Choi Sung-hae' with 'Doctor of Education' excluded.

The Korea Party raised their voices saying that if a forged commendation was submitted for Pusan National University's graduate medical school admission, it would constitute charges of forging private documents and obstruction of official duties for interfering with the admission process of Pusan National University, a national university.

They then demanded that nominee Cho submit the original commendation or photo files that his daughter submitted to clarify the relevant allegations.

They also raised suspicions that Ms. Cho did not do volunteer work at all, noting that Professor Chung was employed at Dongyang University from July 2011, but the commendation submitted by nominee Cho's daughter stated she did volunteer work at Dongyang University from 2010 to September 2012.

The Korea Party also mentioned that Professor Kim Ju-sik, who first established Dongyang University's English Gifted Education Center, revealed that 'center instructors were native-speaking professors and assistance was directly provided by teaching assistants or instructors, so there was no need for outside volunteers in the system.'

Regarding this, nominee Cho said that if his spouse's commendation forgery were true, "I think it could constitute a crime," but refuted that the allegations were not true.

He also said, "My child went to middle and high school student programs" and "The entity issuing the commendation is also the Language Education Center, not the Gifted Education Center, so you are talking about something completely different," adding "It is a clear fact that our child did various English-related volunteer activities including English essay editing for youth in the North Gyeongsang region."

However, nominee Cho answered that "how commendations are managed is something I know nothing about."

Regarding the volunteer period starting from 2010 as stated in the commendation submitted by his daughter Ms. Cho, he said "I think it was incorrectly recorded" and "I have seen a photo of the commendation my daughter received, so I will submit it."

Democratic Party lawmakers Kim Jong-min and Park Ju-min raised the possibility that Dongyang University's certificate and commendation formats may not have been standardized, lending support to nominee Cho's side.

◇ Direct Phone Call with Dongyang University President

The Korea Party attacked that nominee Cho's direct phone conversation with Dongyang University President Choi Sung-hae regarding the university presidential commendation forgery allegations was not only inappropriate but could even constitute charges of solicitation of evidence destruction and solicitation of perjury.

Korea Party lawmaker Jang Je-won said, "The Dongyang University president reportedly has a recording file of the conversation," adding "In front, he says 'I can't talk to the parties involved because of the allegations,' but through the back door he talked to someone who raises suspicions."

Lawmaker Kim Jin-tae of the same party cited President Choi's media interview, saying "Nominee Cho saying 'the president will live and Professor Chung will live' means 'if you don't say what I want, Professor Chung will die and the president will die too,'" adding "This is implicit intimidation and coercion, and I will file a complaint against the nominee today."

Regarding this, nominee Cho explained, "At the end of my wife's phone call, I took over and had a brief conversation," adding "My wife was in a startled state and said various things including asking (President Choi) 'Didn't you delegate this?' so I took over the phone and said 'President, I can't ask you to lie, please investigate and clarify the facts.'"

Nominee Cho said, "My wife was so surprised on the day of the search and seizure that she called the president and complained while saying 'Didn't you delegate this to us?' I don't know the conversation content, but the president probably said 'I didn't do it,'" adding "At the end of the call, my wife was too excited, so I told her to 'calm down' and told the president I was sorry and just asked him to investigate well since my wife was making such claims."

◇ Allegations of Involvement in Dankook University Medical School First-Author Paper and Spouse's PC Removal

The Korea Party brought up the fact that 'Cho Kuk' was recorded as the file information creator and final saver of an English medical paper in which nominee Cho's daughter was listed as first author while attending Hanyoung Foreign Language High School as a second-year student.

This raised suspicions that nominee Cho wrote his daughter's medical paper for her.

Lawmaker Kim Jin-tae attacked, saying "Files claimed to have been written on a home PC were revealed through forensics to have been created on a Seoul National University College of Law PC."

Nominee Cho denied allegations that he helped with his daughter's paper, saying "I have two PCs at home, and the computer in my study is used by my wife and child as well."

Nominee Cho explained, "Because it's our home computer, my affiliation and name were saved," adding "Because I used a word processing program provided by Seoul National University, my name and affiliation that I had entered in advance appear. Whether it's my son or daughter, whoever uses my PC, the file information comes up as my information."

He said, "When the school (Seoul National University) provides a PC, software is automatically installed. When that PC becomes too old to use, a new PC is provided," adding "In that case, there are times when I bring home and use PCs that the school no longer uses, and if that is considered an oversight, I think it's my oversight."

Regarding the opposition's pursuit of allegations that his spouse Professor Chung Kyung-sim faced evidence destruction charges for taking a PC from Dongyang University two days before the search and seizure, nominee Cho explained, "She was in an awkward situation due to coverage by various media outlets. She probably needed to look at and check the contents of the PC in her research office," adding "But because she couldn't go to work at her research office, she went to get the PC."

Regarding the opposition's pursuit that Professor Chung's PC was found in a Korea Investment & Securities employee's car trunk, he said, "My wife was in very poor health, so a Korea Investment employee drove for her. My wife told him to hold onto the PC until she returned from going down to Busan, and they met after she returned to Seoul," adding "Later, the prosecution contacted us and we voluntarily submitted the PC as is."

Nominee Cho said, "There are many suspicions about my wife, some parts I know and some parts I don't know. Since an investigation is ongoing, I think (more suspicions) will come out," adding "I think we should naturally accept the results (regarding the prosecution's investigation)."
